- Work on high performance microprocessors using the latest technology.
- It is fun to see devices that you worked on being sold.
cons:
- High pressure, long hours.  Schedules are getting shorter with fewer people to execute.
- Limited opportunity to change job tasks.
- Focal (annual performance review) is designed to cause employee churn.  A fixed percentage of employees will be let go every year.

pros: High concentration of talented people, very intelligent and deliberate values,
cons: Talented employees identify others as 'competent' or 'incompetent' on a hair trigger - judgement is rampant. More idiots who can play the game than people with real passion or ideas.

review_title: Technology leader, innovator, deeply rooted in doing the right thing.
job_title: Business Operations Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Tremendous opportunity to understand many facets of business operations as rotations and movement is encouraged and expected.  Work-life balance is what you make it and most groups allow you to own your schedule and elected balance.
cons: While this is a super company, it is a large organization that can stumble with swift market moves.  Compensation lagging what the market demands for the cost of living in this area.

review_title: Intel provided me a place to learn and grow my skills as long as my job was completed. Great for a college student!
pros: Flexible, task-oriented, advancement available, good pay, good co-workers, not strict on dress code/piercing/tattoo policy.
cons: Very busy and sometimes tasks you just spent months on get canceled. Intel changes with the market and priorities can change very quickly. So always expect be doing something new or filling a gap.

review_title: They do not care about employees, experience nor years of service.
pros: There was flexibility in work schedule and location.  Work was never very hard as there was so much B.S overhead that what should take a week would take 6 months.
cons: Too much worthless and irrelevant forced training, what appeared was necessary to make their lawyers happy.  Always more and more expected with little to no compensation.  Constantly let go senior employees and excepted remaining workers to just take up the slack.

pros: Safe environment, challenging opportunities, encouraged to have a balance of work hard and play hard.  Great compensation. Flexible time schedules for family when needed.
cons: Separation from the greater Intel has resulted in isolation from newer technologies and shared knowledge.  Stagnated management personel.  Most have been in their positions for greater than 10 yrs and have little concern for moving or taking chances for themselves or risk taking.

review_title: Transitioning from HR to the Business side
pros:
Great benefits! Medical, dental and vision...very helpful when raising children. 
Diverse and talent workforce...many opportunities to learn 
Challenging work...great pace if you are a Type A driver
cons: Politics and red-tape slow things down; Too many rounds of layoffs and reorgs; over dependent on consultants

pros: You get to work on the most advanced technology in the world. Compared to most companies there are a lot of nice benefits and perks.
cons: Layoffs every couple of years. Only have to worry if you get a bad annual review or low stock rewards for that year though.

review_title: Transitioning from HR to the Business side
pros:
Great benefits! Medical, dental and vision...very helpful when raising children. 
Diverse and talent workforce...many opportunities to learn 
Challenging work...great pace if you are a Type A driver
cons: Politics and red-tape slow things down; Too many rounds of layoffs and reorgs; over dependent on consultants

pros: You get to work on the most advanced technology in the world. Compared to most companies there are a lot of nice benefits and perks.
cons: Layoffs every couple of years. Only have to worry if you get a bad annual review or low stock rewards for that year though.

job_title: Silicon Architecture Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Cutting edge process technology in the ASIC world
Stable and profitable company and pays a nice dividend.
cons:
Large corporation, easy to become a "number"
Jobs can become highly specialized which can hurt skill in adjacent work areas
If you are not self motivated it can be rough, its up to you to push your career to the path you want.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Surrounded by smart and innovative people all working together to achieve the overall goals of the company; site people programs; great health benefits; opportunities to rotate within a specific function or outside the business group and even internationally....makes staying long term not boring
cons: Decision making tend to be on the slower side; bad people managers rising through the ranks

pros: Good work life balance, Internal opportunities with multiple groups, Decent pay/benefits
cons: Periodic layoffs (every couple of years), Bureaucratic and slow moving, Too many management layers i.e. low visibility to your work

pros: Dependable work. Good benefits. I enjoyed getting to travel. Getting sabbatical is a great perk of the job in my opinion and kept me there longer.
cons: Harder to move between groups than they advertise. Some people are bright but a lot of people are just coasting along. Salaries are low compared to market.

pros: Intel provides great benefits, good pay, and has a nice compensation package (bonuses, stock purchase program, employee recognition, etc.).
cons: working in the fab tends to make a good tech lose their skills, Intel (at least in AZ) prefers pm techs to actual techs. Also, the supervisors (GLs) they have are hit and miss like everywhere but it did seem like they had more on the miss side.

pros: Good Work life balance. Have some good managers who try to solve problem and deliver product instead of politic
cons: Too much politics. Management chain is still fighting themselves and trying to kill each other instead of cooperate. Sometime managers make issue personel and then try to get rid of person who they don't like.

review_title: One of the best companies to work for.
pros:
- You can express your ideas freely and are encouraged to achieve your ambitions. 
- The employees are very friendly and encouraging. 
- The pay for intern is most likely the highest I have seen in Penang, Malaysia.
cons: - At times your supervisor and team members may not think of an assignment if you finished your work too quickly.

pros: Intel is a good company to work for. Good balance between work and life. Cant complain on how they have treated me.
cons: The company seems to be more focused on checking boxes for employment requirements instead of trying to obtain best in class employees to drive the company to the future

pros: Average pay , very good benefits in terms of healthcare,subsidy and etc. good work life balance . Many department that can switch to
cons: Too streamline on single process unable to learn wide scope of knowledge. Share unit provided to employee is very very limited

pros: Intel has good pay and benefits and provides good flexibility to allow employees to attend to personal matters during the workday  Challenging assignments and very smart people
cons: Corporate culture has changed from the old days of Andy Grove and Gordon Moore.  The strategic focus and execution machine is not what it used to be.

job_title: Graphics Software Engineer in Indianapolis, IN
pros: There are so many opportunities to learn new things and work on cutting edge technology.
cons: All spending has been cut. It seems like there's a new round of layoffs every year now. It also seems like the managers at the top can't relate to the experience of the individual contributors at the bottom.

pros: You work with the best and the brightest. They help you to become the best you can be. Depending on where you work you might even have fun.
cons: Politics and egos are in the way of excellence. Your career rises and falls on who your manager is. That person is to be your advocate. Many times they don't really support you. Especially when you outshine them.

pros: Great place to work, lovely people. Very fair system. You got rewarded for the work you did. Great benefits package.
cons: It was difficult to maintain a normal social life outside work due to the shift pattern. Working over Christmas was the worst part but you were well compensated for it

pros: Location relative to all other Silicon valley businesses.  Worldwide campuses. Still lead in desktop/server-class processors.  Willing to move around to other divisions if interests/skills permit.
cons: Working hours, but that is par for any silicon valley tech company. Employee training.  Employee retention.  Huge turnover to other divisions when management doesn't listen to employee concerns.

review_title: Great benefits but comes at a price
pros: Great benefits and salary. Freedom to work from home on occasion
cons: Management is totally focused on cost and is doing everything they can to get rid of older more expensive employees. Also it is expected that you work literally around the clock to support your global customers. Work/Life balance at Intel is a joke !!

job_title: Deep Learning R&D Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: The company makes an effort to hire the population that has the relevant degrees & qualifications. The workforce is certainly more racially diverse than in the surrounding area, which I consider a plus. The benefits are good. Health insurance options in the Hillsboro, OR location include Kaiser and a local PCP, Connected Care Providence. There are both high and low deductible options.
cons: For a tech company, it is more conservative/traditional. Fewer young people work here.

review_title: Working at Intel, fun and stress
job_title: ODP ICE Technician in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Pay is high, you learn a lot about how Substrates and Processors are made.
cons: Work Hours and day. You work a Compressed Work Week which is 12 hours. One week you work 3 days and then the next you work 4 days. It can be very hard to do anything else but go to work and sleep on workdays.

review_title: Intel has ethics on the outside, but not when it comes to actual engineering work.
pros: It was nearly impossible to get fired, so very good job security.  The benefits are pretty good, and include everything you would expect such as health, dental, vision, including a link to the Mayo clinic for more information. Intel really tried to get employees to be healthy with initiatives to get you to exercise, drink more water, etc.  Every campus has an exercise facility, which is nice.  There are some managers who are pretty good and actually care about their employees.  Intel hires a lot of smart people, so you can feel intellectually stimulated most times.  They also reimburse education costs, as long as the degree is towards a job within the company.
cons: They don't actually use the data to make decisions. They make decisions and then manipulate the data to match the decision. There is a lot of unethical data manipulation and way too much politics to make engineering decisions.  Managers are not trained very well, and to increase the "technical" aspects of employees, people who are poor managers but did well as engineers are promoted.  People with PHD's are hired for positions that are also done by college graduates, leading to a question as to why this makes any sense.  The reasons for doing things such as these seem more political and to get certain statistics up rather than actually doing the right thing for the factories or its employees.  Intel likes to hire people straight out of college so they don't know that the workplace could be better elsewhere and Intel can work them to the bone.

pros: Exposure to a wonderful, talented workforce, and diverse cultural environment.  "Boot camp" for corporate America.  If you can make it at Intel, you can make it anywhere.  Compensation is good.
cons: Brutal politics.  Not enough oversight of and too much discretion given to mid level managers who are, in many cases, unqualified to be in their jobs.

review_title: Good, but not great, place to work
pros: Working in a world class organisation
cons: Can be way too political - you NEED to have a good manager

review_title: Great Place to Work if they fix salaries and mid level mgmt
pros: Great place for lead edge, employees are great.
cons: long days, EVERYTHING is critical (needs action)

review_title: Great place to work but long line for advancement
pros:
Great work life balance at Intel Inc. 
Very smart coworkers at Intel
Job security is top knotch for this economy
Great benefits and cafeterias
cons: There is a glut of employees with 2-4 years experience who will all be ahead of you for a promotion.

review_title: Intel - a good place to work
pros:
leading edge technology
smart people doing brilliant work
lots of opportunity to try new things
supportive management
strong brand name
cons:
Intel is a large company and it is easy to get lost in the shuffle
Bureaucracy makes it difficult for decisions to be made quickly

pros: Good place to learn tools and methodology as a first job. I was able to learn many different aspects of the ASIC flow, as a fresh grad.
cons: Work life balance is not that great. Employees spend a lot of time in the office, but this does not make them more productive.

job_title: Human Resources Business Specialist in Portland, OR
pros: Good benefits package, smart people to work with, nice environment and a lot of communication about whats happening in the business and group
cons: Can be a pretty tough environment when it comes to delivering jobs on time. Employees themselves are very demanding and can be unreasonable.

review_title: It was the best company I have ever worked for in my career.
pros: Intel really rewards for performance and is fair and honest as to where the company is heading. They treat employees with respect for their knowledge and are fair when evaluating them. They empower their employees to challenge themselves and try new ways of doing things.
cons: Wish they wouldn't go out of the U.S..

review_title: it is a good long term job
pros: good for longivity and it is secure, very detail oriented, flexible hours. good options to explore and gain experience in different domains.
cons: micro management, lack of trust on engineers, too many meetings, too many levels of hierarchy. redundant steps in implementation process and lengthy project cycles.

pros: Intel is a well known company, so working there says a lot about you. Compensation is also very very good.
cons: Management can be quite secretive at times. I felt that my manager was more intimidating than helpful. An intimidating manager makes working there stressful.

pros: Its one of the most high tech companies out there and its a great feeling to work on cutting edge technologies
cons: I feel that the people over here are still stuck in an indian mentality and there is less fair growth but then i would think thats true for all companies in india

review_title: Intel gives many perks to make it very difficult for you leave
pros: A lot of team work and great people, which is always fun and nothing is100% your responsibilty so its very easy to take time off and extended vacations.  You always have something to look forward to while your at work and after your vacation your always happy to come back to such a great place.
cons: So many perks they make it very difficult to leave

review_title: Why Intel is a great place to work
pros:
Amazingingly smart people
Challenging and exciting work
Continuous personal and professional development opportunities
Excellent benefits
Competitive pay and bonuses
People are core to the business
Diversity of people/approaches is very valued
cons: More of a positive in my perspective -- its a competitive and challenging environment.  If you want to come to work and go through the motions, this isn't the place for you

review_title: Plenty of oppurtunity for different career paths at Intel
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Company is results oriented.  Stuff gets done.  If you dont like your job it is fairly easy to get a new one internally if you want.
cons: Some departments are worse for work life balance than others.  Everyone needs to decide their own threshold.

review_title: Run...it's a trap!!! It sounds like a dream job but it's NOT!!!!
pros: Salary is ok. Work locations were great. So-so salad bars in the cafeterias. Good on campus perks:    health clinic, spa... Good social atmosphere.
cons: Big. Dumb. Slow. Stupid. Old. It turned out to be just like all the other big megalopolis engineering companies. Disappointed to see the total lack of innovative thinking. Horrible, horrible, horrible, horrible, horrible management. Surprisingly more of a traditional corporate culture than a innovative "techie" culture. Heed my warning and stay way. If you can go work somewhere else then please by all means do so.

pros: Intel has amazing pockets of innovation and risk-taking in which people motivated by creativity and exceptional design can flourish.
cons: These pockets are few and far between, and people in them spend much of their time trying to justify their existence and deal with endless bureaucratic make-work.  The "one size fits all" and "copy exact" DNA of the manufacturing side of the business does not know what to do with entrepreneurial creatives in its midst.

review_title: Smart people, lots of process reviews to make simple decisions, very conservative company.
job_title: Business Development Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great people to work with. I've been with the company for over 10 years. And if it wasn't for the people I would have bailed a long time ago.
cons: Endless meetings and all communication is in PowerPoint. They talk a lot about moving faster but the culture prohibits it..

pros: Strong culture and ethics.  Participating in the fast moving high tech markets.  Job rotation opportunities in various areas of the company.  Promotes employee development.
cons: Sometimes moves slowly, can be bureaucratic.  Company growth has stalled last couple of years.  Transition of new CEO and sr. management driving a lot of change and uncertainty.

review_title: A Great company to work for
job_title: Human Resources Professional in Ho Chi Minh City
pros: Great company culture (open & direct), provides good learning environment and career development opportunities. If you have hunger to learn and grow deeply in your expertise, this is the company for you.
cons: the company can be bureaucratic and slow in its decision making. It has to be more effective at collaboration across business units.

review_title: Great place to start a career
job_title: Data Analyst in New York, NY
pros: The best part was probably the employees. The people I worked with were all very capable and willing to help. The company seemed to care about the growth of its workers.
cons: Most of the cons that come with such a large company. Sometimes it was hard to contact or approach upper-level employees.

review_title: only the paranoid survive but if you work hard it pays off
pros: paid tuition, lots of days off, compressed work week, with bonuses night shift pay 22.5% and overtime you make 50% more than base pay. Night shift best no engineers and managers,
cons: always told you are not doing enough. critical when taking time off.  jungle world to be better than everyone else.

job_title: RET Design Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
* Cutting edge work
* Opportunity to propose new ideas, prototype it, and make a pitch for it to management
* Thinking is encouraged
* Reasonably bright peers, with generally good attitudes -- not difficult to work with
* Very good work life balance (but this may depend on the team and its commitments)
cons:
* Very detail oriented -- necessary for manufacturing, but is a lot of book-keeping
* Some teams have difficult work life balance owing to critical deadlines

pros: Working with very talented and bright people, Keep diversity in work force, Lot of opportunity to learn new stuff, organized work environment.
cons: As it is a very big organization, very oftem employees do not know what is heppening outside their own businees group.

review_title: I had an absolutely fantastic time while I was employed at Intel.
pros: In my opinion, training, compensation, opportunities, and the people were all pros for working at Intel.
cons: There were no downsides to working at Intel in my opinion.

pros: Free fruit and drinks for employees. The company is very safety orientated, with a very safe environment. The company also overs goo pay and benefits.
cons: Management does not have a clue how to manage people. Most managers were promoted for doing a great technical job, but are not people persons.

review_title: A Great Company With Good Salary and Work-Life Balance
job_title: Senior Software Development Engineer in Bangalore
pros: Intel in general a great company and great place to work. You are surrounded by smartest people and your ideas are encouraged. They do really take care of you.
cons: In India, 70% of jobs are into testing and most of the projects are driven from US. So you have to fight hard to get good quality work in India.

pros:
Great Place To Work is one of the company's 6 values:
• Quality
• Risk Taking
• Great Place to Work
• Discipline
• Customer Orientation
• Results Orientation

It is easy to be open and direct at Intel. The best of my employers so far.
cons: May be rigid to changes in some departments.

pros: Traditionally this has been a stable company. The company has projects working a variety of technical areas so you can change jobs without having to leave the company
cons: The company is going through a period of shifting priorities and focus always looking to get into a business that someone else as pioneered.

review_title: Intel profile from an honest pair of eyes of an employee who likes the company and wishes it do better
pros: Benefits and stability, good technology manufacturing, recognizes it should do better to gain on markets (first step of problem solving)
cons: Market compensation goal is 50-60%

job_title: Senior Software CAD Engender in Haifa
pros: Intel is great semiconductors company that leads semiconductors industry from technology point of view. It's great school for every one who want to work in the industry.
cons: If you are looking for software job at Intel it's not the place for you,  also there's a lot of software engineer positions at intel it's not software oriented company.

pros: If interested in low-level enabling and plumbing (E.g. hardware drivers, or developing Linux/Android/Chrome OS/browser middleware) there are lots of opportunities. Engineers generally given a lot of autonomy.
cons: Poor inter-organisational communication with hoarding of knowledge. Career development biased towards US. Homogeneous middle management, ironically out of touch with technology. The US work ethic of overworking is infectious if not careful.

pros:
You can use cutting edge technology
Lot of projects using cloud technology, AWS, etc.
Several projects that start from scratch. You can design, architect, decide technology, etc.
Some of the best compensation and benefits in town.
cons:
Sometime a lot of politics (as in many other orgs)
It is a hardware company, software is not at the same level.
Some projects far away from real customers.
A lot of projects are cancelled, but almost always you will find some other to join.

review_title: Enjoyed my time working at Intel.
pros: A great place to work. Tons of benefits (some benefits apply to family too). A lot of challenges, learn something new every day. Security level is paranoiac.
cons:
Lack of clear communication with employees. Everything is a secret. Security level is paranoiac.
Management needs to improve. Work life balance is a bit gray. Recognition of your work should be increased.

pros: Intel is one of the best companies at the city and good place for developer. Normal salary, compensation packet (medical insurance etc). Good office, there is own cafeteria with acceptable menu and price.
cons: Many legacy projects with accumulated problems inside and you should be support all this stuff. Many rules, codes and bureaucracy.

review_title: Dial up the young and innovative culture please!
job_title: Senior Software Product Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Happy company, people generally feel good about the industry Intel is in and the company's culture is relaxed and easygoing.
cons: Pockets of the company do innovative and new things. The rest are just there for the ride while merely doing their jobs. And politics here and there kills the fun.

pros: Broad scope of possibilities from cpu firmwares to web development. Top class peers and industry leading technology. Ethical & eco friendly environment. Very good work life balance.
cons: Very less number of young employees in the company since the company has been around for a long time. Many of the work environment is still old styled with individual cubes.

pros:
The pay is very good
Get to work with lots of smart people
Interesting problems
cons:
Culture is extremely rigid, it's hard to get new ideas implemented.
Most people are overworked, but his varies group to group.
Upper management seems to have no idea what they're doing, tend to ignore most research on effective management.

job_title: Senior Manufacturing Technician in Hudson, MA
pros: Open minded and employee motivated type of corp.  Always willing to help make the best of your potentials to promote company success and growth.
cons: Management styles and culture promotion can sometimes be overwhelming for new comers.  Patience and listening not always interpreted the  way the employee needs.

pros: The company has a lot of perks for its employees: generous time off, free snacks at coffee at work, good compensation.
cons: The yearly review process is brutal.  It doesn't matter how well the team does, someone has to be ranked as 'improvement needed', and then that person is at risk for layoff.  Also, there is almost no room for promotion, so your sense of success has to come from other areas.

pros: The company has a lot of perks for its employees: generous time off, free snacks at coffee at work, good compensation.
cons: The yearly review process is brutal.  It doesn't matter how well the team does, someone has to be ranked as 'improvement needed', and then that person is at risk for layoff.  Also, there is almost no room for promotion, so your sense of success has to come from other areas.

pros: tremendous reach and diversity. great opportunities within for new roles and to work across organizational boundaries. great teaming available. great opportunities for women.
cons: quite often, managers forget that the invention or device or idea can come from others and still be successful. there remains vestiges of the "not invented here" syndrome.

review_title: Good Pay/Benefits, terrible loyalty to their employees
pros: Good pay and benefits, fast paced and amazing technology.
cons: Very high stress, poor work life balance, not given resources to do your job properly, not loyal at all to long time employees, if you don't have a phd you are looked down on.

pros: Working with talented and passionate people. Dynamic environment that requires flexibility and innovative thinking.  Excellent benefits
cons: Company is in transition, leadership unclear and numerous changes in corporate strategy confusing.  Little loyalty to employees as witnessed by 12k employee reduction as a result of poor executive decisions.

pros: I Enjoyed working there because there was Great atmosphere and Great people. My job was interesting, work hours are flexible, very worker oriented, in house gym for wellfare.
cons: Work from home is around the clock. I was located in Kiryat Gat which was a long drive from home, which is a minus

pros: This is a fast paced and extremly innovative company.  Having spent 18 years there, I saw a lot of transition at the leadership level.  Through it all, the company maintained high ethical standards, great salary and benefits.  They care deeply about the employees and it shows through their GPTW activities.
cons: The culture is not for everyone.  It is fast paced and demanding.  If you fit that culture, then you can excel.

job_title: Software Engineer in Belgrade, Central Serbia
pros: Opportunity to work on cutting edge products and newest technologies and chance to meet and work with some exceptional people.
cons: Small teams outside SC are not fully integrated into the corporation, they don't get all of the benefits of working at Intel.

review_title: Global Marketing Position Politics Killed Me
job_title: Campaign Strategist in Santa Clara, CA
pros: High value, productive, professional organization with great benefits.
cons: Still many staunchy, hard to work with, cut throat folks working there who know nothing about work/life balance.  If you don't marry the company, they'll divorce you and your role.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: great overall benefit package including sabbatical and 401k contribution
cons: Sales org confusing and not aligned with customers.  Risk culture has shifted to one of it's okay to take a risk as long as you get it right.  Manufacturing exec leading the company without clear vision and may under mind the ultimate long-term success of the company.

review_title: Large company, tough times, must change jobs often
pros: Lots of resources because it's size. Lots of employees, lots of different divisions to choose from. Great pay for the Portland area. Largely adheres to it's ethical responsibilities. Never felt like I was compromising my integrity nor would I be asked.
cons: Got to keep moving. Competition is stiff.

job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Growing up with Intel during the rein of Bob, Andy and Gordan was the High lite of life.
These Engineers changed the world and made all of their staff family.
cons:
The corporation evolved. CEO's were eventually non engineering / technical leaders.
This totally changed the direction of the company.

pros:
* Learn great stuff
* Very ethical and amazing value system
* Doing a great transition  to become very nimble and market responsive
* Great Benefits.
* You will love it if you are a techie
cons:
*Size
* Sometimes the process can drag you down but once you learn your way . You will actually find it very helpful
* Tad conservative

pros: Great technology, great technical challenges; if you're in the right group, money is no object.   Very very smart and capable co-workers.
cons: constructive confrontation means you have throw someone under the bus to shine;  had colleagues attempt to wrestle a project away from me because they saw interest from Sr VPs.    if you're not the golden child in your boss' eyes, you will wither in the same position forever.

pros: They pay very well, the bonuses are fantastic, and benefits are the best.
cons: You don't know if you will have a job in 6 months as the corporate direction changes and you find your project out of favor and de-funded. This can happen multiple times in a year.

review_title: Dynamic environment with enormous amounts of exciting challenges. Worked in CDG and throughly enjoyed the people.
job_title: IC Layout Engineer in Gilbert, AZ
pros: You can bet your talents will be challenged to help you grow professionally.  I worked with a great group that helped form my talents along the way.
cons: Many stressful hours along the way but when you couple that with friends you make along the way and the help they hinder professionally, it’s becomes a team.

pros:
Benefits - Medical, Vision.
Friendly coworkers.
cons:
Managers - Some managers do not support your growth, both professionally and personally. They will not approve of your tuition reimbursement if they believe that a Master's degree is not necessary for the job role, even when the discipline is highly related. I've heard that they will do this to keep you from progressing into other departments, etc.

A lot of condescending and belittling behaviors.

review_title: Come to learn, leave before you die of overwork and stress.
pros: Intel has a very challenging work environment with great opportunities to learn.  Effective problem solving is highly valued.
cons: work load is incredible - 7x24 support required in the fabs with huge pressure to perform.  WLE is a joke.

review_title: Intel is a great company to work!
pros:
In Intel, everyone is equal. You can argue with your manager, and your manager won't be angry with you. 

Intel treats new graduate very well.
cons: The salary is not very high. The company is too big, so sometimes it is not very efficient. This is the major problem of Intel.

review_title: Good place to work - but not much growth
pros:
Fairly treated, due processes for everything
Lots of smart people around
Fairly stable environment
Not much of lay-offs
cons:
Not much growth
Salary will grow very very slowly over the years
Business not expanding - completely missed out the Web/Internet business opportunities inspite of so many software folks on board
We cant keep doing the same thing forever - making chips faster/smaller/cheaper - need to come up with

pros:
The salary is good.
The company locates at rural area.
Experienced, professional and knowledgeable colleagues. They are willing to discuss and solve the problem together.
cons:
The manager has high expectation and the deadline is very tight.
It makes the working environment a little bit stressful.

pros:
The salary is good.
The company locates at rural area.
Experienced, professional and knowledgeable colleagues. They are willing to discuss and solve the problem together.
cons:
The manager has high expectation and the deadline is very tight.
It makes the working environment a little bit stressful.

review_title: Great place to work if you like challenges and extreme schedules.
pros: great place to work. Can be challenging but you get to work on the latest products and work with some of the smartest people in the industry
cons: Not enough talk about where the industry is going. In house training needs to be pushed throughout each group and teams.

review_title: Intel is a pleasant and rewarding place to work.
pros: There is a very healthy line of communication up and down the ladder. Also, it is a very professional workplace with competent workers.
cons: As a mechanical engineer your duties are somewhat limited to working primarily with the heating ventilating and air conditioning systems.

pros: It's a very professional and process driven workplace.  The culture is focused on excellence and efficiency.  If a project was worthy of completing you would get budget to do it properly and up to Intel standards.
cons: The visual environment is dispiriting and they have no city offices.  Grey cubicles and barely any window seats.  Some engineers are severe introverts but the marketing and sales people are well rounded.

review_title: Future technology, great people, a truly Great Place To Work
pros: Access to technology, lots of great and inspiring people, super non financial bonuses - like free outdoor activities
cons: Size of the company creates a situation where you can't always work on things you enjoy most, sometimes you need to do some mundane tasks for few months

pros: Fun & challenging work environment, particularly on the manufacturing side. The ability to work with state of the art technology. Opportunities for career growth both laterally and upward.  Excellent benefits including an 8 week sabbatical. Environmentally conscientious company.
cons:
At times can be stressful particularly when you provide 24X7 support. Decision making at times is slow. 
Slow at responding to new markets.

review_title: Disciplined, focused, more than somewhat inflexible
pros: The people are smart, hard-working, and "of a culture," that is the strong Intel culture drives people towards being comfortable acting within certain constraints.
cons: The company leadership is rather inflexible; the people are smart but somewhat arrogrant, and not welcoming of new ideas. "There's the Intel way..."

pros:
Intel is an excellent company to work for. The work culture is great and there is an air of innovation in everyday work. I especially like the freedom and flexibility given to employees to complete their jobs in the best possible productive manner. 

The company also encourages employees to take active part in community involvements and provides employees a platform to unleash their passion for community work.
cons: Pay could be even better.

pros: Good package and fair amount of vacation and personal time.  Package included pension plan, profit sharing and 401K with good investment opportunities.
cons: The total package has changed, like so many corporations Intel is seeking ways to reduce headcount in many areas and pay less into "package plan".  They appear to increase pay only with promotions and by quarterly bonus.  Training in many areas is poor or nonexistent.

review_title: Great products but not as influential in the industry
pros: Intel has some of the most dedicated people in the industry working there. They try extremely hard and generally have many of the best practices
cons: Over the years Intel has fallen victim to the "Innovators dilemma". They have been slow to respond and their relevance is constantly being questioned. The new MGMT team has been very focused on cost cutting and this makes for a challenging environment to be in.

pros: It is a good place for fresh grads to grow and build up skill sets. Company and most departments provide good training plan. Lots of talented people to learned from. Many internal development opportunities and lateral transfer to new functional areas. Get to work with people from diverse culture and different countries. Nice co-worker. Flexible working hours. Good benefits.
cons: It has been a while since Intel introduce a innovative products that excites the market.

pros:
Work on cutting edge technology well before others in the industry even realize it.

Ability to do whatever you want, and you can switch your job from one group to the other to promote constant learning
cons: Not the best salary, Not the best employee benefits, decision making is dragged by management. A lot of politics and fighting between teams doing similar work.

review_title: Cutting edge silicon company, less so on a software front.
pros: It is a real fun to work when surrounded by super professional people. Always can find someone to be inspired by. You'll find here people who invented major pieces of today's technology. Intel can really be proud of a strong culture of collaboration between employees.
cons: Intel is clearly a silicon company. The management understands how to execute on silicon and has little clue on how to approach software products.

review_title: Pros and Cons, but overall good place to work.
pros: There are lots of training opportunities so it is a great place for personal growth, there are opportunities available. Compensation and perks are excellent, education is also a perk in my book. In general there is a good work atmosphere.
cons: Working hours a long and it can be very difficult to find a work life balance. There are lots of politics, and it is a highly competitive work environment.

review_title: Great company as first role out of college
pros: Compensation, benefits, open door culture, work/life balance, lots of opportunity to advance if you try hard, sabbatical every 4 or 7 years
cons: Location of offices, structure/timing of promotions, lots of politics involved, hard to move to new orgs or business units within the company, management likes to trap you if you're good

job_title: QA Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: This is a very competitive firm, likes to win. Comp is ok. People are very talented. you will work with the best in your field. Workplace facilities are improving and plenty of opptys to work in different parts of the company.
cons: Not really a lot of cons. It’s a big company, and just depending on where you are, sometimes decisions can be slow. Normal for any big company. Intel is relatively agile.

review_title: Quality Assurance Technician personal computers manufacturing
job_title: Quality Assurance Specialist in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Consistant workload, good training, salary and benefits, clean working conditions, good fellow employees, nice cafeteria, interesting and up to date technology to be involved with. Education offerings.
cons: Mandatory overtime, indifferent management, flat personality. Too much standing on the work space. No windows/ natural light. Too much security.

pros: Great benefits, plenty of very smart people, refined process, leaders in semiconductor manufacturing, fascinating work environment, great opportunities for problem-solving
cons: Most of my qualms pertain to management / people, it is a big company and seemingly impossible to get fired for poor work performance (they just shuffle people to new groups, so then that a new group has to deal with the issue), horizontal heirarcy

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: A highly efficient working environment which leads cutting edge technology innovation in fast pace. Provided lots of opportunities to grow the technical skill sets and ranking and rating rule is pretty much fair and judged by facts. Learn a lot from Intel and it is great company to work with.
cons: Cultural wides, it is too rigidness. If it can derive few softness activities, it will be more fun and more enjoy to work with.

pros: Free soda and decent cafeteria food. I really enjoyed the freedom I had with my time. I was given a project and a deadline and then set on my way.
cons: Cubicles as far as the eye can see. I hated the higher level of noise associated with cubicles. I really felt a lot like a small cog in a REALLY big wheel. Wish I could see more of my work results on a larger scale.

pros: Free soda and decent cafeteria food. I really enjoyed the freedom I had with my time. I was given a project and a deadline and then set on my way.
cons: Cubicles as far as the eye can see. I hated the higher level of noise associated with cubicles. I really felt a lot like a small cog in a REALLY big wheel. Wish I could see more of my work results on a larger scale.

pros: Great career path development available, it is a long term company with multiple chances to move across different organizations. Very good benefits for employees
cons: In last years the salary increments have been kind of minimal (but it compensates with different quartely bonus)

pros: Many opportunities to work on interesting projects and collaborate with other groups and make contacts. Most people are competent and  good to work with.
cons: On some occasions there were changes in department organizations that did not make any sense and general rules that are one size fits all.

pros: Culture enables innovation. Team collaborate well across functions and groups. Decision making is pushed to the lowest level possible. High level of loyalty among employees
cons: Compensation does not feel competitive. Top management structure needs new blood, this is happening but slower than ideal. Many shuffles and re-orgs

pros:
-Good current corporate culture
-collaborative environment
-helpful teammates
-one of few place in tech you can college grad -> retirement
cons:
-push for growth by stockholders changing company culture
-stack ranking means constant growth or your out
-management that do the "right" things for the business are pushed out for those that chase promotions but make decisions that hurt the business

pros: Good work life balance.  Lots of work is there, some good work and some not so good. So depending upon persons interested he can take what amount of Work/ or do work he likes. Great Place to Work.
cons: Compensation is not so good compare to other Big Companies.  And some time management is very stubborn to your idea or career plans

pros: Great pay and even better benefits.  Lots of opportunity for development and advancement, including tuition reimbursement.  Lots of schedule options/flexibility.
cons: Revolving door of low level managers.  Restructuring layoffs are an annual thing so one mistake during the year could be deadly.  Giant company with a strong corporate governance.

pros: The managers are comfortable with employees who work at home or remote locations; also the company has great resources and lots of respect in the tech industry.
cons: Middle managers don't seem to be getting senior management's message to move faster; decision making is hampered by separation of roles and responsibilities.

review_title: Good company, but fighting a PC war
pros: Decent salary and benefits. Sabbatical is great!  Flexible work environment, good values, and you can request a 1:1 meeting with pretty much anybody in the company.
cons: Intel seems like a rudderless ship at the moment.  They are also fighting an unwinnable war with Political Correctness.

pros: Good for stability. There is little work pressure and it is good for work life balance. Company campus is also pretty good and good facilities
cons: There isn't enough good work to do. The opportunities are less and work is mostly done by US teams. Indian center is mostly a maintenance center.

review_title: Big enough to contain both good and bad
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
A lot of learning and growth opportunities if you are motivated.
A lot of good people, role models and managers you can look up.
Excellent vacation benefit.
cons:
There are some deceptively nice managers who care only his/her job security other than your career development, and you realize you work for such a manager only when you get screwed.
There are many groups that are poorly managed and add no value to the company.

review_title: Responsible for winning approval to construct all facilities in Arizona
job_title: Site Development Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: Intel is a meritocracy which means you are measured on your performance and not your popularity. You are expected to accomplish your goals and objectives and to be successfulAnd you do so in an effort away
cons: Some Senior managers were starting to play politics instead of focusing on the goals and objectives in the person’s performance

pros: Intel is a great company to work for. This is probably a few company left for semiconductor professionals that was founded and long run by engineers. This is excellent policies for its employees and they continuously work to further improve it
cons: Not the nest salary in the valley (but not bad either). Internal politics, especially geo-political politics hurt this company deep.

pros: Work life balance, benefits, easy going life, not a whole lot of pressure, trip to the US once a year
cons: incompetent and corrupt management, average pay, work location remote, bad review system, no opportunites to relocate , limited opportunities to move to other orgs in the company

pros: Close to home and workers are friendly.  Long-term benefits and skilled employees. There could be a few more incentrives that could be utilized to ensure retention of staff.
cons: Private sector and therefore high turnover can occur when economy is not good.  Engineers can have less autonomy as per other companies

review_title: Great company and benefits, but not satisfied with job position
pros:
great place to work and the benefits are great. 
very flexible. great work/life balance. 
financially supportive of higher education (MBA)
cons:
limited opportunities to progress
work can often seem very tactical and not very strategic. 
great first job out of college, but not satisfying after about a year.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel has very strong financial analysts and values bright, driven people. If you work hard, you will be rewarded here.
cons: People have a tendency to be aggressive, frustrating and immature. Intel values people who challenge opinions which can be helpful. It also means you are very likely to work with total, utter jerks.

job_title: Market Research Intern in Folsom, CA
pros: Intel greatly values their interns, and really promote networking by having the HR department specifically plan events for interns.
cons: The working environment (ie. your desk) in Folsom campus is still quite outdated and non-social, yet exclusive.

pros: Intel is a great place to work.  The company gives employees huge opportunities to grow and develop within the company.  It rewards results orientation and risk taking.
cons: Work life balance can be a challenge as there are always more things to do, deadlines to meet, etc.  Even though the company is flexible with time and working from home (to some extent), the workload and meetings other time zones makes it difficult.

review_title: Good place to join when you're at the end of your career
pros: Convenient work hours. supports working from home.
cons:
Lots of politics. Lots of dirty work and not so much development.
Old fashioned methodologies and fear of changes or creative solutions that may complicate things .
Eventually good engineers leave and mediocre engineers stay.

job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Good benefits, good pay, fair horizontal mobility
cons: Too big.  Get stuck in their (bad) ways. Though they have lots of good employees with vision, that vision never seems to make it up to those who make the decisions.  And, they overwork the employees.

pros:
Incredible company 53 on the Fortune Top 500.
-Cafeteria style selection of Health Care Benefits
-On site recreation, very good café.
-Challenging environment, very safety conscious.
-Nice bonuses, good management, great co-workers.
cons:
-Understaffed for required expectations.
-Benefits long term are becoming less that previous years due to changes in health care globally. 
-Labor force challenges due to global environment.

review_title: Requires a lot of hard work, but results are rewarding
job_title: Design Engineering Manager in Fort Collins, CO
pros:
Working on the most advanced VLSI technology in the world
Working on products that dramatically affects the lives of everyone
Generally smart people
Health benefits are good
cons:
Work required per engineering team is increasing dramatically, and the company does not yet know how to accomplish this without affecting work/life balance
Salary appears average
Too many silos in which people spend time trying to protect their charters and futures

review_title: Overall a great experience with lots of opportunity
job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros:
Easy to move laterally and try new things
Great benefits
Generally supportive of work-life balance (at least in theory)
Work with many brilliant minds, can learn a lot, some great role models
cons:
In order to really compete, sometimes its necessary to put in a lot of hours 
Lack of focus (many times the expectation is to work on so many things that you get spread really thin)
A lot of re-orgs (especially lately)

review_title: Constant change keeps you a little off balance
pros: You can define the technological solution space of the next generation compute engines
cons: Use of performance anxiety driven overwork labeled as "healthy tension" can make the place "difficult".  See also "high tech lawsuit" for further info on HR policies.

pros: Ergonomics, work with some talented, good and customer oriented coworkers, learning oportunities , delicious free coffee, additional health ensurance,good values and culture. Thank you Intel !!!
cons: Several not skilled  managers, not people oriented only with its circle of friends, it is a shame but it is true. More often, honest ,dedicated  employees , are leaving this company because the toxic environment and overloaded duties.

pros:
- lots of growth opportunities at first
- excellent atmosphere
- flexible work time (no time tracking; do what needs to be done & go home)
- access to cutting-edge hardware knowledge
cons:
- buzzword-filled corporate culture (safe to ignore, though)
- lack of direction, lack of ownership, unclear requirements
- significant pay raises never happen
- work gets stale in the long run

pros: Even though it's a big company they can change direction quickly by scrapping a project and refocusing.
cons: Still using a lot of waterfall engineering style which means if you are contributing as an engineer you will probably not be able to make smart decisions about how to achieve project goals. All important project decisions are made by architects and they may impose their bad decisions on you.

review_title: Good Work if you can get it
pros: Short on politics and long on data. Great overall compensation compared to the local market.  Very little micro-manangement and plenty of authority and accountability to make decisions.  Plenty of opportunities to expand your scope into other areas if you are willing to take a risk.
cons: A little too tight on travel and entertainment budget.   Tending to lean a little too much towards the politically correct recently.

review_title: join it only if you are an Indian to the core - mean, badly behaved or a man!
pros: Name and reputation of the company, perks,
cons: A lot of mediocrity in work, jealousies among people are very high, very bad team working environment. Mainly MS level people are in management positions. They are extremely insecure of people with higher degrees

pros: world best talent to work with which mean, you can work with one of the best people on earth. Work on latest and greatest technology with best compensation package.
cons: offshore design house mean lots of decision still decide at main site in US even though effort being made to bring up local talent and expertise.

pros: great company; good environment, lot of training and learning opportunity; it is up to you for your job security, great place to work; open and direct
cons: too political and missing leadership vision: management cares more about his personal interest over value to the company and there is too much political stuff going on everywhere

pros: Intel has excellent compensation; tries to retain the best talent; Able to move around jobs;
cons: Depending on the group, there is no such thing as work life balance; They will work you into the ground; will use unfair and/or unknown metrics as layoff criteria without blinking

job_title: Software Test Engineer in Bayan Lepas
pros: A lot of room for career development - actually be given the freedom to try new things as long as its relevant to the job scope. The company do focus and provide support for career development, great life and work balance, but depending on your manager. However, most of the managers here are reasonable within means.
cons: Can be stressful - high expectation for you to catch up fast especially when you're a newcomer

pros: Interned there at Fab 32 and had a really positive experience. I was given a mentor that helped me get acquainted with the company. Great company to intern with.
cons: As an intern, sometimes I had some down time that I felt I could've been using to get started on the next project.

pros: Good internal training program and productivity tools.  The company has a "Great Place to Work" philosophy which helps create reasonable work life  balance
cons: The annual internal review process is haphazard at best and favors employees who are focused on keeping their manager happy rather than doing the best thing for the company

pros: Hillsboro/Portland is a great area to live, decent salary for the area, challenging work, can have great coworkers and teams depending on what group you are with.
cons: Performance rating system doesn't always reward the best workers and almost never penalizes the worst performers, mismanagement at the highest levels is causing layoffs, thrash and churn on projects.

review_title: Do I stay or do I leave?
pros:
Agree with BK's strategic direction for the company.

Have had the opportunity to work on great projects. Lots of interesting technical challenges. Opportunities to learn from many very smart people.
cons:
Bureaucratic decision making processes can be soul crushing. 

Diversity initiatives undermine meritocracy. 

Although the company provides indispensable technology, it isn't considered to be a tech leader.

pros: Talented people, great manufacturing prowess, big company but good compensation, the sabbatical is nice, new leadership betting big on data center, iot, memory, and 5g
cons:
Large layoffs
Moving tech jobs to India from USA
Lost its way
Morale is at an all time low 
Bad leadership
Selling of divisions
Totally missed the mobility market
Not a software company
Ruled by manager who are not technical

review_title: Aloha Oregon site secretly the best
pros: The site is small by intel oregon standards, but you get to know people like family
cons: Parking can be tough if you show up late.  But compared to how far you have to park from desk or fab at Ronler, it it way better

pros: The working style is more free than other Taiwan company.  Nice work life balance . Communication can be more straight forward by setting up one-on-one meeting .
cons: Need to improve job skill on your own, otherwise skill development is limited here. Co-working between different groups require high communication skill .

pros: Most the people are intelligent and prrofessional, total compensation is competitive for Sacramento market, opportunity to be a significant contributor to company operations
cons: Benefits have been decreasing, Employee Stock Purchase has been reduced, company 401k contribution has been reduced, extremely limited salary increases even with positive ("successful") performance evaluations, poor training and career advancement opportunities

pros: Work is never boring as the problems are constantly changing. Great sabbatical program.
cons: Intel has been focused on protecting its cash cows rather than investing in new markets and products. The company also has a long history of betting on the wrong technologies.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: I came to Intel from much smaller technology companies, including startups. I had some concerns about large bureaucracy or disinterested employees. I was pleasantly surprised to find not-to-bad bureaucracy and committed, smart employees. Management team generally works to keep engineers busy on meaningful projects.
cons: Still some big-company churn: Layers of needless "process" to get certain things done. Periodic required courses on company policy. Etc.

pros:
Great workplace and surrounding infrastructure. 
 Very flexible schedule for partial time works such as undergraduate and graduate students.
cons: Stress full work. A lot of tasks to do at the same time. A lot of tedious hard including  constant "customer service" for other department.

job_title: Spouse of Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Good health insurance.  Okay pay, but not keeping up with skyrocketing cost of housing.
cons: Husband had to work ALL Fourth of July weekend. Literally 7 am to midnight.  And, it's like this almost ALL the time.  They don't even have an on-call schedule anymore because they are so short staffed that everyone has to be on call 24-7 all the time!  Our kids haven't seen him in almost a week!

pros: Good people to work with, fast paced environment, good bonus programs, Sabbaticals, free coffee and fruit
cons: Long hours, working holidays and weekends

review_title: Numerous opportunities available to employee for growth and training.  Great culture!
pros: Good benefits, flexibility, and work/life balance.  Brought modern day conveniences on site including gym, dry cleaners, etc.  Sabbaticals are an extra bonus not seen in most companies.
cons: Sometimes the bureaucracy and multiple layers of management limit progress.  Besides that, i dont have anything else as I enjoyed working for the company and was sad to have to leave

pros: Benefits, pay, sabbatical (if you can last over 5 years), quarterly bonus, etc.
cons:
1) Poor managers with low EQ that are not accountable for their bad decisions.  They let all the blame flow downhill and scapegoat the ones that are working hard and making personal sacrifices.
2) Intel is all talk and some of the "managers" are not examples of what they portray to the media and to new employees.  Some of the employees will continue to perpetuate the hype and lies because they are a part of the ingrained negative politics and backward thinking culture.
3) Their focal process is unfair, based on politics, favoritism and CYA tactics.
4) The open door investigation process and warm line is a joke.  It served to only collect information from the employee, appease them temporarily, just to discredit them and kick them out of Intel, so that they will not have to deal with them anymore.  This was the most sneaky and underhanded tactic that I have ever experienced in my professional career.   It would take an act of God for me to ever trust Intel again.
5) Retention of women in STEM is also laughable.  Support is limited to those that have a dedicated mentor.  Those that do not have one are vulnerable to the politics and  the recent popular backlash against women and minorities within Intel.  
6) New people are thrown into a disorganized group with ill-defined processes, managers with no management skills, direction and EQ. They are then expected to succeed when key team members are laid off in the middle of a project and without the necessary support from some team members and managers.

review_title: Great employees, normal problems assoc with companies that use stack rank review process
pros: Overall, nearly 90% of coworkers are outstanding.  Great resources.  Focus on deliverables and ability to question the routine, even from the top.
cons: Stack rank promotes unhealthy competition, focus on "my accomplishments" at expense of genuine teamwork.  Those that are comfortable with self-evangalization will thrive.  If your not, you either adapt or get weeded out.

review_title: Avoid this place if you can
pros: You will learn some very good engineering skills
cons:
Unreasonable work-life balance
Hostile work environment
Pettiness, vindictiveness, nepotism are all rampant and remain rampant to this day

pros: Great work culture - No micro-management - Lots of opportunities. Workload and how much you learn depends on the team you join.
cons: Some teams are laid back, you may not learn at the same pace as you would in other companies like Samsung, NVIDIA or Apple. That being said it is up to you to work hard and be the goto person. There are lots of smart people and some dumb people as well!!

pros: great environment to work. good enough pay.  choice of wide range of technologies to work on.
cons: work life effectiveness takes a hit sometimes (depending on the job profile). Career growth is very slow in general. Managers are pathetic in terms of their help with employees career growth and are always in "get work done" mode.

review_title: Loved the people, the culture not so much
pros:
- top notch coworkers
- diversity of roles
cons:
- more competitive than collaborative
- yearly employee compensation review is based on how you compare with every other person in your grade, not personal growth or abilities. Also on how aggressively your manager is willing to argue for you. 
- frequent rounds of staff reductions

pros: Total compensation is competitive. Good relationships in rank and file. Leadership products.
cons:
Near total collapse in morale and trust with management changes. Annual layoffs in order to hit arbitrary benchmarks. Employees in the US viewed as costs to be eliminated as much as possible. Absence of leadership and condescending, poor quality communications to staff.

Almost overnight the culture for Finance was poisoned and survivors of the actions left embittered and frustrated.

pros: I love the compressed work week schedule and the benefits offered. Intel does try to strive for the Great Place to Work mentality.
cons: It becomes monotonous after a short time. Also, based on the location of employment, traffic is horrible, adding to the amount of time required to work and to travel to work.

pros: I worked for Intel for more than 9 years.  It was a great place to work, good benefits and many opportunities for growth.   There are many opportunities to stretch and develop your skills at Intel, but do not wait for someone to “present” them to you.  You own your career there, so strongly recommend people proactively seek new projects and growth opportunities.
cons: Can be a stressful environment

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Santa Clara, CA
pros: On-site Gym, Tuition Reimbursement, Scholarship Program for children of blue badge employees
cons: Each department a world within itself.  No cohesion across company and departments.  Laid off in most brutal fashion.

cons:
1) Very poor management - they're managing eng teams as if they were managing unskilled blue collars
2) Instability of projects - you never know when the project you've spent a dozen or so months is going to be canelled

job_title: Staff Hardware Engineer in San Jose, CA

cons: Like most large companies, it is easy to get lost in the shuffle. Certain organizations can be very political as well.

pros: there are many pro's such as time off. excellent pay and benfits plus salary. the company takes good care of its employees. It is a overall good company
cons: its very competitive working at the company but its a large company and I guest that can be expected. There are not much more cons

pros: Great place to work. You get to learn a lot from the best people in the field who are very helpful.
cons: Hard deadlines have to be met and the ramp-up time is very less specially for an intern. Be prepared to slog long and hard.

pros: Nice benefits including free fruit and rm 2 lunch subsidy. Free medical coverage. Flexible working hours. Have the chance to work with a group of smart people.
cons: High living cost and traffic jam at penang. Stressful at times. Lower mobility in job rank and position. Salary increment is limited.

pros: Love the work ours and shift they have to offer
cons: Pay is good but it becomes a issue when someone been working for company for 25 years and making less than someone doing the same job your doing and they have been here for 12 years. Half the time you been? :-(

review_title: I had a great time, Plenty of hard work to go around
pros:
Benefits were great
Time off was great
cons: Not enough Qualified personnel to allow for rotation of time off during holidays

- Performance oriented workplace

review_title: Very nice place to develop career

-bright people
-friendly atmosphere
-good salary
-strong team relations
-professional management
-good benefits (multisport card, private health insurance, lunch vouchers, fruits everyday, team building parties every quarter, gifts for Christmas, Christmas party and Easter party, cakes from diffrent occasions)

cons:
-long working hours (too less employees, if project needs to be done perfectly: you need to do overtime)
-changes take long time

pros: Real technology leader in silicon design and manufacturing. Flat organizational structure. No Executive offices or corporate perks. Excellent employees each an expert in their respoective field that make a great team.

review_title: Intel is a great company to work for.
pros:
- Lot of learning opportunities.
- Company emphasises on values and integrity at workplace.
- Colleagues with exceptional talent

- Especially, those groups of Intel working on SoC based designs, work pressure is more. This affects the work-life balance. Despite boasts of work-life balance, but this is not really the case.

review_title: Excellent opportunities and great total pay package

cons: Insanely driven, you can have WLB but at a cost.  Also, seems like two companies, manufacturing and everything else.  Stay out of manufacturing (half the company) and it's great, otherwise, prepare to be a cog.

pros: when Intel makes a decision it moves very quickly  but means having all politics in line worse than congress

review_title: Poor work-life balance but there are some good points.

cons: Lack of work-life balance, poor communication in some teams resulting in redundant work, some politics and bad managers.  Results in high turnover.

pros: Enjoy benefits , no pressure for contractors

Do not allow them to progress , most peers who work with contractors are new to management , micro manage and do not allow to learn and contribute, CW augment their work and give them grunt work and have them stay that way though CW is willing to learn and contribute

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Beaverton, OR
pros: Health bens are good, bonuses, maternity/bonding leaves are nice.  Sabbaticals are a huge plus! Easy networking environment and fun people.
cons: Always looking over your shoulder so you don't get blindsided.  People are not afraid to walk over the bodies they've thrown under the bus.  Too many chiefs and not enough Indians.  Upper management heavy.  Too much work and not enough people.

pros: They pay well and they have great perks. Moving to completely different positions is encouraged. They have pretty good bonuses as well.
cons: They are a bit like a good ole boy company so if you are a female its hard to rise or get equal pay. Work life balance is non existent and you could be let go at any time if your dept is not making enough money.

pros: Lots of room to advance and learn as well as transfer to other areas within the company.  Work life balance is outstanding.
cons: Review process encourages stepping on one another for advancement.  Engineering to technician communication sometimes is lacking causing confusion and animosity within the team.

pros: Good Benefits, good health insurance, free fruit and soft drinks, bonuses and stock discount program

pros:

You can take leave whenever you want, just make sure you have your work done. 
Good option of taking work from home.
cons: Work Pressure is there. Everyone is very competitive here.

job_title: Senior Systems Administrator in Chandler, AZ

cons: Pace can be tough to swallow at times. Long hours, demanding priorities, fluctuating market conditions all make for a place that can "chew up and spit out" those who want to go into career cruise control.

pros: Great company to work for. Lots of opportunity around different areas to work on and roles. Easy to move between groups.
cons: Being a big company, decision making is slow. Corporation restructuring currently ongoing and uncertainty abounds. Performance review process not very effective.

pros:
Benefits are much better than any other company I have worked for.
Flexible hours, if not abused.
cons:
In the department I work in there is no stability.
High stress, very competitive environment right now.
