job_title: Applications Developer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: There are a lot of benefits. The work schedule for jobs outside the fab are very flexible.  Free drinks and fruit from the cafes.  Lots of opportunity to move around to different jobs.
cons: The environment is very competitive.  You are expected to be better than those around you and improve your skills constantly ... or get laid off.  Makes the concept of teamwork pretty much non-existent.

review_title: Good work environment. Pays a bit less than other tech companies
job_title: Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good work environment with supporting managers and friendly colleagues. Many people have worked at Intel for more than 10 years. Company provides free drinks and fruits.
cons: Pay is relatively less compared to software companies like Google Facebook. There is bonus and stock benefits, but it is much less compared to those companies.

job_title: Business Systems Analyst in Folsom, CA
pros: Intel really prepares their employees for success by ensuring they have the necessary new hire training courses to be successful in their job.
cons: Be prepared to work over 50 hours a week on a regular basis

pros: It is very opened to try all kinds of technology. Hence there will be some job vacancy probably. Jobs can make life easier but you need to work independently and ramp up soon.
cons: Reorganization is usually seen. This may due to the improper evaluation strategy before applying new technology.

pros:
Temporarily a stable job.

Will provide work visa if you need one.

You can get a job if you are completely fresh out of college. In fact this is precisely what Intel prefers. Intel does not like to hire experienced people, and instead prefers to hire inexperienced college grads and pay them the lowest salary the market would allow. This gives Intel the advantage of having young, single, hardworking engineers at very low salaries.

Surprisingly intelligent peers. One of the unfortunate things is that smart engineers graduating from top schools in the country think that Intel is a great company. Intel has a great legacy to talk about. It has a rich legacy and a great history of amazing products and innovation. But that era is long past. Intel is now a middle-aged (it is almost exactly 50 years old now) obese company with a totally crazy CEO. The era of Intel's greatness is over now. Unfortunately, students graduating from universities don't know this. They learn about what amazing things Intel did almost 15 years ago and are awe-struck, and they want to join!

Practically the only major company with a large fab. So if you want a job in the fab, this is one of the companies you could consider. But as such jobs in the fabs are on a slow decline. Remember, automation is key in everything. And Intel's 10nm, 7nm, and 5nm are not really as far ahead of the competition as they claim. In fact the thing Intel senior staff has repeatedly ignored is that time to silicon is as important - if not more - as silicon manufacturing readiness.
cons:
Intel is a slowly dying company. And jobs there are about as stable as the temperature of water in a kettle that is on a low flame. So when you join you will not know at all that the company is dying, but it is slowly dying.

Poor salaries. Actually the "highly paid" Principal Engineers are abysmally paid according to industry standards. Intel HR compares salaries with other companies of "similar nature", but Intel has to grow up and learn that employees do not use that criterion when deciding whether to stay.

Intel does NOT reward additional industry experience or knowledge with appropriate salary difference against fresh graduates. As a result, your salary will NOT be ANY higher than a fresh graduate with zero industry experience, even if you have prior experience in industry.

Stagnant salaries. In fact this is the #1 indicator of a slowly dying company. The smartest of their engineers could get a salary increment of less than $2000 additional, year on year. Their best performing engineers do not get the best salary increments. If you want a good salary increment you better hope that you are some sort of a manager. Intel rewards ONLY, and ONLY managers. In fact, the only individual contributors that might be rewarded are Program Managers.

Practically the only main job growth avenue is to become some sort of a Program Manager or become the supervisor for your team. Yes, Intel does have a technical track for growth. And yes, there are divisions where tech ladder is a serious job growth avenue. But the VAST MAJORITY of Intel jobs can advance to the next level as ONLY a sort of Program Manager (or someone "driving" something tracking its schedule) or at best as the supervisor in your team - a minor promotion. But remember you became a manager ONLY because your boss became a second-level manager. And now there may be additional levels between you and the chain of command. In my view, job growth should be measured in terms of your sphere of influence - how wide is the circle of people you influence. What you'll realize is that while you may technically influence a very large number of people, you will probably never get rewarded for that. And even if your managerial sphere of influence is moderately improved, remember that Intel is an ocean of very smart people, all wanting to grow just like you.

Be ready to be unsatisfied with the salary for years. Your manager will keep showing you a carrot of phenomenal job growth out in the future "if you do this one thing". But that doesn't really matter. They've decided to pay you what they plan to. This carrot is only a fake. When it comes time to actually give the increment you deserve "low budget", "lack of funds" etc., are commonly heard. Intel has the most unscrupulous and the most unfair and dishonest managers of all in the entire industry.

Please be forewarned.

pros: Wages and benefits are good, and they certently know how to run a fab.
cons: Intel recently pushed out a big pool of senior talent, making it difficult to build on BKMs and rise up to meet the next great push in technology.  Also, their current culture seems to be fractured and the overall direction seems to be hit and miss.

pros: As a student it was excellent learning period. Every colleague was cooperative and I was given offered topic to work upon for my thesis.
cons: It was very tough competition to get permanent position in company since there were many potential candidate inside company as well.

job_title: RET Support Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Great benefits, great pay, compensation, and benefits. Team atmosphere generally positive, and management helps you set goals and move up.
cons: Some areas are more physically demanding than others. Quality of work life may depend on where you get put.

pros: Sabbatical every 7 years, 4 weeks vacation after 10 yrs.
cons: Lots of Bad managers and HR turns a blind eye towards them even when almost 75% of people reporting to same manager move to different teams or leave the company in 1.5yrs.  Zero Growth and Politics plays a major role during Focal (Absolutely no merit). They just want RCG's so that they will do what is being asked rather than question them on why it needs to be done.

pros: I was part of a group acquired from a mid-sized company. Intel gave our team great retention bonuses to stay for four years and set us up as a small site close to our former company. This strategy kept our team intact long enough to get our product developed and into production.
cons: If you work at a small Intel site, be prepared to be asked to move to a larger site at some point.

review_title: Good overall but average compared to other tech companies
pros:
- Decent work/life balance
- Working remotely is generally accepted
- Quarterly profit sharing 
- Some of the new technology we are investing in is exciting
cons:
- Large company, difficult to navigate
- Hard to get stuff done because there are usually a lot of different stakeholders involved on every project
- Very political company culture

pros: You work with really smart people in  collaborative environment. It is really team dependent though, if you get put on a good team, you are good to go. Although it is mainly a hardware company, so software is more of a 2nd priority there.
cons: If you are not put on a good team or don't have support. It is very team dependent.

pros:
Good work culture
No swipe-in/out
Salary is ok
Gives stock options
Has nice facilities like gym etc.
cons:
Not much in core ML/AI domain, focus is largely on hardware aspects of it.

Can't afford to innovate as freely, because it runs into competition with its own customers like microsoft, google etc. 

Some managers can be coward and too fixated on using tools rather than focussing on solutions to problems

pros: 1) Amazing benefits and flexible hours 2) Very smart, fun, and motivated people 3) Great work processes, training, and documentation 4) Employee ideas are appreciated and tons of opportunity to change 5) Very innovative
cons: 1) Brutal political culture which is very competitive 2) Kill or be killed the higher up the chain you go

pros: Good services, good bonus, good wages, good environment to work
cons: Long hours working, difficult life-work balance, lack of real planning

pros: Intel takes good care of employees. Even during COVID situation, the employer did not lay off the employees and gave an additional paid leave to relieve stress from the hectic work.
cons: Random work assignment for the college grads. Students with software background may get to work on VLSI topics and students with EC background may get to work on c++.

pros: Great benefits, free fruits everyday, quarterly bonus, annual bonus and mid annual bonus.
cons: Racism and when you tried to highlight it to HR, they did nothing even though theg always mentioned that the company is focuaing on diversity. Manager is like a king and they can decide anything on your focal review.

review_title: This big company gives you freedom to succeed
job_title: Product Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: This big company gives you freedom to succeed. It is also good to be associated with the Intel name and brand, which is highly respected.
cons: Too process oriented. Intel needs to break away from its manufacturing processes to succeed in new markets

review_title: NOT a place to grow your career or income.
pros:
Intel's competitive advantage is its ability to deploy a manufacturing technology quickly and in the largest scale possible. Intel's manufacturing technology is cutting edge, but only in commercial deployment. The cutting edge technology is developed not in big corporations but in academia and start ups.
If you are fresh out of college, start your career at Intel to learn about the industry, tools, and commercial technology (usually at the beginning of its decline). Leave no later than 2 years, start your own company or join a start up (you will make more for the hours you put in).
cons:
A typical manager is competent talking to a power point, with very little understanding of or appreciation for the content. He is a good salesman and a sycophant. He gives little thought to the growth of his direct reports (who usually haven't left the team or the company because they are on Employment Visas or the employment market is bad).
If you are looking to gain technical experience/knowledge you will work atleast twice as long as the industry on a project, spend twice as much time in irrelevant meetings.
If you are looking to grow your career vertically, there is little hiring and most managers have decades to o before retirement, translation: very few management positions in the foreseeable future.
If you are looking to broaden your skills (grow horizontally), the hiring managers will not consider your application without "prior relevant experience", translation: most groups operate as silos.
If you are looking to grow your income, follow the stock price INTC (a good portion of the compensation) the last decade (Jan 3rd 2000 to Jan 4th 2010) the stock has fallen more than 50%. The average annual raise in salary in the US has ranged from 0% to 6% during the same period.

review_title: If you are lucky, maybe you could do something better!
pros: good people, good salary pay, nice team work, good management and collaboration. sometimes you maybe have additional bonus, etc. so on....
cons: very few change to get promotion, if you want to stay there over 15 years, maybe you have a little bit change.

job_title: Senior Attorney in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel's name carries weight both nationally and internationally. It is a good place to have on your resume and might open doors to other potential employers.
cons: No upward mobility opportunities, no risk taking from management regarding allowing someone to move into an upward position; instead they hire from outside even though that person is not as qualified. This tends to send a bad message to existing employees.

job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: Dealing with Top notch technology with reasonable pay package. Good future, commited to spend in research & developement, top notch technology.
cons: Not as annovative as Apple, Google. Always does the catch up game. Review process is not very growth oriented. Process technology leadership is waning.

pros:
Good salary, good training program, good benefit, as well as good engineer training process. 
Potentially, one can grow very well due to their experience at Intel
cons: Tough working schedule sometime. One have to be absolutely ready for the tough schedule and the lots of deadline to meet.

pros: Lots of room for growth, easy to move around between departments, excellent job stability.  Benefits are very good and bonus program is good.
cons: Intel is a large company and can sometimes be too process-oriented.  At times progress can move more slowly due to excessive processes.

review_title: Intel is good place to grow technical strength, but do not expect a fast salary increase or promotion
pros: talent employees to discuss and share technical problems
cons: Intel is large company and there is always re-organizaiton in every other years. if you get impacted, then you may lose your promotion oppotunities.

review_title: Intel gave me a chance to grow at very beginning. But now my growth and promotion is limited.
pros: Intel has the leading edge process and has a lot of stuff for employee to learn. Intel gave new hires a chance to grow.
cons: Intel is too big to be efficient. There are a lot of overlaps between different groups. In addition, some managers only attend meetings and not able do management stuffs or solve employee's problems.

review_title: Intel has provided me various opportunities to learn and to advance my career
pros: You get opportunity to work on cutting edge products and with some of the smartest people in the hardware industry.
cons: Just like any big company, you have to learn to navigate the process and people issues in order to accomplish your goals.

review_title: Overall Intel is a good company to work for.
pros: Stock options, bonuses twice a year, pretty descent 401K/SERP benefits. A lot of job growth if you put in the effort. The company encourages taking college classes to keep up with technology and lastly a great place to work!
cons: To many managers that can't agree on the basic things! Most days you are in 5-6 meetings a day and it's hard to get anything done.

pros: Benefits that go far beyond the average company.
cons: Bureaucracy is the company’s biggest enemy.  It takes 10 times the effort it should to get anything done.  This is mostly due to having multiple layers of management attached to a single decision.  Many of which do not understand the science behind what their employees do.

pros: Influence on world class technology, great products. Big variety of products - from biomedical chips to chips for supercomputers. Diversity of teams - hardware, software design, chips and packaging. High level of research in some teams.
cons: Sometime slow movement. Orientation to high volume production and high level quality is good for products with very high volume, but game should be changed for diversity of products with relatively small profit margins.

review_title: Big Company. Big Bureaucracy. Small Advancement.
job_title: Product Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
- Lots of smart people.
- Cool technologies and products
- Good benefits and overall pay package.
- Generous tuition reimbursement
cons:
- work/life balance are just words
- SO few opportunities for genuine advancement

review_title: Intel salaries not equal. Based on gender.
job_title: Human Resource Manager in Rio Rancho, NM

cons: Men still treated better than women employees.  Women work much harder than men to get to the same levels.  It seems they have to prove their capability much more.

review_title: Large bureaucratic corporation, little room for growth and lack of excitement/challenge
pros:
- Cushy job
- Flexible schedule
cons:
Improvements required:
- Pay people competitively
- Focus on talent rather than headcount
- Reward talent
- Improve perks
- Emphasize and drive towards dynamic, tangible goals rather than static line items
- Make documentation a central part of any project
- Fight to keep good employees. Anything less is demoralizing

review_title: Good company. Trying to bounce back
pros: Good Company with brilliant people from ages. Decent Pay. Under Re-organization. Recently lost a wave of innovation through mobiles. Trying to bounce back to mobile market. Hard path ahead but they have full focus to win the mobile market. They have lot of resources, just need the right direction and focus to win.
cons: Need to hire young technical leaders and grow them.

job_title: Analog Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good Work/Life balance, good pay and bonuses, good perks. Care for health of employees by offering free fruits and Gym facility (though a very small one in Santa Clara compared with other sites).
cons: No room for growth if you don't know how to play politics. No interesting work for analog engineers. No risk taking. Lot of politics and its review system is the worst.

job_title: Senior Process Engineer in San José, Alajuela
pros: Good safe environment. Very good benefits and compensation. Very good opportunities to grow professinally and excellent training and learning opportunities.
cons: Burocratic. Things move slow sometimes and it is frustrating to go over all the procedures to accomplish something and get a project done.

job_title: Operations Manager in North Sacramento, CA
pros: Great History, great learning grounds, great benefits, average pay, fast culture - Lots of meetings, Many very smart people with great experience.
cons: Lots of political challenges, some areas do not allow for work-life balance, Still a bit old fashioned.

pros: Great benefits and salary.  Lots of time off. two month Sabbatical every seven years. INTEL values safety of their employees  number one. Very diversified. Fun place to work. They will go out of their way to create a work  life balance. Great 401k and profit sharing.
cons: High pressure. Lots of projects. Quotas on making improvements.

pros: Great benefits and salary.  Lots of time off. two month Sabbatical every seven years. INTEL values safety of their employees  number one. Very diversified. Fun place to work. They will go out of their way to create a work  life balance. Great 401k and profit sharing.
cons: High pressure. Lots of projects. Quotas on making improvements.

job_title: Senior Engineering Technician in Austin, TX
pros: Seems to be a lot of activities to keep your interest, and the pay is about middle of the road.
cons: They want to take over your life and make sure you drink the corporate koolaid.

pros: The pay and the benefits are both very good. I also enjoy working with a majority of my coworkers who are mostly fun to work with and supportive.
cons: Not much communication from management. Stack ranking system. Highly political work environment. I've seen plenty of incompetent employees get promoted while other good employees get let go.

pros: Benefits are excellent. Safety is the top priority.
cons:
No concern whatsoever for employee burnout and health.
Management is inept and unable to actually manage and inspire their employees--they simply micromanage to an extreme degree and never allow the engineers any professional latitude. The engineers are basically told exactly what to do--any creativity that deviates even slightly is looked upon negatively.

job_title: Associate Software QA Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
1) Intel Security has passionate and hard working people.
2) Good engineering practices.
3) Lot of learning opportunities within the organization.
4) Friendly and dynamic management.
cons:
1) At times the work-load is too much.
2) Not many activities organized to know more people and relax.
3) The campus has no good facilities.

job_title: Portfolio Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great company with opportunities to do meaningful work. You get a chance to expand your scope to the ends of your personal limits. Intel provides you with not just one opportunity but several different opportunities to express and develop yourself as much as you are able to handle.
cons: Continuous change in the business, technology and management reorganizations.

pros: Benefits are good.  People are driven.  There are opportunities to move around and experience many different roles within the corporation.
cons: It's a large corporation.  Bureaucratic at times and subject to treating people as numbers.  Flexibility has been decreasing steadily over the past several years.

pros: There are many great reasons including benefits, smart people, and salary.. that is if you end up in a group and job that is mundane.
cons: often overworked yet underutilized. You may be smarter than your managing hierarchy.  a lot of politics make it difficult to get work done

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Good pay, benefits and culture.  Lot of amenities for employees including gym, yoga and other activities.  Work, Life Balance is very well addressed.  Joy to work for company
cons: Their year end rating system is not correctly used.  If the manager doesn't know how to keep the employees happy with this system, lot of people get hurt.

pros: Consistent bonus supplement low base salaries offered to employees
cons: Significant undervaluing contributions of senior engineers. When the job is easy at junior grade levels, people perform the grunt work well with discipline and get rewarded. When they become senior, the scope of responsibility undertaken voluntarily by the employee is high but no matter what one does, it is not rewarded accordingly.

pros: Benefits are above average. They go beyond most to show that the employees matter. Totally committed to employee safety. Management asks for and excepts employee input. One of the best companies I have ever worked for.
cons: Not much bad I can say. Working a compressed work week does not agree with everyone. Made for plenty of time off, but does get old.

pros: work life balance ok for the most part, good benefits and exciting high tech field.
cons: current management doesn't have clear idea of where to go, lot of shuffling of the work force and overall bad morale

review_title: Broken between Sr and FL Management
pros: Lots of smart and nice peers, but trust disappears if they go into management.
cons: Meritocracy and transparency are doublespeak. Big gap between do-ers and upper management. 2016 cuts have killed trust and will bring out cut throat internal competition. Low level managers don't have all the facts but can kill careers.

review_title: As a contractor for technical writing and training I enjoyed the assignment...good working conditions, pleasant peers.
pros: Good people to work with. Good environment. Great cafeteria. Interesting work. Worked in Folsom, Ca and also Massachusetts. Liked both locations.
cons: Challenging schedules. Not always a complete description of expectations. Would have preferred less condescension to a contractor. Did enjoy work, tho.

review_title: Good pay, horrible work conditions and future prospects
pros: Intel bonuses (if they continue giving them at the same rate) put total comp well above their peers.
cons:
Working conditions are truly abysmal.  They just went to even smaller cubes in Hillsboro (Jones Farm campus).  
Sr. Managers spend 90% of their time trying to manage their hierarchy of reports.  
HR, payroll, and IT are woefully out of date.
Huge bureaucracy and overlapping job responsibilities even after their recent layoffs.
Too many people running around doing nothing, especially those that have been there for more than 10 years.
Middling benefits

job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Very nice and has a lot of nice people, they also make work very fun and you can get some great benefits
cons: I think that i should get payed more money because i stay late work overtime and i don't get to see my family that much

pros: Amazing people who are making a BIG difference in the world!  Competitive compensation and benefits and commitment to flexibility and being a Great Place to Work!
cons: Work many hours and always "on".  You definitely need to be someone who is driven by this type of culture to be successful and happy at Intel.

job_title: Senior Manufacturing Technician in Chandler, AZ
pros: Great pay and benefits. Very exciting cutting edge work. Great training. Great culture.
cons: Like all big companies it's about dollars. When the company is doing well everybody benefits. But when times are tough financially budget cuts and layoffs become the norm. Especially targeted for layoff are those in higher pay grades and close to retirement. If you know this ahead of time and save money and plan it's no big deal.

pros: Cutting edge work, best in class EXOS program (trainers/nutritionist/exercise classes), seems better than average on keeping employees long term, good work life balance if you are on the software side
cons: not an agile company in general, even hiring has a huge overhead. Hardware side of the company is a fine-tuned machine, software side is still rough around the edges

review_title: BAD management and BAD place to work for serious software programmer
pros: Free drinks from coffee machine, free fruits program
cons:
Bad environment for serious software programmer. The company focus too much on the hardware until the software departments do not have proper and healthy software culture. This leads to bad software quality especially the internal tools. Software engineers in my department are mostly under lots of stress getting a half baked product out quickly and then struggle with tons of bugs. And while we are fixing bugs and providing support to the users, the management pushed us to deliver more features or new app/tool. This department is super under resource and sadly the management still want to be even more stingy by expanding the business scope without hiring more engineers.

I worked in the so called "low cost geography", and yet my wages and salary is not even on par with the market value after working in Intel for 3 years. This is a very slow career growth for me. And Intel is not as high tech as everyone think. They give engineers slow laptop, they still using old system and the management are pretty much old school and reluctant to change.

There is this graduate trainee program going on in Malaysia Site. Basically this program is to hire fresh grad with 1 year contract.  Unlike the permanent employee, all the graduate trainee are not entitled for various bonuses such as Quarterly Profit Bonus, Annual Performance Bonus. In my department the management treat the Graduate Trainee even worst. There are times where the department give priority for the permanent staff to have a proper wide screen monitor, while the Graduate Trainee only get to use a square IBM monitor! Graduate trainee also gets older laptop and they are not entitled to claim for broadband and online external training.

review_title: BAD management and BAD place to work for serious software programmer

cons:

And Intel is not as high tech as everyone think. They give engineers slow laptop, they still using old system and the management are pretty much old school and reluctant to change.

In my department the management treat the Graduate Trainee even worst. There are times where the department give priority for the permanent staff to have a proper wide screen monitor, while the Graduate Trainee only get to use a square IBM monitor! Graduate trainee also gets older laptop and they are not entitled to claim for broadband and online external training.

review_title: Good company for career growth aspect
pros:
You get to work on cutting edge technology. 
Currently Intel is pushing hard to establish a foothold in the 5G modem market as well as AI.
Also I expect Intel's acquisition of Israel's Mobileye is soon going to open huge markets for Intel's wireless technology as well.
cons: There is too much work pressure in some teams like the firmware teams. The work life balance is more oftenly compromised.

pros: Flexibility, strong career development, opportunities for international rotations, good canteen food, free coffee, nice people, rewards hard work and new ideas, good pension and share investment schemes. Free health insurance and gyms. Free Gym classes.
cons: Sometimes a little slow to keep up with the market in terms of basic pay but still stays in top tier.

job_title: Manufacturing Technician in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: World class manufacturing for computer chips, clean-room environment. Team and Individual jobs tasks with positive growth and offsite vendor training to further develop job skills.
cons: Due to world competitiveness and lower employee wages  Intel computer chip manufacturing  have relocated overseas in China, Israel and Ireland.

review_title: Amazing benefits and so many career opportunities!
pros: Sabbaticals, LGBT benefits, free training classes, on-site health centers, on-site fitness centers with free fitness classes and more!  I also have had the opportunity to change careers within Intel.  I've been able to work in the Fab, assembly and test, test software and now Human Resources.  I have been here for 14 years and hope to retire from Intel.
cons: Nothing I can think of!

pros:
- Some of the best minds in the world. 
- Incredible access to resources and opportunities to work with giant manufacturing and supply chain infrastructure.
- There are no lazy people at Intel, just overworked people.
cons:
- Too big. 
- Too many gatekeepers, things take a long time to get done because there are so many involved
- People become averse to risk and become filled with fear 
- Management definitely rules through fear.

pros: There is an abundance of opportunity at Intel but it depends on a lot of internal networking to develop a job for yourself.
cons: The cube environment leaves people feeling lonely even though they are surrounded by people.  Organization of work space is not by functional area, so it was difficult to find anyone else working on the same project.

pros: High quality technical work is valued, fair and using the system for focals, new ideas are valued, management supports or explains why not
cons: The nature of work drives long hours and extreme focus on results, difficulties with life and work balance, education degrees not always valued. Larger innovation projects face higher barriers to implement.

pros:
Secure job compared to other companies which lay off many engineer periodically.
If you like low-level programming, then is could be just for you.
cons: Big corporate - sometimes you get the feeling you are working on something that will get trashed as soon as the senior management sobers up.

review_title: Work Hard, need to be close to the revenue stream to be appropriately rewarded for that work.
pros: Good flexibility with benefits and balance time agains long work hours.
cons: Advancement opportunities, reward for good performance is inadequate if role is removed from direct revenue impact.

pros: Intel is a great place to work providing a good work lif balance. The people are very talented and the product line is very innovative.
cons: The corporate culture is confrontational and needs some professional attitude adjustment. Else, you will find yourself out of place at Intel.

pros: Great place to work, flat corporate structure (everyone is accessible), decent pay, smart coworkers, company cares about your growth and progress
cons: It's a highly specialized industry (silicon manufacturing), and being the best at what they are, it's really the high point of being in the silicon manufacturing industry.

review_title: Overall I have had a good experience over my 11 years at Intel.
job_title: Senior Technical Marketing Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Taking all 4 weeks of my vacation is never a problem.  Training is encouraged, so you can stay current. Intel has been one of the best companies to work for.
cons: More work than time for family life.  Travel can be a problem in my position.  Getting the equipment needed to do your job needs lots of justifcation.

job_title: Graduate Technical Intern in Folsom, CA
pros: The small group I worked with was a great group of people, doing interesting work.  As an intern, I was happy to see they help you with the learning curve, but still expect you to pick it up and work hard.
cons: Lots of bureaucracy and politics.  Half way through my internship, my group was disbanded and people were moved around with little satisfactory explanation.

review_title: Great place to work on cutting edge products that impact every one
job_title: Senior Verification Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros:
Great place to work
Most cutting edge product development
Opportunity in multiple technologies/desciplines
Good benifits
cons: Longer decision making needs to be fixed which is due to bigger hierarchy

review_title: Fantastic technology company, great culture, great company overall
pros: Always challenging, very smart/competent coworkers, very driven culture, good benefits (including an eight week paid sabbatical every seven years), great management; always feels good working for the company driving Moore's law and exponential growth in technology
cons: Culture can be a little stuffy compared to other tech companies; some areas of the company have too much governance, not enough freedom for teams to do their own thing

review_title: Interesting project, frustrating experience with corporate
pros: There are always interesting projects to work on.  The company has a commitment to diversity and ethical behaviour.  Pressure to work overtime is reasonably low.
cons: Information sharing within the company is remarkably restrictive considering this is a tech company.  The company fosters an unhealthy attitude of internal competition, both between employees and between teams.

review_title: Intel not such a great place to work
pros: will hire you when you are not experienced
cons:
you would probably get stuck in a job you don't really enjoy.
you will have tones of meaningless meetings.
may god help you if you need help from another employee if it is not in their interest they will in the best case ignore you.

job_title: Business Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros: This company provides challenging opportunities, good benefits, and great learning opportunities.
cons: The ranking, rating, review and promotion process reminds me of a shark tank.  It is too competitive.

review_title: Intel really a great place to work for!!!!
pros: Intel did provide free fruits and drink in cafeteria every day, it is kind of healthy lifestyle. There is a lot of sport facilities in the companies also. The working environment is pretty good and the working hours is quite flexible. Intel really a great place to work!
cons: Quite stress when few week before the milestone deadline

job_title: Component Design Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: Intel provides a great environment for technical discussions in and across teams. Provides lot of good training to strengthen your understanding of the field.
cons: You are expected to sometimes unreasonably handle a lot of tasks in parallel by manager. This leads to getting burnt out and lesser productivity.

pros: They have great employee retention. I have known many people there who have worked there for 20-30 years. People literally enter Intel as fresh graduates and work their way up to high management there. Good benefits. Lots of opportunities within the company to change group or move to any other geographical location.
cons: They have fallen a bit behind in the latest tech businesses and need to turn around faster

pros: Great place to work. opportunities to develop your career. Well structured and organised complany with clear roles and responsabilities, good salaries
cons: Meritocracy which could make you feel frustrated depending on the department and manager you work with. Soft skills become in a short period of time more important than technical skills

review_title: Like any large company. Good work/life balance
pros: The CEO is pretty transparent with its employees and has done some interesting strategic moves since he's taken on the role, which has been reflected in the tremendous growth in the stock price.
cons: Like any big company, it's difficult to move fast and execute quickly at this company. It's a components company with a focus on selling chips in PCs and servers. You need to like that.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Helsinki, Southern Finland
pros: My direct boss is the best I've ever had, but that's not thanks to Intel per se.
cons:
Growth thought acquisitions creates sporadic product portfolio and cultural conflicts.
No connection between what executives say and what happens on ground level.
Far too many overlapping functions, no sense of common goals.
Ridiculous organisational change management.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Good strong company, excellent finance talent.  Ability to work on projects that are of enormous scope.  Finance rotates through various business units so you get a wide angle view of various parts of Intel - mfg, sales/marketing, engineering, product groups, etc.
cons: Way too much emphasis on diversity, bordering on enabling URM's unfair advantage in promotion, job oppy, and raises.

pros:
Very flexible working hours and location.
I have worked from home for more than three months!
cons: Very large company, which makes it difficult to progress in your career. specially when you work in a very big group where everyone is competitive. It all depends on the department, it could be one with lots of opportunities and unfortunately it also could be very not stable with a lot of people and limited chances to progress.

pros:
Many teams are doing outstanding projects at Intel India, So great opportunities.
Open culture, your ideas will be heard.
Good Work life balance
cons:
Many teams do not give proper Technical training, thus, sometimes it takes a long time to learn small things.
Synchronization between various teams is less so many time you end up doing duplication of work already exist.

pros: Great benefits, pay, stock, bonuses…. You will work with very high caliber people.
cons: cyclical layoffs, a less then honest upper management about plans, stressful review process, you will miss your child's birthday party for a critical project that will suddenly be canceled the next week….if you are a technical woman, they will pay you much, but don't get how to keep you in typical tech fashion.

job_title: Senior Account Manager in Portland, OR
pros: Competitive, diverse, strong values. Global player in technology markets. I found lots of opportunities to grow from RCG to middle management
cons: Very competitive internally. Forced ranking and rating. Market is tough for PCs and Intel is driving new markets. The focus on server and IoT will make things interesting

review_title: Great place to work, with excellent compensation.
pros: Their compensation package is excellent, and the benefits package is very good as well. Also they offer a paid sabbatical after only 4 years.
cons: It seems the management keeps expecting more and more output with less and less people, although goals are still met, not sure if it's sustainable. Also, news about any layoffs or closures are heard in the media first.

pros: Only hires top talent from top schools in order to keep innovation
cons: Internal FOCAL process is forcing management to identify min 5% population to get penalized, and sometimes excellent performers got hit with business situation changes. Those people are still high quality performers than many other companies.

pros: Flexibility in work hours and ability to work remotely etc. Good benefits. Sabbatical policy is a great benefit. Improved bonding leave policy is a boon.
cons: Extremely political environment. Beauracratic and top heavy. Hiring/firing/promotions are no longer based on meritocracy. Zero accountability in the system. Many people to take credit but very few want to roll up sleeves and get the work done. More focus on processes than outcome.

job_title: Senior Graphics Software Architect in Folsom, CA
pros: Relative job stability, good/competitive compensation, internal opportunities, technical knowledge, access to state of the art technology, blah, blah, blah, etc... blah, blah, blah, etc... blah, blah, blah, etc...
cons: Too much nose browning, politics involved to climb ladder. Yearly performance review (Focal) process is completely broken and fosters internal competition instead of collaboration

job_title: Operations Manager in South Amboy, NJ
pros: Intel is an extremely fast paced company - if you are up for the challenge you will have fun, learn, succeed and grow both personally and professionally.
cons:
Many changes are occurring and going too fast to see what is working and what is not working !
Executive management needs to refocus on the skill of their employees and use them wisely

review_title: Intel is a Great Place To Work
job_title: Design Automation Engineer in Portland, OR
pros:
Intel has Amazing Benefits:
Great 401k with 5% given each year
SPP for about 1% increase in  if you contribute
Great Medical/Dental/Vision
Employee Discount Program
Free Fruit & Drinks
Lots of Fun Events and Free Meals/Celebrations
Work with Brilliant People
cons:
Hours can be long depending on job and project status.
Lots of phone call with other time zones at odd hours.
Upper management botched roadmaps leading to lots of lay-offs.
Lots of red tape and bureaucracy

review_title: Well compensated but poor work life balance
pros: The pros would be compensation, free fruit in the cafeteria, brand name recognition on your resume.when looking to work elsewhere.
cons: The place is an intensive environment with high expectations and little room for error. There is also little room for individual professional growth.

review_title: Great pay and benefits, that's were it ends unfortutnely
pros: Worklife balance, Sabbatical and pay are all great. Work can be challenging depending on the group you are in.
cons: Non- Exempt employees have a difficult if not impossible time to transition into an Exempt role. While the roles for Exempts encourage growth the feeling is not the same on the Non- Exempt side.

pros: Some teams have a very relaxed environment, you can learn a lot if you are with the right team.  Everything depends on the manager and the work.
cons: There are some managers who have no self-respect because they think that they will get fired easily. It's very demotivating to work with such people.

pros: good work life balance, great place to learn, flexible hours, good brand, cutting edge technology, good pay etc.
cons: bureaucracy, playing catch up in most of the new areas, management is arrogant and slow to respond to changes. too much emphasis on process to the point that it paralyzes you.

review_title: Racism still exist at Intel as being  Green Badge  vs  Blue Badge Employee
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Today, they had an event at Intel. There was some food and drinks. I thought it was for everyone. When i was about to get on the line for some food, and drink some lady stopped me and told me that it was  only for blue badges. I felt so bad about it. If i knew i would never get on the line to have their creepy food.
cons: Not an equal opportunity employer

review_title: Successful leader company in high tech industry with highly talented workforce
job_title: Senior EMEA Sales & Marketing Manager in Milan
pros:
International & stimulating  work environment.
Good  and Meritocracy based compensation.
Leading company in high tech industry.
Continuous learning and career development opportunities.
Great colleagues and best in class workforce.
cons: Current massive reorg is disrupting the work environment and employees  morale, forcing many great talents to leave the company.

job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
a. Great and big organization offers better job security, benefits and perks.
b. Possibility to move within organization exists depending on personal drive.
c. Infinite learning opportunities exists.
cons: a. Easy to get comfortable and get trapped in mundane activities supporting managers/bosses will.

pros: Benefits, pay, free coffee for employees!  Lower level management is usually very understanding and supportive of life and personal goals.
cons: Decisions don’t always seem to be what’s best for the whole. It’s difficult to move into other fields even with training or school.  Can seem to get pigeon holed.

pros: good salary with different components (base, bonus, stock) , interesting and very advanced technology, a lot of opportunities due to the size of the company
cons: unclear future due to big challenges on the technology, mediocre management with too high salaries, very unclear communication & decisions

job_title: Component Design Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros:
Good work life balance.
Friendly environment.
Good benefits.
Good food, free fruit, free real coffee, tea.
Good moral, good products.
cons:
Internal team competition, but I don't know if this is common amongst team.
Micro management by senior team members.
Performance review is relative to team, and merits are superficial.

review_title: Stable Employment but Very Stale Managers
job_title: Senior S/W Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Stable employment, above average compensation, professional environment.
cons: Disengaged managers who have been in their positions very long term,  very little turnover in front line managers, directors and GMs.

job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
Have been with Intel ~8 years. 

Leading edge technology and lot of learn. Flexible management to allow easy move in different domains. 

Shuttle services (bmtc buss passes given free),
internet access at home,
good travel and reimbursement policies
Good campus,
good quarterly celebrations and year end celebrations
Good cafe (though paid food),
cons:
Need to hire good talent and pay good attention to retention. 
Need to solve traffic problem in front of SRR main gate.

pros: Pay is ok in Portland area but with the sacrifice of your family life. Sabbatical is good if you stayed long enough to actually use it. Insurance and benefits like onsite gyms, eye doctors, dentists, health centers are all positive, again if you get to use them.
cons:
In Portland Technology Development, the biggest problem I've seen is the incompetent top managers. Not that they are technologically incompetent, but becasue the important technological decisions/directions are changed on a weekly basis due to product roadmap change. I feel this company is very product/market oriented. Because of this, an engineer's work for weeks, months or even years, easily goes in vain simply due to the direction change. In the end of the year, no one cares what you have done, the managers only value the outcome and if you have none, regardless it's due to the directions change, you are screwed. It just makes you feel you are cheap and expendable.

An engineer in PTD has minimum chance of career growth. No way to switch to other companies because of the geological location. The skills are also not very transferrable considering all the code names and acronyms. Everything is secret. You can only learn what you need to know. 

Weekend meetings and extra work often ruin your personal life and trip plans. Depending on the manager, you can be called for weekend coverage very often with no compensation day. Favoritism is something that does exist. The exposure to top managers decides how good your Focal is, not the time/effort you spent on your work. So practice your bragging/chit-chat skill if you decide to climb the Intel ladder. Also be sure to spend time on attending every possible meeting than doing the job. Someone will pick it up anyway. Top managers are impressed by talkers much more than doers.

pros:
Reliable work: Even if automation steals your job, they'll retrain you to do another.
Low turnover. 
Great mobility between day and night shift. If you can't work nights, they work with you immediately to get you off them.
cons:
Limited upward mobility, rumored lateral mobility. Staying a tech for two years brands you as a tech and possibly stuck that way.
You will do the same job, repeatedly, for years.

job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: Work-Life Balance, Pay is OK, Sabbaticals, that's about it...
cons: There's increasing feeling of unease from within the company. I've been in multiple organizations across Intel and the last few years have been filled with reorganizations and "shifts in management." It almost feels like there's no one strong at the helm that is willing to make the tough decisions to make progress. IT is in shambles so productivity has hit an all time low with outsourcing abound. We're behind in process technology after being the leader of the pack for so many years, and the gap is growing. We also can't seem to find an industry where we can land a hit on so we acquire hoping to gain market share and then when we fail we sell off at a loss. Culture health within Intel has also hit an all time low. We have many managers that are in high places within the organization that have zero understanding of how to manage, plan, provide vision and lead. They're essentially YES men/women pleasing those above them. Backstabbing is rampant in order to advance in your career or become "visible." If Intel doesn't start making some hard calls and clean the slate of leadership bad apples and fix the culture we're in for a catastrophic next few years.

review_title: A good place for people with donkey/slave mindset - Worse than a mindless IT job
job_title: IP Logic Design Engineer/SOC Design Engineer in Bangalore
pros: you can work from home any day
cons:
I worked in something they call "RTL design/IP logic Design team". Within a week I got to know that the designation is fake. Every body in design teams in Intel India is just maintaining the designs made by Israel or American teams. My work only involved removing errors, cleaning and maintaining their flow. The management is trained to manipulate the employees by frequently lying that whatever they are doing is something they have to be proud about. I was lied before I joined to this team that I will be getting the best work in the world!!! 
As soon as I joined I was given a bunch of linting errors. People who worked in Intel for more years lack skills and are incompetent/useless outside India.People who join Intel after college are either stuck in Intel forever or are forced to go for higher studies. US teams consider indians as slaves and expect them to be always available. There are some very senior people in the team who are so insecure that they will try everything they can to make sure that the junior people will not learn anything so that they can remain important.  Approaching the management is useless as all they can think about money. You will get reminded of the mind set of indians that led to their enslavement by the europeans in the past.

review_title: Good place to work in a challenging business
pros: Working with leading edge technologies and top people
cons: Is a big company that is hard for its people to adapt quickly to change

pros:
-Free coffee, soft drinks, and fruit. 
-Covered parking. 
-There are a large number of good/smart people that you can network with. 
-If you avoid validation in Austin, it seems like Intel might actually be a great place to work.
cons:
-Work life balance is not respected by managers in the validation group in Austin. Long hours are the norm and expectation. 
-There's a matrix management structure. 
-Managers are people managers rather than tech managers/leads. 
-Managers do not listen to the needs of their team.  
-Managers do not recognize and correct their own failures.

The managers in the validation group have no respect for work-life balance. There's an expectation that you should stay late regularly on weekdays. They also have no problem demanding that people come in to work on the weekends on short notice.

The managers are focused solely with making their status sheet indicators green. They will also use these indicators to make gross and inaccurate judgments against teams and individuals. Worst of all, they don't have a problem with sweeping indicators that aren't to their liking under the rug against your better judgment. A few months later, when what they swept under the rug becomes an urgent problem, they are very quick to blame you for not alerting them about it even though you did. At this point, they demand you come in on the weekend to resolve a situation which could have easily been avoided had they listened in the first place. All of this happens with no acknowledgement that this is mostly their failure, and with no appreciation of the fact that you are giving up personal time to bail them out.        

There is a matrix management structure which means that you will report to additional managers aside from your own manager. Often, the things these managers want you to do for them are in direct conflict with each other, or will take a large amount of time to complete. This puts you in a position where it is hard to give all the managers you report to what they want. Thus, when you don't deliver on some of these tasks, you will have multiple managers thrashing you and propagating a negative perception about you across the organization. Unless you are wiling to work 60-80 hour weeks regularly you will have very slim chances at pleasing them all. 

What fuels a lot of the above is that most of the managers are people managers and not tech managers or tech leads. This is the one thing that some of these managers actually recognize, but just like with everything else, they do nothing about it. The major drawback of having managers that don't want to or have never done the work themselves, is that they have no concept of what they are asking you to do, so it makes them quicker to jump to thrashing you about certain tasks if they "take too long" for you to complete. 

If you bring up any of these issues to your management, they will usually give you the "yes I understand" nod, but eventually respond with something similar to "it's all on you to fix this". The managers never bother to ask themselves if there is something they can do to correct some of the structural issues that are present within the culture of the organization. This is the root cause of all the issues in silicon validation in Austin. 

Overall, it's a toxic place to work. There is cultural change that needs to happen, and it needs to come from middle and upper management since they make the decisions that foster this despicable culture. The good news is, it seems like these problems aren't the case at other Intel sites or even in other groups outside of validation in Austin. It seems like Intel really can be a great place to work if you land in the right team.

review_title: CEO needs to follow his own policy
job_title: IT Marketing Communications Writer in Sacramento, CA
pros:
It's a Fortune 500 company recognized throughout the world, so people immediately take notice when you say you work/worked there.

Benefits are still better than with smaller companies; vacation and sabbatical plans are particularly well set up.
cons:
Intel no longer places employee happiness or job satisfaction at the top of their list. It's now about the bottom line -- $$$ -- to where people are literally worrying about their jobs from quarter to quarter.

Company uses some devious -- albeit legal -- ways to dump employees: 

Close a facility and let everyone go because their job skills are no longer relevant, instead of providing new training. 

Consolidate nationwide/virtual departments to one campus, and force existing employees to move there (with no relocation reimbursement by company), or have to quit their jobs (and of course, when you quit your job, the separation package is substantially different), or retire. 

Implement a "no rehire" policy on some of the employees who are cut loose, instead of placing them in redeployment pool for consideration when future jobs appear (apparently, this policy has always existed, but was never enforced until last year. However, Intel made the policy enforcement retroactive to your previous year's job performance, meaning you didn't have a chance to correct anything that you may have just found out you were deficient in). 

Make an "all decisions final" edict, meaning no appeal if you're let go for any reason (the benefit of being an "At Will" employer). 

And, coincidentally, manage to primarily lay off (or encourage retirement among) employees with 15+ years of experience at Intel, or who are 50+ years old. There are legitimate, legally endorsed reasons for this, but it still looks bad.

review_title: Worst place with deeply ingrained dishonesty and political BS.
pros:
1)Great Benefits. Excellent health, dental, vision, 401K, and PTO policies.
2)Company's earnings are stable. The company is never short on cash.
3)Cutting edge in many IT technologies. The company is not afraid to spend money on IT projects that delivers business value.
cons:
In my opinion, Intel is one of the most dishonest corporate culture I have ever witnessed. It is also racist, and I don't just mean racism from whites to minorities. Reverse racism (H1B Indians against others) is fairly rampant especially in IT.

The company has deeply ingrained dishonesty in its culture.  If you look at any long term employee who has made at least to middle-management, you can bet they are dishonest and shady. The company, in my opinion, inadvertantly rewards those who lie and hide the truth. There is no straight-talk between senior leadership and the rest. There is no straight talk between the middle-managers to the rest. There is only BS and it is pervasive. Everyone knows this. 

The performance review is almost always a complete farce. Seniority is highly prized and political alliances takes top priority. Those who are outside-looking-in will almost definitely get the shaft, irregardless of their actual performance and capabilities.

That is too bad because Intel has a virtual monopoly on one of the most important products: the chip that drives virtually every computer today.  For over 30 years, Intel has tried to diversity its product portfolio by pouring tens-billions into its R&D and M&A. Today, Intel has virtually nothing to show for those tens of billions invested outside of its single core product. Why? Its culture is rotten, dishonest, racist, and degenerate and doesn't reward\punish its employees properly. 

Intel has been a subject of numerous lawsuits that validates everything I stated above. Again, no one ever says Intel is a culture of straight-talk and honesty...ever.

I was hired for one project I was interested in. I was interested in technologies in this project. On my first day I was announced that I will not work for the project I expected. They lied about reasons why I was reassigned. I heard so much lie within two weeks that I stopped trusted any word.
The planning was bad. I had to be in the office at 7am to connect to another team. Early morning conferences and late evening conferences completely ruined my regular life schedule.

pros: Moulds your career with new skill set set and trainings. You can explore, learn and contribute sharing and gathering your knowledge with your peers. And most importantly great compensation with amazing benefits.
cons:
Sometimes senior management lacks proper communication with the low level employees on company's long term goals and projects.
Too hazy with too many meeting schedules which sometimes make you feel apart from your work focus.

pros: Aggressive company that seems intent on catching up on the SOC fiasco of about 8 years ago ... still makes the best desktop and laptop CPU/GPUs in the world.
cons: Colluded with other companies to keep salaries low for more than 15 years.

pros:
Intel is a large and stable company. 
We do both research and development here, and the balance is very good. 
The tasks are well suited to the specific employee.
Good balance of improving current tech and building a new one.
Very good balance between life and work
cons:
It's a big company so you never know it all. 
The administrative processes sometimes may be slow.

pros: Intel managment is generally open about why any desision, from why a project is kicking off to why Intel is exiting a business.
cons: Intel is ruthless in pursuit of efficancy. If you are not doing something you love you probably won't be doing it long.

pros: Intel had great benefits and is a very stable environment. Despite the semi-annual reorgs, layoffs are few and far between. You get a free piece of fruit everyday.
cons: Every group is a political silo. Many teams are working on similar products with competing technologies.  Project management is non-existent and there is very little ownership over decisions.

review_title: Great place to work, especially for students but sometimes feels like too big a company
pros: Very comfortable. The pay and terms are good and the job security is nice. Exposure to a lot of different fields and technologies.
cons: It's hard to advance in your work. There is a lot of bureaucracy to deal with and hardware to set up. What could seem like a minor setback could cost hours or even days.

pros: Great place to work, nice people, great location. A lot of good stuff on site, food sports and a lot more.
cons: As in every large company to make something new, not as usual, is a bit of a problem, you need to  go through a lot of bureaucracy,

review_title: Bad layoff practice lowering employee morale
pros: good benefits and environment overall (except for generally low annual pay increases)
cons:
Lower/middle management need better management training and more empowerment to be useful (give job/career guidance, etc).  Middle management quality vary greatly among different depts.  Lack of internal communication/convergence of design processes.  
Layoffs should be based on real performance feedback, not stock award.

pros: Working with really smart people on things that matter. Some of the great place to work events are actually really fun like movie day!
cons: It's a big company. Like really big. You can get lost in the sauce a lot and not get a lot of traction waiting on people

job_title: Digital Design Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: Good compensation and benefits package.
cons:
Unusual relationship between DFX team and Test team.
Test team was regarded as a customer, and pleasing them seemed to be more important than the actual customers of the products.
Test team also interfered with DFX team work, which is unusual.

Work/life balance could have been better.

pros: The interview itself was rather easy.  Haven't started yet but company is flexible in terms of taking time off and working with your schedule.
cons: Pay may not meet your requirements depending on your living style/ situation. You might get stuck in a position and feel like just a number.

pros: leading at forefront of the silicon technology. Good work life balance, with market competitive salary. Lots of job rotation opportunities
cons: Consistent internal reorganizations inside the company. Multiple layers of managements also creating bureaucracy, not always a fast mover in addressing big market trends

pros: Modern tel Aviv startup with good wibe and advanced technology stack. Young team , great office interior. A lot of things to learn.
cons: Lack of management, office location. That wasn't easy to integrate and start to deliver the product and new features.

pros: They train you well, you will learn a lot.  They have some of the best product development practices in the industry.  Good pay, treat their employees very well.
cons: Big company, sometimes difficult to get things done and difficult to know who the decision maker is.

pros: The perks and benefits are a little bit above the average. WFH only in special circumstances.
cons: Very hard working environment, but the pay is less than half when compared to freelancing. All the processes are slow and cautious, except your day-to-day job (that's the only thing they expect to be moving fast).

pros: Intel is a company which gives lots of bonus such as profit sharing, special bonus(for certain team eg: FA team), 1.5 months salary, food subsidy, toll subsidy, car interest subsidy, fruits and so on. Besides, you will be exposed to various type of training in both technical and soft skills.
cons: If you get a chance to relocate to US, the calculation for the package/allowance provided is not transparent.

job_title: Engineer Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Large technology company with many opportunities to work at the cutting edge of the industry. Continuous career growth, opportunities for learning and advancing and having fun doing it
cons: Too large a company to actually have a serious impact in outcomes. Difficulty to change direction and to get the visibility to implement new ideas

job_title: Engineer Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Large technology company with many opportunities to work at the cutting edge of the industry. Continuous career growth, opportunities for learning and advancing and having fun doing it
cons: Too large a company to actually have a serious impact in outcomes. Difficulty to change direction and to get the visibility to implement new ideas

review_title: Good Company but going through hard times
pros: I've enjoyed working for Intel for the last 10 years. There were lots of opportunities to explore and the pay is decent. no shortage of hard work and goals to achieve.
cons: The company is losing money hand over fist. you can do research to understand why. It's cutting its workforce. The next several years will be tough.

review_title: A profound learning experience in technical and cultural aspects
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San José, Heredia
pros: Ample variety of positions keeps you learning and experiencing new jobs without leaving the company. Great benefits. My managers have all been very professional and caring about people.
cons: Repeated layoff processes keep you distracted from work and wondering if your job will be cut next. Impossible goals rob employees of the happiness of ever meeting them.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Financially stable. Leading edge CPUs & SOCs
cons: Big company is big overhead!  The old guards are hard to replace to bring new ways of thinking. Decisions are made slow.  And one may be lost in the crowd!

job_title: Senior Applications Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Great people, solid company core values and culture.  Good opportunities to move around in the company to find a job that fits you and do the things you enjoy and keep people motivated.
cons: There are times the is overly too many layers of  processes to follow and bureaucracy.  People in the company has a habit of creating or attending full day of group meetings.

pros: Very respectful, autonomous and team oriented environment. You get to drive your projects yourself without micro management from your manager. Very good environment to learn fast and make your contributions visible.
cons: Decision making whether or not to take project to the next phase was slower than I thought

job_title: Supply Chain Analyst in Chandler, AZ
pros: Health Benefits, Salary, bonuses, vacation, ability to work with very intelligent people.  Opportunities to expand knowledge and skills.
cons: Shrinking salaries and bonuses, shrinking opportunities for career advancement, heavy workload and extensive work hours.  Increasing layoffs through voluntary / involuntary / early retirement packages.

review_title: Good place to start your career
job_title: Software Development Engineer in Nizhniy Novgorod
pros: Stable place to work with professional employees, good salaries and opportunities for development. Good place to start your career while studying.
cons: Some projects are not so interesting, because that only thing you need to do is support. There is not enough development.

pros: Good pay, great place to work, flexible work hour, brand value is strong to open door into any company
cons: Too much restructuring resulted in the lack of quality resource to re-build new Intel. Due to unique company culture, it is hard for some new hires to adapt themselves to the new environment.

pros: Get to work on some interesting projects. At the time, had a lot of flexibility as to what kind of projects you could work on.
cons: Sometimes the projects can get dropped according to higher level decision made by management. Usually MCM doesn't really appreciate or know the value of some of the developments being made.

pros:
Competitive salary
Easy to work remote
cons:
Big delta between vision and execution.
Interest from upper management changes as often as a 2 years toddler.
HW and not a SW company.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great compensation and benefits.  There are some very bright people with whom you have the opportunity to work and learn.
cons: Visionary leadership is pretty much a thing of the past.  Most of today's leaders are managers with technical backgrounds, excelling at  neither.

pros: Strong sense of purpose; good company values and best practices; Company top leadership trying to diversify the company
cons: My group was behind the curve in engineering practices; very long planning cycles; big desin up front. Career depended on whom you know and who likes you. Management did not live company values. Stack ranking.

pros: Intel pays great bonuses, medical insurance, events for employees and families, nice place to work, internal courses that you can take.
cons: huge company one time i had to get access to some tool and t's took me 3 weeks to find out who is the owner that can handle my request.

pros: Benefits, time off, effort required
cons: Pay could be better, environment doesn't encourage people to try hard but sometimes overworks us, management and engineers don't always listen to techs - assume they're not always smart.

pros:
Can work with different technologies, switch projects from time to time. Nice perks.
Trainnings.
cons:
Big re-orgs shake everything, closes projects and lay-off entire teams.
Leaders don't come from the company but are hired externally.
Bad salaries compared to any other place.
The manager will lie to you to keep you around and increase his power in the company.

job_title: Applications Developer in San Jose, San Jose
pros:
Been working for Intel for the past 5+ years, great employer which really cares for the employee well being and professional career, keeps always motivating people to challenge themselves by moving to different positions.

Definitely a great place to work.
cons: Probably, like any other big corporation there is a lot of bureaucracy on some processes, this is not really a cons since bureaucracy is a necessary evil on big companies.

pros: Excellent investment in developing talent. A great deal of effort has gone into Gender Diversity leadership & development - especially in the US.  Many opportunities for progression for the right candidates. Superb volunteer and good employee  benefits programs.  Flexible working etc.
cons: No cons. Candidates must consider that this is extremely fast paced setting and work hours generally go beyond 9-5 and can include weekend working

pros:
Work/home balance
Career advancement
Work from Home
Yearly Bonuses
Yearly free stocks
Quarterly Bonuses
Constant team building\employee appreciation  events
cons: Keep an eye on the news for the group you are in, non profit groups will be closed down and layoff will happen

review_title: Large company with lots of opportunity
job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Lots of ability to experience different aspects of the business.  The company does interesting and innovative things, go find them and contribute!
cons: Easy to get lost in the corporate maw.  Sometimes difficult to find managers who are mature leaders. Very easy to find managers that forgo the right thing to do in favor of things they've been told to do...

review_title: Large company with lots of opportunity

pros: Lots of ability to experience different aspects of the business.  The company does interesting and innovative things, go find them and contribute!

pros:
1.) Flexible work time
2.) Decent benefits and payroll
3.) Great diversity with decent growth chance (you can switch to other dept if you stop growing in one area)
cons:
1.) Company is too giant and slow to respond
2.) Frequent internal change may cause lost in focus and direction
3.) The 2 items above ultimately lead to some political play
4.) Possible burnout due to high commitment with low resource (vary between dept)

pros:
If you're interested in a topic you can get to work on it; you very much own your own career there
Very open, anyone can ask anything
Get to work with really smart people
cons:
Division I was in was very marketing driven
Poor engineering discipline in many places
Very disconnected across groups and divisions, in terms of strategy and tactics

pros: Lots of opportunites, freedom to work on cool things. IT is relatively flexible for such a big org. Work/Life is very free, bonuses/stock is generally pretty good.
cons: Management at time seems pretty random, decision  making process can be tedious and at time very opaque.  Lots of meetings & emails.

review_title: Chaotic seemingly with a lack of strategic direction.  Investing heavily in moonshots while neglecting core business
pros:
The people, the varied work and the collaboration enable good people to shine.  
The benefit package overall is good but not brilliant
cons:
The politics and double standards alongside the lack of management support.
The constant towering threat that your role could easily go to a low cost geography

pros: Intel has changes, work is fast paced and challenging, you get to work on top class technologies with brilliant people. Best part is the amazing work culture

review_title: Ok place to work with limited growth opportunities

pros: Benefits, opportunities for continuing education, sabbatical every 7 years, lots of tools and support for an employee's entire family--from free sessions with a nutritionist to college essay coaching for your kids.
cons: Performance review method discourages collaboration. Only pre-determined percentage of employees are allowed to achieve high performance ratings.  Reporting hierarchy is overly rigid. Cooperation & collaboration between business units can be poor.

review_title: Intel really good company for most people, unless you are old
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Good benefits,  salary and work environment.
cons: They push out older workers on small technicalities, unexpected bad reviews, or "incentives/threats" during reduction in force, especially those with close to or with enough retirement credits. Rule of 75 (age + years of service > 75) or after age 65.

review_title: Good work environment in some groups

Work environment is good. I work on a small project with very few engineers. Good environment to learn about different aspects of the work that my teammates do. Flexible work environment.
Ent.

pros:

review_title: Straight facts from a satisfied prior employee.

job_title: CAD Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
brand name, pretty much a stable job.

Being a big company you are a small spoke in the huge wheel, end up doing a very miniscule part a big project, impact percentage is less, rather dispersed. NCGs would be better of working for a start up.
the cafeteria is over priced, and some traditional foods can do much better.

review_title: A good place to work for
pros: I am able to work remotely (work life balance) with flexible schedule. Compensation is not top of the rank but job is stable.
cons: Not very up to speed with the industry standard, also there are too many layers between application development and production support.

review_title: Toxic bosses who, ahem, bend the truth routinely ; Stay away unless u r semiconductor wizard
pros: Everyone everywhere knows Intel and what they make. Large company structure brings its associated support structure like IT help desk.
cons: Confidence betrayal is built into the system; Employees are considered very disposable. Factory mindset allows authority only to those who manage 5+ direct reports and have been there for 5+ years. Nepotism and systematic misleading of peers, subordinates is institutionalized and encouraged

review_title: Top Notch Technical People at Intel

Working at the world technological cutting edge microprocessor design

Good compensation packages overall
cons:
project is extremely schedule intensive.
highly pressure job depends on which departments you work with
salary adjustment could have been more transparent

review_title: A very nice place to work.

good benefit and allowance for servicing the company. 
great training opportunity given.
foresee about our career path under the great guidance of manager
