under pressure when there is multiple projects to be completed in short period. 
poor communication among employees due to large organization

pros: it's a really big company. compensation is high considering what you don't do...if you like big companies then you should really consider working here.
cons: the big corporation feeling is too impersonal to me. very typical desk job. in a cubicle. 9-5pm workday. can't stand it. cafeteria food sucks.

pros: Great Place to work. Friendly environment and a lot to learn. Good work life balance and high value system.
cons: The way senior management takes up things is dis heartening. There are not many opportunity of growth in some teams. Look for job if you want to have relaxed life with minimum work load and loads of time to spend with your family.

pros: I'm sure that somewhere within in Intel it's probably a great place to work...like my badge says.
cons: I'm not at the place it's a great place to work.

pros:
Competitive and rapid pace while trying to overtake ARM.  Constantly toggling between multiple project with never a null moment.
New building is awesome and filled with perks.
Management tries their best to improve work life balance, but market reality makes it difficult
cons: Engineering team is constantly in execution mode without much of a breather.  There is no time in between projects, since everyone is always working on multiple ones at the same time.

review_title: Good place for beginners - afterwards it depends on what you want and how you do.

Relatively stable.

Fantastic brand.

Great facility.
cons:
Slow growth.
Weak career development.
Not yet software oriented.
In certain groups, focus is on file a bug, fix a bug. 
Weak middle management.

flexibility - can work from home
insurance coverage - medical, dental & optical
benefits - the best of the best in other semicon company in Penang
OT claimable
cons: career advancemet - disappointing. need to have high visibility in manager's eyes / self promote

review_title: A company that makes an employee feel good.

Low passion among employees towards work

pros: Many different career opportunities within the company.  Located in multiple geographies, opening up opportunity for travel and living in different locales.  Great people, and depending on type of position, good work life balance.
cons: Sometimes too large of a company (you're just another numbered employee).  Some groups and or positions can be demanding of work/life balance.

review_title: Fast Paced, best technology, good lateral movement
pros: Good company which gives you the opportunity to try new things if you seek it. World class engineering talent. Large variety of things to do.
cons: Large company moves slowly sometimes. Will box in employees that do not actively seek change. As a large company, not all groups operate the same. Your experience can change dramatically from one to another. Stress is always a factor.

review_title: Huge company, just a number, just a pay check.
pros: State of the art equipment. Benefits are good.
cons: Just when you get comfortable with doing your job, get moved to different area or technology. Excellerated training, expected to be an expert within a month. Feel as though you could be gone the next day, and the company would not miss a beat, and no one would care.

1. Great work-life balance.

2. Benefits not top of the line.
3. Work can be a lot Intel specific, so, the experience may not be helpful outside Intel.

pros: Fulfilling work. Never the same job twice, and you have opportunities to move within the company. Risk taking is usually appreciated.
cons: Work life balance is hard to figure out. Very demanding work. Stress levels are pretty high. Training is difficult to find

review_title: Good company, trending the wrong way
pros: Salary, bonus, and benefits are good. Medical took a step backward recently, although this was due to Obamacare requirements and nothing related to Intel actions.
cons: Management direction is taking the company in a negative direction, in my opinion. Work-Life balance has always been a negative at Intel.

job_title: Senior Manager, Client Marketing in Folsom, CA
pros: Great technology and smart people.  Worldwide leader in their field.
cons:
New management is all about numbers,  not people.
Intel no longer seen as a cool place to work for the younger generation. Lots of oldtimers still hanging on.

review_title: you're there to serve a purpose
job_title: Sharepoint Applications Developer in Beaverton, OR
pros: Opportunity to get hired on full time. Gain experience while serving a purpose and making some money.
cons: Depending on which team you're working for. You are just seen a person who is there do get a job done and leave.

pros: Good bonus scheme, very clean and safe work environment.
cons: Bureaucracy at every turn making it a very hard corporation to integrate into from new. No realistic career path. Departmentalised structure means limited exposure to varied work.

pros:
1. Pay is good and not limited to monthly salary....additional perks are also there.
2. Employees are respected at every level and politics is "comparatively" lesser
3. Facilities are good and senior management communication is very crisp and clear.
cons:
1. Job security.... but this is common across the industry.
2. Growth can be slow depending on your org...project....and ofcourse your own effort at being visible.
3. Very very very less onsite opportunity.

pros: Intel really focuses its energy to teach new employees what they need to learn in order to perform well arty their job. People are there and ready to help.
cons: Intel is such a big organization, sometimes the structure and management style can lead to bad project scheduling

pros:
I work for the R&D division and we are the high stress arm of the business. Always in motion, always pushing the edge. It's not for everyone, but if you like challenges it can't be beat. 
Great, well kept (and many new) facilities with gyms, cafes, health care centers.
cons: Kiss personal time goodbye. Not really - but we do put in long hours, usually by choice.

pros: Flexible  work hours. Challenging projects.
cons: Have to work off hours due to many different geos support. Some time you will have to sacrifice work life balance.

review_title: Abandon all hope, ye who enter here
pros: Competitive benefits, though benefits don't mean anything if it is HELL to work there everyday
cons:
Where to start:
-Management:
  • Treats you like garbage
  • Takes all the glory for your good results, give you all the blame for their mistakes
  • Plays mind games with you. Pulls you in with empty complements, has you work hard, and throws you under the bus at a moments notice if there is any indication that they may receive any kind of negative feedback for anything you may have done, based on their VERY poor direction
  • Over all EMOTIONALLY abusive, subversive, and passively aggressive (see the pattern?).
 -Work environment
  • CANNOT TRUST ANYONE - because of the dog eat dog work environment, you have to be a soulless monster in order to achieve any success at the company
  • Do not expect to have any real friendships, do not expect anyone to care who you are, everyone is there to survive, and (for those who have been there for some time) understand that it is survival of the most 'paranoid' - See "Only the Paranoid Survive" by Andy Grove (First Intel CEO)
  • If you like working in a mental and emotional HELL, well, look go further, because you have found it! In the words of Dante (from Inferno) "Abandon all hope, ye who enter here.".
 
Over all results of poor management and terrible work environment (personally speaking):
  • Nervous breakdown
  • Severe clinical* depression (*clinical diagnosis)

Glad to say I now work for a company (TOYOTA) that is the anti-Intel in terms of overall work environment. TOYOTA is a company where I feel truly valued.

So, unless it is a choice between working at intel, and being homeless/living on the streets - Please do yourself a favor and look else where.

pros: Good Job Satisfaction. Challenging work environment.
cons: Average or below average compensation. Huge variation in what people make at same grade level. Difficult to get promoted. Can never understand why does or does not get promoted. Very painful immigration guidelines and process for people on H1 visa. Makes difficult to explore opportunities.

review_title: Ok company for the hardware field, but can be better
pros: Reasonable benefits, flexible work hours, relatively stable job.
cons: Not much room for growth, benefits being cut year after year with the new CEO, especially stock grant, which is becoming a joke.

pros:
Interesting work.  
Good challenges to keep motivated.
Work impacts all of technology, opportunity to be driving  industry.
Good people.
Nice benefits and schedule flexibility.
cons:
Your incoming salary will be your salary with slight increases each year.  Easy to make lateral moves, but difficult to make a jump to the next grade levels. (typical corporate)
Typical older corporate culture...encounter people just 'waiting to retire' and not as embracing of change.

pros: Good Benefits, Profit Sharing, employee stock options, training. Great Place to Work theme.
cons: Too much responsible at times. Great exception from workers. Had to follow the program and stay in line. Micromanagment at times

pros: Flexible working arrangements, good support for continuing education and training. Fantastic teamwork within UX dept. able to get tools you need.

review_title: Intel (Data Center Group) is unstable and clueless about its future roadmap for machine learning
pros:
It is a big name company which can look good for your resume. But if you can get to a Tier 1 company like FAAG, don’t bother with Intel. 
You can move between organizations (but do not ever expect a pay raise. The only way to get to a raise is to be a people pleaser and work 80 hours or leave)

There are some really knowledgeable programmers  who know all the tricks to squeeze every ounce of performance out of a CPU.
cons:
Data science / machine learning specific comments:
Intel has little vision for machine learning and artificial intelligence. It does not align with market expectations. It also does not want to solve current pain points of big data which sorely needs easy parallelization solutions and easy engineering tools. Most of the managers and executives are old: they don’t want to innovate either from a hardware nor a software standpoint, but to reuse old business models that “worked”. They keep using deep learning benchmarks for computer vision that show their inferior performance to GPUs when there are NLP benchmarks that CPUs are better at than GPUs. And they just don’t even bother to hire people who know how to write machine learning benchmarks that showcase their products in a better light. 

They have trouble attracting good machine learning talents and the imposters scare the real talents away. 
I see “data scientists” and “machine learning researchers” at Intel who are actually programmers who took a few Coursera courses with a random (CS) degree. They think by running a few online tutorials, they KNOW machine learning and data science. 

Software at Intel is considered as non essential as hardware is the bread and butter. It speaks a lot for the (lower perceived) status of the software developers or data scientists at Intel. More importantly, if you are a software developer, expect that boosting hardware benchmarks to be your sole mission. 

Culture wise:
The Data Center Group, despite being the growth engine, is beaten up by NVIDIA and has low moral. There are constant reorganizations, hiring freezes and firing rounds because the executives need to act like they are doing things. It cannot attract talent as it pays peanuts compared to top tier tech companies and act arrogantly like it is a top tier software tech company.
I saw teams and teams of developers of promising software products (eg Apache spark and Hadoop) got gutted just when they start to get results.

Also a lot of the devs do not know nor use modern software engineering practices like version control nor software testing for work. If you use something more up to date you will get marginalized. (Forget about teamwork).

There is also little to no accountability for projects. They don’t care if a job is done well they only want you to say you have worked on certain shiny technology.


HR experience: 
They have terrible hiring procedure and HR people have terrible attitude. The HR pits teams against one another to fight for talent and they complain to each other afterwards. The HR person also had the worst attitude for salary negotiation as if s/he does not expect a negotiation. 

The clerical staff was overworked by all the managers for supplies and paperwork and was discontinued because s/he was on a contract and it expired.

review_title: Not the Intel that it used to be
pros: You get to work with a lot of very smart people.
cons:
The environment in Intel is tough. Many companies have training programs for new employees, but training runs counter to Intel's culture. If you are new and trying to figure things out, no one will help you. You are expected to learn everything by yourself. Intel also has a habit of taking H1-B visa students who recently graduated and overworking them as much as possible. If you are a new graduate, do not come to Intel. There are much better companies.

As a process engineer, work/life balance is non-existent. Process Engineers are on-call 24 hours per day, and it is very common to receive phone calls at 3 am. Intel refuses to hire shift engineers. The Rio Rancho plant is also being downsized, and 10% of the work force will be laid off in the fall of 2013. 

Intel claims that it has a 2 year lead on its competitors, but that's a lie. If Intel had a 2 year lead, why would they need to lay off 10% of their work force in Rio Rancho? If they had a 2 year lead, why are their chip sales 5% lower in 2013 compared to 2012? The reality is that Samsung and TSMC are dominating Intel in the cell phone and tablet markets. Intel has focused too much on laptops and PCs, and they have ignored cell phones and tablets. Now, Intel is 10 years behind in cell phones and tablets, and they refuse to consider new ideas, such as licensing their designs to third parties or making chips that aren't based on x86 architecture.

If you are considering working at Intel, pay attention to what is happening right now. Intel does not have a realistic 10 year plan. I would not be surprised if Intel lays off more people within 10 years. Intel is shrinking, not growing. Intel is simply not adapting to changes fast enough, and upper management refuses to consider making changes to Intel's business philosophy.

review_title: The Internet Has Left Intel Behind
pros: Strong earnings in microchips and memory.  Strong benefits package.  Gatherings every month to get office workers together.
cons:
Intel does engineering at the pace of a snail.  Their "agile" teams are slower than your average waterfall team.  The culture is driven by pointless and generic Power Point slides.  This is not a joke.  Even the developers and engineers are writing Power Point slides.  There is no ownership in the company.  Everyone blames other people and teams for problems and no one ever says, "I own this problem.  I will solve it." which leads to nothing getting done.  For example in the whole time I was there they never fixed the issue of getting Macs onto their network.   You can "connect" but then you can't get to critical resources like...the Internet.  Or if you can get to the Internet then you can't connect to company web pages that are optimized for IE 7.  That's not a joke either.  It's not a complaint because as an Intel employee you get used to things being slow and not working right.  I just offer it as a tangible example.

If you have ANY talent at all stay away from this company.  If you are marginal in talent then jump right in. By the way enjoy the on-boarding process.  It is from 1990 and drives everyone nuts but no one ever fixes it.  Again, no ownership here.

job_title: Senior Hardware Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Reasonable compensation; plus "panem et circenses" including free fruit and soft drinks, free movie tickets once a quarter or so.
cons:
Intel was once a great company, managed by great men such as Robert Noyce and Andy Grove (who was the CEO when I started work at Intel).  As the years have gone by, the leadership of the CEOs (and, inevitably, the management chain under them) has steadily degraded to what seems like rock bottom with the current CEO, Brian Krzanich.  BK, as he is affectionately (?) known, is in way over his head, and seems to be running the company more as a social justice platform than as a business.   Failed decision follows failed decision, each accompanied by multi-billion dollar losses.  But what does this mean to the average employee?  Nothing good:  intent on making up for lost profits through cost cutting, the company has decided that loyalty to employees is a thing of the past.  They are working to transfer all jobs to the lowest bidder by replacing US jobs with overseas jobs, and experienced workers with new hires.  To accomplish this, they are laying off (or encouraging the defection of) tens of thousands of their best and most experienced people.  This is cratering employee morale, and leaving behind more work for less people.  Trust me, you don't want to be one of those 'left behind', nor do you want to begin your career with a company that will start you off you in such an environment. 
Workplace accommodations have been dropping for years - employees are expected to empty their own trash, accept smaller cubicles every year, and overcrowded buildings make it tough to even find a conference room.  
Benefits have been dropping for years - at one time Intel hired the best and brightest, and strived for first-in-class pay and benefits.  Now they look for employees who are merely 'qualified', and continuously decrease benefits (such as retirement benefits), shooting for compensation that 'is in line with peer averages'.
If you're a low to mediocre performer, Intel may be the place for you.  For the best and brightest, you would be better off looking elsewhere.

review_title: Not a Great Place to Work
pros: Intel has very competitive pay and benefits.  It's how they retain their employees in the slave like environment.
cons:
Intel is a military type of culture.  Employees compete with each other as part of the "ranking and rating system" that is closely enforced by Intel HR, and is pleasant neither for the employees nor the managers.  This encourages a company culture of secrecy, competition rather than collaboration, and an overall atmosphere of fear and bad morale.  Especially with the recent round of layoffs, morale is really bad.  Employees feel like they have to compete with each other to each the "Outstanding" and "Exceeds" ratings, which can be 10% of the employee population on any given year, otherwise they may be at risk for being laid off.

I was part of the recent layoffs in April.  I was sat down in a meeting with my manager and HR, told I was being laid off, told I had a few hours to get any personal files off of my company laptop, and was not allowed to go back to my desk to collect my personal things.  After 20+ years of service, that is how Intel Corporation treats employees.  Not what I call a "Great Place to Work".  The pay is competitive, but the price is your sanity.

review_title: It's a TOUGH company to work for.
pros: Intel seems to have a decent compensation package, there is a lot of opportunity within the company for younger recent college graduates,
cons: Tough company culture to deal with; continuous offshoring and job relocations; higher level management is disconnected from the reality within the company; senior leaders protect their buddies.

job_title: Software Engineer III in Hillsboro, OR
pros: I cannot think of any positives except for the fact that there was a really great cafeteria with good burgers and a pretty good salad bar. My contract ended prematurely for which I was ecstatically  grateful.
cons:
My contract ended prematurely for which I was ecstatically grateful. I felt sort of like a POW finally being released released from the Hanoi Hilton.
The building, all of it, was kept uncomfortably cold
The bathroom sinks were unable to provide any warm/hot water
The Senior/Lead to whom I reported was so autocratic and such a critical parent that I finally began referring to her as "Ivan the Terrible"
The work environment was sickeningly political
My co-workers were either hot or cold. Very friendly to work with or extremely negative. One co-worker actually had a disclaimer on his email signature which read (paraphrase), "I apologize for being extremely difficult and negative to work with. It is because of my long term employment with Intel". News Flash: If you aren't trying to fix it then it isn't an apology.
The work environment was so stressful for me that I finally began barfing 2 - 4 times a week.
The Test Fixtures with which I worked were constantly being altered by other people with no notes indicating what had been done. Thus, almost every day I had to get the lab manager to help me troubleshoot the darn things. This inevitably led to "Ivan the Terrible" browbeating me for taking too much time.
There was NO "How To" documentation regarding procedures and processes. It was ALL tribal knowledge and you really had to know what question to ask in order to "fill in the blanks".
Contractors are only allowed to work when "real" employees are present. Hence, contractors, me specifically, had no avenue to make up hours. This REALLY hurt over the Christmas and New Year weekend where I lost a total of 32 hours of pay.
My work hours were mandated as 7:00 AM to 4:00 PM. Nine hours because I was required to take a one hour lunch break.
Contractors, at least for me, were made to feel unwelcome and NEVER a part of the team. I was pretty much treated like n inconvenient piece of meat.
I had, at one time, vowed to never work at Intel due to their penchant for laying of a few thousand employees and then replacing them with Contractors. For me that is dishonest and unethical. I took this contract against my better judgement because I was unemployed and dying of "Cabin Fever".
This was by far the most damaging contract I have ever worked, both psychologically and physically.

cons:
Recent college grads have too much power to make big mistakes and get so many chances to continue to make bad decisions.
It amazes me that young, recent college grads get more power to make horrible mistakes than do the seasoned veterans who have decades more experience.
There is HUGE divisiveness between co-workers due to this fact.  
I'e worked in 4 groups and no one even likes one another. The team builders often times fail because no one wants to see those they work with 12-hours per day after work.
There's a department called the Great Place to Work department that puts together lame things for folks to feel like they're important but they are simply ridiculous ways of saying "we're trying" rather than make real changes to end the divisive between co-workers.
there is no trust and it's rare to find someone who is truly trying because they so often get doors slammed in their face.
The large cafe I mentioned earlier is large indeed with lots of choices. The food typically is horrible and they completely over charge.
Lots of time off is followed by a horrible 12-hour, ball-busting shift....and they continue to cut resources so everyone remaining has to work even harder.

The CEO said in a video he wants to begin hiring more folks from other cultures because he thinks white males have enjoyed too many years of privilege.
Morale is worse than I've ever seen in my 30-year career in the semiconductor industry.

job_title: Equipment Maintenance Technician in Hillsboro, OR

cons: If you work there a long time and are at the top of your pay scale, they want to replace you with someone new.  There are obnoxious politics in certain areas.

pros: Opens up to a whole new horizon. The design team is exposed to the state-of-the-art technology while getting the chance to modify and tune the product for better performance against other products in the market. Great mentorship structure and lots of rewards.

review_title: Solid company if you started as a graduate.

review_title: From the point of view of Software Engineer (Contract)
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros:
Nice cafeteria and great food
Organized
Great d.space room with cool gadgets and resting area
cons:
Let me start by sharing demographics. 
70% Indian, 29% Chinese , 1% Everyone Else
98% Male, 2%Female

As a contractor you  a basically treated as 2nd class citizen . For example you must pay for each cup of coffee u consume (1.89$), you not allowed to drive bicycles, sick time off or any personal time off at all and referred to as "green badge".  From the very beginning  things were rather odd.  When I started , i was left alone for about a week. No introductions to team members, no lunch , nothing. Out of boredom i wrote a 20 proposal with visuals and backing stats how to improve the software i was assigned to. Well it was completely ignored , not even response to email acknowledging its existence. Indian manager kept polite , but very distant and dint wanna hear nothing about innovations or at least upgrading .net 4.0 to something more fresh. Oh well, ok fine.  They dont use  async , solid or design patterns. The code is working , well kinda -  if you careful about clicks u good. They dont engage in technical discussions, code reviews or any kind active knowledge sharing. Tools such as Resharper ,  only out of you own pocket. Also had to bring my personal headphones and mic for conf calls. The work hours, and lunch time very strict and always had to start and finish day at the minutes precision. I was getting tired of paying for coffee and asked if i could bring my own coffee make. Nope. Long story short the place felt like prison. I cant say if all teams are like that, but mine was.  If you are contractor : run .

pros: work life effectiveness and benefits are very good if not the best in the industry.
cons: Career growth is very slow and takes a very long time to reach management positions such asFor example to become a project manager it takes about average of 5-7 years. This is a very long time.

pros: @ Intel , I found good people and work culture is very nice. Heaven for people who have skills related to core business of Intel. people from other skills will find this place to work for larger number of years. minimum at least 5 yrs.
cons: > Tough to move around different Intel offices across world.

review_title: I often wonder how companies with such poor corporate culture can be so successful. I saw a lot of unhappiness there.
job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Salary is good. Equipment needs are generally met. Most people working there were OK.  The work presented few surprises.
cons: Corporate environment sucks. My group would meet endlessly and never reach a plan or consensus. Meeting which should have never taken place at all (or could have been conducted in under of an hour) would last endlessly.

review_title: Good balanced company for career growth, work-life balance, cultural diversity and compensation
job_title: Technical Program Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good work life balance, compensation and growth opportunity.
cons: There's the usual company politics, lack of timely decision making and a workforce that have experienced only market dominance and now being forced to a new mode of doing business.

review_title: I am Analog Engineer @ Intel Corp since 2011. As a new-hire, I got good exposure to the project flow.
job_title: Analog Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
1. More responsibilities --> varied scope for learning
2. Great development opportunity
cons:
1. Planning and execution could be better
2. Lots of time wasted in debugging tool issues, not adequate DA support

review_title: Intel is a great place to work
pros: Intel develops your skill set with many useful classes and refresh classes every year. The people here are always helpful eventhough they may not work with you. The pay is great!
cons: Intel is a very process oriented company. Eventhough they encourage you to think outside the box and be innovative, at times, this becomes hard to achieve with current process.

pros: Job Security and Work-life balance.  There is a good sense of work life balance within the company and generally you can work out your needs with your manager. Also Job security with the company is good, it is a good company to retire from and you have a sabatical ever 7 years.
cons: The yearly review process may not reflect the amount of work you did.

job_title: R&D Test Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: will work with very talented individuals and cutting edge technology.  will work with large, cross-functional teams.
cons: evening and weekend work is expected.  flex time is supported, but often not practical with other demands.  don't think I ever used all of my vacation days in a year and they are not rolled over.

pros: The working environment is quite nice. The team I worked in is like a big family. People there are hard-working. And they are patient when you ask them questions. It was a valuable experience for me.
cons: As far as I know, the corporation is good. But some department in it doesn't accept international applicants. That may depress some applicants from other countries.

review_title: Engineers are given what they need.
pros: Compensation is good. I think each department is different. My environment was supportive. Training and development is good.
cons: Because it's a big company, engineers have some choices to make about which department or product they want to be a part of. This leads to some jostling when things get reorganized.

review_title: Terrific place to join strategic thinkging and doing and management!
pros: Intel is the center of so many universes, working here was akin to helping so many people the world over in their  everyday lives!
cons: At time, too management heavy, with time spent at meetings more than doing one's work.

pros: I believe that to be productive you should really love your job and be happy. That is what Intel was for me.I totally felt the company and it was such a pleasure to work with INTEL and its employees. All the people were very warm and they keep you motivated through some activities.
cons: I haven't seen a downside during my work experience

pros: Flexibility, stability, corporate services, vacation time, sabbatical, family atmosphere (depends on group you work for)
cons: Monotonous jobs, fickle management, low travel budgets, low stock grants, complacent upper management, too much management, no headroom for growth

pros: Intel is a solid company to work for. Intel have had the history and the vision for the future which makes it the best place to work for
cons: As a big company you do not have the opportunity to progress your career as you wish to

pros: great benefits, probably close to the best i have seen in this day and age. pay is good too and vacation time off.
cons: managers are technical and not people based. some of the worst managers in the business i have come across, think they are great because they have a manager label. HR is toothless.

review_title: Great, unless you are unlucky enough to land in a bad project
pros: Smart people, disciplined processes, good compensation and excellent benefits.
cons: If you land in a project with a bad manager or with no direction, you can end up spinning your wheels furiously and getting nowhere.

pros: good culture, good people. Decent benefits and the ability rotate every 2 years is a nice change of pace
cons: you can be overworked pretty easily. work can become tedious at times. nothing else to report

job_title: Senior Sales & Marketing Group Manager in Maricopa, AZ

cons: Corporate culture is at odds with actions.  Goal is to convince the world of PC stance on everything but actions speak louder than words.  Ethical focus is lacking, management is from the 18th century

pros:
Intel is one of the best place to work.
Factors such as work-life balance, professionalism, employee respect, 
earnings, stocks, bonuses etc are all very very good
cons: You need to really think harder to find cons at Intel.  Sorry I dont have any except internal politcs, but even that natural when there are humans.

pros:
Well paid.
Rewards like gift coupons based on performance.
Goodies at special occasions.
Cafe offers free juices, soft drinks, buttermilk etc.

Crappy work.
Lot of head weight to the leads. Zero guidance, average knowledge, very high attitude.
Work hours can go from 10-12 hours a day (yes, even for an intern!).

you own your own career

work life balance

big company where individual end up doing very specific work

pros: Great pay and benefits are included.
cons: Ranking and Rating becomes a game of who you know and if you manager will back you up.

pros: You are surrounded by some of the most intelligent people anywhere, and you get to work with the most advanced technology in the world! You also have the freedom to chart your own career path. Management is fairly accessible due to open door policy.

review_title: Great work environment, but company lacks cohesive strategy for growth

pros:

pros: Compressed work week, hype, 401K

Compressed work hours, manufacturer managers, senior people.  Management failed to encourage education benefits and support.  This is a completely soul sucking cultureless company. Go work for Amazon, Google, Microsoft. All pay better and have better company culture.
Pay below education level.  A good ole boy culture.

review_title: Overall a great place to work!
pros: Great culture. Great platform to learn. You get to work on cutting edge technology no matter which project you belong to.
cons: About 5% bottom performers are fired every year from the company. So not a place to get into comfort zone.

review_title: Great Company that continuously improves & transform

cons: If you are resistant to change Intel will leave you behind...be ready to pivot!

In Intel you can take your professional level higher.

review_title: Not a great company to work at.
pros: Clean, Certain techs do very good work.
cons: Green Badges "Temps" or "Contingent Workers" are shut out of any and all Intel parties/programs/events. As a veteran I tried to attend their veteran event and was turned away because my badge wasn't blue. The Actual workers for Intel "Blue Badges" talk down on green badges.  EXTREMELY one sided racial ratio. Nobody speaks English unless they have to. Very poor security, people walk out with items in their purse/luggage all the time.

review_title: A great place to start  your career
pros: A great technology company with lot of smart and dedicated folks.   Has huge resources to throw at a problem when decides to focus on something.

Very, very slow moving company.   Very cumbersome decision making process.
Majority of senior technical talent is wasted as they are mostly doing stakeholder management instead of focusing on innovation.

review_title: Been a good run, but shutting the doors soon

cons: Quick decision to close the factory from what we have experienced, alot of very experience and knowledge going to potentially lose their jobs

pros: Working conditions and benefits are very good, flexible working hours and the possibility to work whenever you want or need to online from home is very efficient in balancing family and career.

review_title: A great company to work with

cons: Still heavily inclined on US based decision making which never gives you end to end ownership of a product, work life effectiveness is bad as you move up the ladder,,

pros: Tech titan, semiconductor manufacturing leader, great employee benefits, excellent bonuses when company does well, Intel Education Service Corps, stock purchase program, retirement contributions.
cons: Late to the tablet and smartphone markets, core PC business not growing any more - new management focusing on wearables and Internet of Things too - significant uncertainty lies ahead.

review_title: Highly competitive workplace working on the cutting edge technology in the engineering field..
pros: Working on the cutting edge IP's in the industry. Easy to transition to other groups if you have personal networks within the team you are going to.
cons: The focal process is tied to your success as an employee and that is tied to how much you manager values your work. Nepotism based on ethnicity.

review_title: My Intel experience provided the foundation for my rewarding career today; it shaped my career and skill set

Culture driven environment

A lot of red tape in the engineering (product development) process, imposed by management which stifles productivity.

pros: One of the leaders in CMOS foundry/manufacturing technology. Have good healthcare benefits. If you work for seven years you get a sabbatical. Descent retirement benefits.
cons: No work life balance, absolutely none. Work environment is very much a silo-model. Management cares about one thing and only one thing, the schedule. Unrealistic schedules which burns out employees. You can get pigeon-holed into one type of assignment. When you leave, it is hard to find another job, because of your limited knowledge (no breadth). Additionally you work with CAD tools which the rest of the industry is not familiar with.

cons: After an incredible year where I delivered ahead of schedule on a major project and multiple minor projects, my manager openly told me the yearly review system is biased and sorry for not getting me the promotion I was expecting.

review_title: Great innovative technology company with great opportunities to develop yourself and your career
pros:
Encouragement to think outside the box and  come with you own ideas which makes the job interesting and progressive.
Intel consists of many different Units so you have great career opportunities
cons: Might be long working hours because you need to constantly train yourself on the new technologies in parallel with your normal work

pros: Compensation is ok once you get to level 7 , 23 days off a year (once you work there for ~6 years)
cons: it can take a long while to get to level 7 , while in the meantime you can comparable level 07 offers from other companies ( years before you get there)

review_title: Lots of potential gone to waste
pros: Good benefits, most projects are interesting.
cons: Way too much bureaucracy, and poor handling of harassment and bullying.

review_title: Will remain great company if certain actions are taken soon.
job_title: Software Strategist in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Being able to participate in making global impact and fundamentally transform some of the oldest industries through the application of Si scalability.
cons: There are typical large company problems. Also, lately the quality of senior management is degrading in terms of politics, gurading territories, power struggle and lack of confidence in taking risks.

review_title: review of Intel Corporation's finance organization
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros: flex time, good benefits, competent and accountable business partners, things get done quickly, some groups are very well managed, good CEO care for employees
cons: no work life balance, could be short sighted at times, conferentational business partners, unpredicable work hours, communication not waterfall down to staff, some groups are much better/ much worse managed than others

review_title: great place to work, but not great place to get paid
pros: Great work-life balance, good but not great benefits, about 20% of salary in bonuses and stock over the course of a year (for entry level analysts, much higher for management), many opportunities in finance
cons: not much advancement opps, very structured review and rotation process

pros: All employees knew that they were accountable for the success of the company. The corporate culture valued direct and open conversations.
cons: The locations that Intel is in geographically are not culturally diverse. Intel did little to support and to retain a diverse workforce.

review_title: Good place for technical background in a big bureaucracy.
job_title: Research Scientist in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Real high tech company, good compensation if you are a key player. 
A big company that can still learn and improve itself.
cons: Hard to see a great career growth, development for many employees.

review_title: Poor senior planning of business resulted in massive changes to business units and layoffs, not much fun. Nonstop emails
pros: Energetic smart people. Good pay, poor communicators (short but never complete info, always asking more questions). Engineering driven, excellent marketing. expect job changes every 2 years as rule.
cons: Changes mind on business units/product tangents, cuts off bottom performers regardless of reasons for poor sales/performance.

job_title: Component Design Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Even though Intel has one of the best technologies and Process, the design teams seem to be definetly overstaffed, which means a better work life balance
cons: High degree of heirarchy, and a huge workforce means motivation and push on individuals is less. From a personal experience, many under performing people have a safe haven with very less to no growth even with experience of 10-15 years.

review_title: Good company, great for a start but difficult to move up
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Benefits, perks & culture. There are some good teams to work for.
cons: Salary isn't the great.  Also, the culture might be a little too aggressive at certain teams. You'll learn to deal with politics higher up in management.

review_title: Worked for 6 years at Intel - great place to work.
pros:
Career development - plan for career development modeled and being monitored be managers who always care for the employees to be satisfies with their career advance.
Professionalism - most of the people I worked with are professional and competent in their field.
Great people.
Job security.
cons:
Processes are slow.
Late to adjust to the market needs (mobile devices processors)

job_title: Component Design Engineer in Bayan Lepas
pros: A lot of benefits from the get go. Subsidised lunch, free drinks, gym facility, car interest subsidy and housing subsidy for higher grade levels. Work/Life balance with flexi-hours.
cons: Require high depth of knowledge for technical work. Willing to work long hours (even after work using Intel's laptop).  Sometimes a lot of mundane/repetitive work.

review_title: Wonderful experience if you find the right manager
pros:
Work is challenging and interesting
Most people are very smart and very friendly
If you find the right manager, you will learn quickly and job will be fun
cons:
Cubicles are getting smaller with less privacy
Difficult to get work done during day because of continuous interruptions: IM, SCRUM, email.
Culture promotes thinking inside the box

cons: Require high depth of knowledge for technical work. Willing to work long hours (even after work using Intel's laptop).  Sometimes a lot of mundane/repetitive work.

review_title: A dinosaur technology giant trying to stay afloat with the pace of innovation.
job_title: Product Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Large company that provide opportunity to experience different functions without having to switch companies.
cons: Lack of innovation, bureaucratic environment,  stagnating career growth, and danger of learning the Intel way that makes you unemployable in many other companies.

pros:
Working with cutting edge hardware and software.  Top of the line medical and 401K benefits.
Very diversified workforce and many overseas opportunities..
cons: Too much emphasis on qualified degrees that do not match the work functions.  Very high volume(stress) workplace.  Lots of competition for bonuses.  The drive for bonuses outweigh common sense solutions.   Sold out American workers for off shore campuses.

review_title: Good place to develop a long term career
pros: The company has great flexibility in terms of schedules and working remotely. It has a nice environment to keep learning from others.
cons: If you do not outperform others you can end up being just a number, however, if you do your work correctly it is tough to ge fired. The food served in the offices is terrible.

review_title: a majority of good but a lot of bad.
pros: benefits, schedule, salary, some managers will do their job.
cons: they make it hard for reimbursement for school, closing down sites, people will lose their job, with no job openings at other sites.  everyone feel HR works for management and not for the people.

pros: Solid company, good pay and benefits, produce great technology, and it is an ethical and principled company
cons: Many senior leaders not willing to adapt their strategies for new markets - they are stuck in the desktop/laptop mode; a lot of arrogance among senior management too -- "we know better" and "we know everything" attitude

job_title: Senior Product Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great place to work that offers an opportunity to work on cutting edge products. Global scope of products allows you to gain very good overall experience. Flexibility to change jobs internally allows for a fulfilling career in the long-term.
cons: Constant management changes and priority changes. Lot of what you can do depends on the business group you belong to and your manager.

review_title: It was a dream company to work with when I started
pros: Good work life balanc, challenging work culture, most managers are technically strong which helps in inexpereinced peoples growth and understanding
cons: Pay, management needs to learn from past failures, too much of duplicate effort

job_title: Circuit Design Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: Intel provides excellent benefits and lots of opportunities for education and career advancement.
cons: Work environment is not on par with modern innovative tech companies like Facebook and Google.

job_title: HW Design Eng in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros: Good ethics, company values, people, and compensation package. On the R&Rs side, it is easy to get involved in interesting projects, have valuable support from upper tech. leaders, and have full control of your career path.
cons: Promotions pace is really slow (at least in LatAm region), so it is better to get hired with a really good wage to avoid future frustrations.

review_title: I have worked here for over 30 years and I think, on balance,  it has been a great place to work.
pros: Challenging, fast paced, environment where you have the opportunity to rise to the top or get washed out.  It's all up to you
cons: Work life balance can be challenging.  There is a lot of pressure to keep up.

review_title: they really get what they can out of you
pros: good benefits, nice campus, smart people
cons: work life balance is often a challenge as work demands push into personal life weeknights & weekends.  Stress level often climbs above reasonable range.  Hardly any time to innovate, create, learn new methods.  Employee competition is high.

pros: Leading manufacturing technology and strong influence in setting up industrial standard
cons: Not agile in product development and overall culture is less attractive to people who are entrepreneurial

pros: intel is a Fun and flexible company that enables a good work-life balance. the Haifa site has a vast amount of eng. domains.
cons: feel that the salary isn't competitive enough. additional, it is hard to break the promotion pace in the company, even you have outstanding achievements it takes a long time to get promoted accordingly .

pros: Great environment if you know how to work it. Super open and can email anyone and usually expect a response (even the CEO)
cons: If you don't like your project you are SOL. They don't pay for intern housing only a stipend which doesn't cover any apartment!

review_title: Very good company to work for
pros: Intel is a very good company to work for. They provide very competitive compensation and benefits. The career development is good. The corporate  culture is friendly and attractive.
cons: The business is not as good as before. Some decisions that the senior management made didn't meet the market expectation.

pros: Well balanced but sometimes global meetings take a toll on you because of different time zones. Manage your meetings online as long as you have internet.
cons: So hard to move up just like any other grandfather company with lifers. Well balanced but sometimes global meetings take a toll on you because of different time zones. Manage your meetings online as long as you have internet.

pros: Nice to have on your resume, Intel is a diverse company.  Middle management is just as scared as you are in getting cut.
cons: Keeping a job.  When your project is complete, you have 3 months to find a new project.  If you don't, you're out.  Have fun with that.  Of course this rule only applies to SW engineers.

pros: large company. many opportunities/ groups to work in. many locations. trying to improve on diversity. get the feeling they genuinely care about employees. very stable. good for people who are older/ have families
cons: probably not as great for younger people. things can move very slowly because it is a large company, lots of hoops and loops to jump through. a thousand meetings

pros: Absolutely wonderful company. They treat you like royalty as a blue badge. The pay was insanely high! Always room for advancement and education.
cons: Extremely boring and repetitive work. Glorified button pusher. 95% of new hires are put on night shift. The hours are horrible and Portland sucks to live in.

review_title: End of the Last Great Corporation
pros: Great Benefits, Good Pay, Safe environment
cons: Management has stopped caring about the workers, indirectly target older employees for layoff. Management are not up front with employees, talk around issues, won't answer many questions.

job_title: Process Technology Development Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: There is set procedure established for process engineers and so getting accustomed and trained in the company is a fairly smooth process.
cons: I feel common sense should be subset of management. It's hard to think of such a great company with world class research happening in it is unable to apply commonsense in easy evaluation of employees

review_title: Not a great place to work
pros: How much they pay and how much time off you get. Working a compressed work week with holidays, vacation and personal absence time, you work about 120 days a year and every 7 years you get 2 paid months off.
cons: Golden handcuffs... For a technician in the development factory there is very little to keep the job interesting.

review_title: Great company but a little disorientated
pros:
The very great place to work - an internal slogan from Intel, and they did it.
Humanist management, with a lot respect to employees.
cons:
Deep and complex hierarchy, decision making is not effective.
Lost in mobile battle recently. Mass layoff from time to time.

pros: High paced company of type A personalities. Loved my 20+ years there. Only left because of the corporate downsizing and early retirement package was very nice and I didn't want to relocate to AZ or OR.
cons: Long hours and no enough information given out for a site that is more than likely closing

review_title: Cool place and easy to find next opportunity within the company

cons: Too many people/employees, Old strategies but getting better with new plans, difficult to find a respective person if you are working on a product.

review_title: Great Salay No Work Life Balance
pros: Intel pays one of the highest salaries in the industries and allows for time off to recuperate.
cons: The work life at Intel can be extremely stressful. It is as if the work environment breeds of unhealthy competition which makes employees distrustful and cut throat. Additionally, it is expected that you put in as much as necessary to get the job done.

pros: Good work to life balance, nice teams, lots of options if you want to change groups, good salary if you are hired at higher grade
cons: Lot of red tape which i guess is expected with every big company, more people than work, less pay compensation than market

pros: One can have a decent or just-little-over the average (not a lot) lifestyle or affordability in life.
cons: Even though company can claim or prove, in reality the culture for innovation or trying out new things and that it is ok to fail doesn't really exists.

pros: One can have a decent or just-little-over the average (not a lot) lifestyle or affordability in life.

pros:

job_title: Industry Technical Specialist in Ciudad de Mexico

review_title: Great career development opportunities and supportive for working Moms

Job rotations 
International job opportunities (rotations and job coverages)

pros: freedom of Work From Home, many facilities, high pay for the beginners

pros:
Culture. 
No such thing as level gap as everyone’s opinion is taken into consideration.
Positivity and knowledge sharing by US teams
cons:
Racism. Although they said that diversity matters. Trust me, been there for a few years and diversity is nothing.
Malays and indians will be less prioritized and treated differently. Income gap is also obvious.

pros:
Great benefits and working environment 
Involved in cutting edge technologies and products (NDG/New Devices Group)
cons: A lot of layers of management. Incurs a level of bureaucracy and sometimes slower decision making.

pros: You work with the best and brightest
cons: Stuck at position and little incentive to move up.

review_title: Lots of opportunity if you're willing to work through the red tape
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Santa Clara, CA

job_title: Component Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA

pros: You have all the means to advance your career if take advantage.

pros: Work life balance is awesome.  They are very understanding of your personal situations and cater to your needs as much as possible.

pros:

pros: Intel is a great place to work. Tons of opportunity for growth and development. Managment is supports risk taking and creative thinking.

pros: most people are energetic, friendly

pros: Great work environment to work here, pretty balance work pace/life balance, A little hurdle to career growth after some times

pros:

At Intel, you're rewarded for being the person you are and for investing in yourself.

review_title: Working with sharp people, wonderful benefits and work-life balance

review_title: A really Great Place to Work
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cavite, Nueva Ecija
pros: A really great place to work. There is what they called open door policy where in you can go directly to the management to address you issues. Environment, benefits and compensation wise, its really a great company to work with.
cons: Few months before it shuts down its Philippine site, some of the benefits they offer were changed or some of it was removed.

pros: Ability for diversification, a wide range of job openings, good social benefits, a great atmosphere and working environment

review_title: Employee friendly, disciplined but open culture

review_title: intel is great for people with family

review_title: Good Company with very talented people

review_title: I don't have words a single word to say
pros: Joining Intel is everyone's dream. but dreams are not true or last only for short duration.
cons: Intel is having the policy of regular reorg. Managers in Intel hire the new employee so that he can be sacrificed next. By this way, manager saves his own job and showing the company that he is good with the reduced headcount.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The company is making the right bets and is generally moving in a good direction.  Pay and benefits are awesome.
cons: A lot of the day to day people management is really poor.   Management doesn't really get improved even though they continually talk about improving it.  If you find a good manager, it mitigates the issues quite a bit.

pros: Great Company, lot of innovation in product teams
cons:
Managers at Intel IT can be non-technical, which is a big problem
Most managers don't know what they are doing
Nepotism is big here. 360 reviews , pay raises are all based on nepotism and not merit
Software Engineers take blame of project failures and get re-deployed while managers happily get pay raises seek out other roles if things get too hot.

pros: This was the greatest place I've ever worked in all my 30 year career.  The safety  crew, management,  and the clean room workers. All very educated and always willing to lend a hand. That meaning always willing to talk safety within your area of work.
cons: Intel uses a lot of dangerous cemicals, that being said it is a very safety oriented place to work, if you follow Intel's protocol

pros: I love Intel.  It's been a great place to make my mark and work on creative programs.  the people are great - smart, candid, driven and accountable.
cons: It's having a bit of a mid-life crisis and the constant reorging and leadership changes are having an effect on the company.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros:

review_title: Every problem is not solved by a CPU
job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Eau Claire, WI
pros:
Great pay and benefits
A few smart people
cons:
Corporate system geared to create lies
Micro-management = distrust of engineers
Wasting money on the latest leftist political mantra has nothing to do with successful technology
All problems are not solved by a CPU nor the methods used to create CPUs

pros: Great working environment, Work from home,  facilities and commute services, Employee benefits. Overall a great company to work for long term
cons: There are many 20+ employees who have a circle of their own. Difficult to get in and gain acceptance. Need better planning in executing projects. Over all confused wrt to what needs focus - Not all teams. Some teams are just reactive and that causes lot of work life imbalance

pros: Excellent benefits, great diversity, smart, kind colleagues, good pay
cons: A culture of constant work where you never seem to be doing enough

review_title: Good place for fresh graduates, experienced engineers should move out
pros: Top-notch in technology. One Generation Ahead of competition. World famous brand name.
cons: No accountability for managers. Employee's feedback is almost always ignored. Low paid jobs. Performance review are not fair. People think Intel engineers earn a lot, but that is not the case. Managers deliberately do not hire anyone who could be a threat to their positions in future. Managers find loop-holes in the system. A single manager is suppossed to take care of 10-15 egineers, but they unofficially appoint team leads to make their own jobs easy, so they can slack off.

pros: Intel offers great work life balance and job security. U are always innovating. Communication within the team n among teams is very good.
cons:
Scope of growth is limited (at least to my knowledge).
There is too much dependence on Microsoft technologies. Intel shud start looking at Open source as an option(Some teams are adopting open source technologies and also Agile development methods)

review_title: Good overall company to work for.
pros: Compensation was great. Salary was good with great bonuses, and a good retirement plan. Every 7 years you are entitled to a sabatical, that is a 2 month paid vaction.
cons: Intel puts you in a pressure cooker with high stress. Can interfer with home life when special projects are needed to be completed.

review_title: Intel as a place to work
pros: Creativity rewarded, risk taking rewarded, work with very smart people, lots of opportunities to try new jobs, work with important projects that impact the world
cons: bureaucracy. You compete with your colleagues - bell curve ranking and rating.  Salaries could be higher.  Can be hard to advance pay grades. Silos.

pros: decent pay and the benefits.
cons: meritocracy was supposedly in place but I don't believe it was truely used. in 8 years there were a few detrimental corp. surprises. management weren't as truthful as they could have been.

pros: excellent place to learn. great as a first job. kinda ruins a large number of other employers for the rest of your career.
cons: too rigid and hierarchical, risk averse culture. penny pinching leads Intel to lose out on great opportunities (why was xscale sold off to Marvell? talk about the worst possible timing!)

review_title: A great place to grow industry experience
job_title: Product Marketing Engineer in Columbia, SC

cons: Extremely process oriented which can limit one's ability to do creative things to accomplish goals.  Since Intel is a money machine, it can breed a highly political climate.

review_title: Great company with lots of talented people
pros: Intel's cutting edge technology will make you always stand in front of the technology trend. Also there are lots of internal opportunities that allows people transfer between groups.
cons: There are also some people doing little things and waiting for the retirement. Not very good project planning within some divisions. Re-org is happening very often.

pros: Lots of smart interesting people.  The people are what really make the company worthwhile.  Its great working there since you get to see early development of technology, as well as process.
cons: Large corporation, easy to get lost. Your project may not make the final cut.  Competitive atmosphere, also more focus on hardware than software.

good benefit compare to other companies
bonus is good when business is good

pros: Intel is very solid company. Great history and products. Very strong culture and employees who genuinely care. Benefits are very good.

review_title: Financially stable but too political company.

cons: The company is too slow for so many stake holders with political intentions. It seems so far so good, but not long days after the company might be in trouble some day because of this.

pros: Great company to work for. I really enjoyed working for Intel. The culture is great and the people you work with and interact with are very smart. This company has so many opportunities so you can get on the right career path. Great Benefits.
cons: If you don't challenge yourself you will get board. I saw some underperforms given the pink slip twice in my 2 year career there. So slacking off is not appreciated and underperforming will get you in trouble.

pros: They have a wide variety of projects and necessary skills. They are a very experimental company constantly doing new things so much of the work is like research instead of mill work production.
cons: Be prepared for disappointment if you can't wait to get your work out to the public. Much of what Intel does in the software field never sees the light of day.

job_title: Component Design Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: lots of long-time industry experts. stable work environment and work-life balance. decent medical/dental/vision benefit. it is easy for individual contributors to transfer to different positions inside the company to gain comprehensive industry experience.
cons: Intel as a company is moving in slow pace and high level management don't come with good vision to steer the company. there are limited opportunity for new comer to move up inside. salary increases very slowly and as a company Intel couldn't compare favorably with other tech giants.

review_title: Overall great place to work, but things could always be better.
job_title: Graphics Hardware Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros:
Stable Company
Reasonable Pay
Good benefits
Lots of opportunities to try out different groups and teams.
Stock and overall company is moving in the right direction.
cons:
Recovering from a stumbling period
Relies too heavily on process technology to maintain competitive advantage
A little too much focus on how other companies pay employees and their relative headcounts, instead of what is needed to get the job done.

review_title: Great Site - Great people - Activities are boring
pros:
The GDC site is great even if you're a contractor (CW), you can have community spaces or free beverages (GDC ZPN not, only for BB).
Great people to work with - Always helpful
You can learn a lot of corporate things.
cons:
Racism between CWs and BBs
You need to ask "what else can I do?" every time, if not, you'll be bored at work.
Site is too separate of the urban area.

pros:
Sometimes the pay is good--depends upon the group you're in.
Benefits and bonuses are also good.
cons:
Your success--even survival--depend entirely upon the group you're in.  Many of the managers simply aren't good managers, and this is fairly common.
HR is not there for you: HR runs Intel, and what this means is that managers can do no wrong.  A number of my managers had multiple sexual harassment charges or were having affairs with their direct reports or alcohol violations--ad nauseum.  It was astonishing.  But no actions against them were ever taken.

pros:
Sometimes the pay is good--depends upon the group you're in.
Benefits and bonuses are also good.
cons:
Your success--even survival--depend entirely upon the group you're in.  Many of the managers simply aren't good managers, and this is fairly common.
HR is not there for you: HR runs Intel, and what this means is that managers can do no wrong.  A number of my managers had multiple sexual harassment charges or were having affairs with their direct reports or alcohol violations--ad nauseum.  It was astonishing.  But no actions against them were ever taken.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good benefits including sabbatical, 401K and profit sharing
cons: You're always overloaded with work. Senior managers played favoritism.  There is little promotion regardless of how hard you work if you're not a favored team player. Little work and life balance.

job_title: Area Coordinator/Manufacturing Technician in Hillsboro, OR
pros: The salary or rate of pay per hour is above the market average.  You are eligible for a sabbatical once you have been employed for 4 years with the company.
cons: Due to the recent company direction morale at the workplace is below average.  There is too much bureaucracy to release repeat poor performers.

pros: It's interesting work, with some difficult technical challenges.  Work/life balance is good, outside of the final push towards product deadlines.
cons: Your long-term professional success largely boils down to finding good managers.  As the saying goes, "up or out"...you will eventually work your way up to the point where you struggle to be competitive against your peers, then it's only a matter of time before the "focal" (performance management) process chews you up and spits you out.

pros: Good company of you love technologies.  Salaries are industry average.  Perks and comps are great.
cons: New CEO is more worried about pleasing the shareholders than supporting the enployees.  You may have to play politics to advance depending on your group.  Some managers will activity block you from moving to other groups.

pros: Some nice people around. Interviews are usually easy. They generally ask about what you've worked on and some design questions that you would find online.
cons: Intel does not really stand up to what it says. Their hiring events are just a joke. They hardly hire any experienced technical people but rather novice for low salaries. Don't waste your time interviewing with them. In the hiring event they talked about flexibility for its employees to move around the departments but they rejected asic designer saying the designer didn't fit the asic validation role altho the designer had exposure to validation..talk about their honesty to society!

pros: Great set of benefits and perks. Good pay. Very flexible work life balance. Very good 401K. Plenti of job opportunity within the company for folks to try new ideas
cons: Long processes, overheads and slow decision making (as in any large company) will test millenial's impatience (to try do new stuff quickly).

review_title: Good, but not as good as when I joined
pros: Intel definitely provides a lot of great benefits to it's employees, and it is a forward thinking company.  Lots of different jobs to choose from exist there.
cons: Competition has made benefits shrink over time.  Depending on your job, it can be very stressful to work there.  I was there for 20 years in IT, and it seemed like you were never safe.  There is a constant push to reduce costs/budget every year.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, San Jose
pros: Excellent benefits package, a company with great reputation at the country level and a place where you can develop your career. If you are into constant evolution, innovation and setting challenging goals every day...Intel is for you
cons: Company culture might not be a good fit for everyone out there. This is a fast-paced company that strives for results. For some people, the constant evolution of the business structures might be hard, so you need to adapt and re-tool yourself quickly.

pros: Ability to rotate ~2yrs across a broad spectrum of business groups and functions.
cons: Very limited ability to drive decisions, poor systems and difficulty getting the right data (much of time spent hunting down data).  Duplication of effort, there's always someone else or another group doing the same thing you are and a lot of time spent getting alignment.

pros: Decent benefits, although they have been going down over the past couple of years. Various jobs throughout the company with room for advancement. Good hours - compressed workweek, 3/days one week, 4/days the next, 12 hr shifts
cons: Toxic management attitude among many of the middle manager class. Upper management doesn't seem to respect workers that actually make the products.

review_title: Great company, needs to work through some issues
job_title: Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Some of the smartest people I've ever worked with. The culture offers great mobility between teams, departments, and even disciplines.
cons: Middle management is a tough place too be -- too many layers of decision making and limited upward mobility because of the glut of high grade level people.

job_title: Market Development Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Good benefits, good salary, many opportunities if you decide a particular job isn't working out.
cons: Becoming a much more challenging environment. Difficult to get  meaningful raise or promotion. Continue to create new ways to reduce the workforce. A very successful company, but missing the smartphone and tablet opportunity leaves them vulnerable. In my opinion, they are not a 100K size company and will continue to reduce the workforce over the next 12-24 months.

review_title: It was an amazing adventure working for Intel. Couldn't have asked for a better employer.
job_title: Corporate Services Technician in Chandler, AZ
pros: Great benefits, pay, and people. The work is chalenging and will keep you interested always. We relocated to FL to be closer to family where Intel does not have a site, or I would still be with them.
cons: Every year or 2, Intel goes through cost cutting. Letting go hundreds of hard working, dedicated employees is always their first answer. Usually the technicians get hit first and the hardest.

review_title: new managment is changing the culture
pros:
good salary an benefits.
there are still some good people left in the company. mostly not in management.
there is still hope that after the fiasco of current management , Intel will get back to itself.
cons:
zero trust in the higher management, from every aspect , including competency and  integrity 
convergence is used as a method to make sure all sites performing as poor as Oregon.

job_title: Process Engineer Process Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Work life balance,total compensation, opportunities for advancement, agressively promotes diversity.
cons: Lots of poor middle managers trying to carve out their own fiefdoms, agressively replacing middle aged workers with cheap labor on H1B visas. The diversity program places many non-qualified individuals in positions they shouldn't be in and they are un-touchable.

review_title: No direction and all propaganda now
job_title: IT Systems Engineer in Beaverton, OR
pros: Good benefits and pay, used to be a great place to work
cons: Board of directors and executive management making horrible decisions by purchasing other companies and making ridiculous products that will not sell other than their x86 products that are becoming a dinosaur..  Veterans that built the company either retired or laid off killed off corporate culture, innovation and morale.  HR is making it harder to stay at the company for more than a year as their roadmap now either to be promoted or get fired without any leverage within that timeframe.

review_title: Great work life balance but average pay for Silicon Valley
job_title: Commodity Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel is serious about work life balance for all employees. My experience includes little to no pressure to work late during unreasonable times and no pressure to take earned leave and/or vacation.
cons: Salary is typically around 20% less than you could earn at other tech firms. It also does not provide regular stock or 401k matching as part of compensation.

review_title: Good company ONLY if you have a good team.
pros: Working on latest technologies. Good work culture overall.
cons:
Bad attitude with team leads, they feel they are superior in terms what they know about the project details. 
No freedom to implement your ideas to write code, even if its better. 
The lead's will impose the one which they feel is correct and will not answer why was it chosen.
They talk rudely if you ask them question on project details, no professionalism. Overall had worst experience here.

review_title: Awesome place for engineering and freedom of thought/learning
pros: Strong business orientation; Loads of resources available for ones self learning and growth; No one constraints you with any thing. HR is very empowering for Employees.
cons: No major cons. Company is big - working through your visiblity can be challenging but can be managed through your strong results orientation and business acumen.

review_title: Careful with which team you end up with.
pros: An elephant, you can work across any division and interact with anyone in the organization. If you have the interest and will to learn, and have the perseverance to do so. Intel is a good place to be in.
cons: Salary is not one of the best in the industry. They expect people to stay because of job security

review_title: Do not work for this company.
job_title: Technology Development Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Good competitive salaries and benefits (retirement plan, etc.)
cons: Second level management and up only care about themselves. Working in D1C, D1D, and D1X is the worse places to work due to poor quality of life. You will be penalized if you make a single mistake. They layoff people with 20 years and up only taking a consideration the last two reviews (even if promoted the third year). Very bad company to work for, very bad. Intel lost its race  against Moore's law  Other companies are making millions of dollars with old technologies.

review_title: Discrimination against temporary green badge employees.
pros: Its only good if you are permanent blue badge employee.
cons: Temporary green badge employees have no respect overall. Management is biased when it comes to bad behaviours shown by blue badge employee. Green badge employee will be terminated if he complains against the bad behaviour shown by Intel blue badge employee. This place sucks over all. You can only get hired if you know someone in the upper management.

pros: Surrounded by good people who all started from an equivalent role. Salary and health insurance benefits are very good, not to mention good stock compensation.
cons: Job is very demanding. You are expected to be available nearly 24 hours a day, 7 days a week in order to stand out as a top performing employee.

review_title: Interesting career; don't plan on working till 65
pros: I changed jobs every 2-3 years, so there was lots of variety. The company makes a lot of money, so finding ways to increase profits by 0.1% is a big deal.
cons: The main downside is that management at the highest levels is determined to hound out the last white or Asian male. It seems like this will eventually catch up to the company, as most engineering schools are full of such people.

review_title: Good and stable job if you can stand corporate culture
pros: Stability, good remuneration (if you are able to negotiate one at start),  access to some new technologies (albeit Intel-only, meaning not much usable in a different work environment), many intelligent and knowledgeable people, some ability to change (choose) projects.
cons: Limited career possibilities in a technical path if you're not going to move to US, limited pay rise, feeling a "cog in a machine" where not much really depend on your effectiveness, even your bonus...

pros: Decent work and pay, flexibility to switch between groups
cons: Bad hiring practices which lead to a lot of riff raff getting hired, mediocre talent heading top positions which leads to genuinely talented people getting frustrated and demotivated, too much of politics

job_title: Business Operations in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great Internship program for college graduates.   Good company for aspiring engineers.   Decent compensation and benefits.
cons: Does not do a good job on integrating new acquisition.   The HR partners were  inexperienced, untrained to handle sensitive HR incidents.  Collaboration with other business units present some challenges.  Managers from other business units seem more interested in doing what is needed to advance their political aspiration vs what is truly right for the company.

review_title: Great company, but workloads vary significantly depending on group
job_title: Technical Director MOD & Integration Yield Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Lots of opportunities and growth space, good health care and vacation options, sabbaticals
cons: Manufacturing positions for engineers are very stressful, with work expanding 24 hours including weekends, not the best Work life balance scenario

review_title: Good place to Start your Career, but move on after couple of years!
pros: You learn an extreme amount in a short amount of time. Constant trainings and learnings are a big plus. Ideal situation would be to go to Intel after college, stay there for a couple years and move out to bigger and better things.
cons: Pay is extremely low compared to other companies. I don't understand how Intel retains its talent when they pay 10-15% below market level for their employees.

pros: At its' core, I believe it is a high integrity and ethical company that tries to do the right thing.
