cons: It is a demanding environment, but in recent years benefits and now pay have been gradually whittled downwards under the banner of increased competitiveness.

review_title: Not Good, Not Bad - just typical American corporate bureaucracy
job_title: Process Engineering Group Leader in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Average pay & benefits, most jobs outside the factories have work-life balance programs.  Stability in down economy.
cons: Tolerance of mediocrity, risk averse, inane HR policies allows the poor performers to stay, questionable business ethics recently (2009's European Union fine & AMD settlement).

job_title: Design Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: very smart people.  you can find great mentors here. Intel really cares about its employees.  The sky is the limit here.  highly recommended
cons: it can be stressful at times.  you can be working over time.   people can be overly competitive here.  The location is not that great.

review_title: Good place to work  for people willing to own their career development
pros: Good opportunities to rotate to other jobs or groups, good benefits, relatively good job security for high tech industry. Results oriented culture.
cons: The one downside to the results oriented culture is that hours can be long when a deadline needs to be met.

pros:
Industry leading salary
Benefits package best in the sector
Great people to work with, including managers and co-workers
Advancement potential is unlimited
cons:
12 hour days
Work load is sometimes very high
Expectations are high no matter what the workload is at the time

review_title: Squeezes the last drop of blood out of you
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
OK benefits
Does not concentrate on military production
Company is well-known for advanced technology
cons:
Extreme work pressure
Inevitable extensive overtime work
Evel system of performance review
Secrecy does not allow professional growth
No influx of external experienced workers
Lots of brainwashing

job_title: Software Development Manager in Bucharest, Bucuresti
pros:
Very interesting projects, very open space in the software division,
you feel that you can really do things. Management overhead is minimal,
and you can focus on what you think brings most value. 
You get free fruits and coffee, and you get challenged to perform :).
cons: Sometimes the corporate processes are very heavy, like filling in expense reports, but most of the time people help you get the stuff done and are not raising barriers.

review_title: Special and diverse culture, fun and challenging to work with
pros: Flexible working hours help in balancing work and life. Get to work with lots of talent from around the world, tackling very advanced engineering issues. Lots of innovation gets done when there is focus.
cons: Large organization can be slow to respond to certain situations. Sometimes changes in business environment forces many unanticipated changes to projects and might because a certain degree of stress.

review_title: Very good company with a lot of internal opportunity to grow career
pros: Work life balance, focus on employee health and career development and a lot of flexibilities
cons: Some corporate politics (which is inevitable) and slow decision making process that hinders the company to flourish.

pros: Wonderful work environment and mentally stimulating work. Vacation is very flexible between most managers and the progress review system is a good way to have productive feedback between coworkers.
cons: Lots of work during the end of projects, sometimes just trying to get the job done instead of learning a better way to do the work.

pros: As long as you say 'yes' all the time, give up all personal life and spend a lot of time telling your manager and your manager's manager how brilliant they are, you'll do fine.
cons: If you work your butt off and do amazing technical work, then either you'll not be recognized for that great work or someone will try to take credit for what you've done.

review_title: An Engineering motivated company with ample Career growth
job_title: Performance Architect in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Day to day activity involves complex engineering problem solving.
Accomplishment acknowledgements and promotions.
Engineering culture with no work place politics to allow growth and development in all verticals and horizontals based on individual interest
cons:
Large corporation dealing with lot of nuclear business units, aids growth but possibly with loss of efficiency when untamed. 
Technology talent/funding invested largely in the core businesses, more motivation to invest talent in new ideas could provide spin-off business portfolios at lower investments.

pros: Good salary and benefits. Culture is good. Product is decent. Exposure to different segment of the industry and ecosystem. Training is also good.
cons: Focal is not a good process. Always have budget cut, limiting travel. Lake of opportunity to get promoted, thus they have the rotation program to move you around hoping you won't get bored.

pros: Great employee friendly, good working environment. Good resources to learn and be productive.
cons:
Not using latest technology for software development. 
Top management needs to look at what at ground is happening. Too much distance is there. 
Company is manager centric. If a good manager is there, one can go at heights. If a bad manager is there, one will go down in their career. It is luck. Chaning projects is difficult.

job_title: Staff Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great work environment and flexible hours. Connecting shuttle provides day trip between sites so that you can spend time with your family
cons: Increasing Internal Politics is discouraging innovation and engineer motivation. Following old time business model might not present bright future but change is not happening fast enough to catch up the current business trend.

review_title: Best Company for Growth with Excellent Women and Diversity Initiatives
pros: You have the opportunity to go anywhere in the company and the sky is the limit as far as career growth. I have grown from an admin's contract worker to a program manager for a program that is gaining momentum and recognition throughout the company.
cons: Process can sometimes get in the way of moving quickly and in the right direction (Velocity) but good management can easily alleviate this.

pros: Lots of monetary benefits regardless of performance. On performance excellence huge bonuses and pay raises. If you work hard and handle the politics you are on top. Good place to go to pension.
cons: Lots of dirty politics - corporation style. Silent "knife stabbing".

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Lots of opportunities to work in many different areas.  I've worked here 21 years and held jobs including fab automation, MP3 player firmware development, silicon validation, marketing TME, set top box device driver developer, and applications engineer. Great benefits starting with 3 weeks of vacation from day 1.
cons: HR practices can be a little shady.  The way performance is measured is not always made clear and can lead to surprises.  Decision making can be painfully slow at times.

pros:
Flexible vacation
Decent health benefits
High level of autonomy
Great place to learn 
Job security afforded by working for such a large company
cons:
Moving up is less about performance than years of service
Lack of offices and personal space - shared cubical design
Somewhat lacking in other benefits compared to industry (free snacks, free food, work from home)

pros:
Excellent company to stay on top of new technology  and have fun with what you are doing.. 
Excellent company to stay on top of new technology.
cons:
Can only work 18 months then have to leave for 6 months.
Can only work 18 months then have to leave for 6 months.

job_title: Business Solutions Architect in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Exciting company to work for with lots of opportunities available.  Most groups are made up of energetic employees that have strong skill sets and work well in teams.
cons: Too much middle management that impacts the speed of decisions.  Too much emphasis on contract employees and hiring at specific sites when job doesn't require physical site interaction.

pros: Great benefits including profit sharing and sabbatical. Good focus on diversity.
cons: No longer feels like a growth company and the CEO is experimenting with drones and devices that are not in Intel's wheel house. Sales seems to be less valued in general with a greater focus put on manufacturing and engineering.

pros: Purchasing Intel products at reduced cost.  Flexible vacation time
cons: Focal review process is a lot of smoke and mirrors. Smaller sites beware! Working at a small site means that upper management is constantly looking for a reason to get rid of the site and consolidate everything on the West coast.  People routinely bite off more than they can chew knowing that they can just pass it off to someone else.

pros: They did/not give any recognition for years of service I rtf how well you did your job. Based everything on where you were at presently. Top job grafe and pay and you were out of there!
cons: Rigid managers who knew not how to manage.  They also didn't know what the people that worked for them did on a day to day basis.

pros: Lots of positive perks such as gym, free fruit, free soda, tea, and coffee, movie tickets, etc. On site conveniences such as a bank, dry cleaners, doctor office, personal trainers, etc. Excellent work/life balance. My manager is very easy to get along with and encourages me in my career growth. The pay is good. My team members are fun to work with.
cons: When the work slows down, there is always a fear of being laid off.

pros: Great company to work for if you have little to no experience in IT. Why do I say this? Because they will hire people who seem to no very little.
cons: You are working for a corporation so like all other corporations you will be treated as a number. Don't expect to be promoted unless you know people within the company.

review_title: More personal skill than engineering skill to survive in intel
pros:
1. Learned the a lot of skills irrelevant to engineering
2. Gain a lot experience of hosting/participating in meeting
3. Developed strong email management strategy
4.  Words speaks louder than actions!
cons:
1. Review system is purely a manager's bias
2. You can always find a way to dump work on others
3. No engineering skill required to be an engineer

review_title: As we approach 50 years, need to up the focus
pros: Well balanced, very state of the art approach to technology. High importance for work life balance and values. Competitive salary
cons:
Very conservative approach to risk taking
Very reluctant to change and don't often challenge the status quo

job_title: PTD Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Smart people abound.
Developing important technology.
Location is nice if you like cloudy and rainy days (I do).
cons:
Management is hit or miss with plenty of despots and micro-managers.
Backstabbing boot lickers abound.
Engineers trained to mistreat techs in the fab.
Gotta "Neg" the vendors.
Rife with SJW at all levels up to the top. Groves would be rolling in his grave.

pros: They have a really great very good sabbatical after seven years of working at the company you get 8 weeks off of work
cons: The company needs to find its direction again. there is too much in fighting and focus on who the employees are and not what they are doing.

pros: They have a really great very good sabbatical after seven years of working at the company you get 8 weeks off of work
cons: The company needs to find its direction again. there is too much in fighting and focus on who the employees are and not what they are doing.

pros: The company offers excellent Benefits and other compensations.  Dress Code is relaxed for most job types.  Work is always challenging.
cons: Frequent Company reorganization can cause unplanned job changes.

pros: Great products that change the way that humans think, connect and interact. There are lot of opportunities to move around as Intel is a big company spanning from IT to software to hardware. And Intel is also very involved in community and support schools, STEAM etc..
cons: Since it is a big company, there are lot of stakeholders that you need to deal with.

pros: Company takes very good care of employees, good incentives
cons: Work overload, few resources.  A lot of promise to do improvement projects but busy putting out fires day to day.  Micromanaged to the max with corporate metrics and expectations

pros: All the benefits of corporate life-- free fresh fruit and coffee, funded networking activities, great benefits, easy work-life balance.
cons: It feels like Intel is very worried about the future-- as they should be. Their monopoly on CPUs is coming to an end.  There are a ton of inefficient processes and the organization is very bloated.

pros: Intel has a good work culture, is a very results oriented company and provides above average benefits.  Sabbatical of 8 weeks every seven years is a plus.  There is a lot of scope to move within the company should you choose to  work on different things.
cons: The PC industry is slowing, Intel is attempting to diversify into data center and other areas.  This is accompanied by some churn.  Salaries at Intel unless you are senior employee are average.

pros: Easy daily commute, with affordable housing nearby
cons: Seem lost the vision to the future, and lack of synergy.  Lots of really good engineers already left with a few of dinosaur leaders remain. Decision making process is painful slow.  2nd line and above, or even many 1st line managers , stay in their comfort zones and never put their hands on technology or engineering,  knows nearly nothing but making powerpoint slides, or creating fancy slogans, or manipulating head count math

review_title: Great place to work...but the pressure is on and culture/morale has taken a hit
pros: Interesting work and lots of opportunity for growth and advancement. Reasonable flexibility, though it varies significantly by group. Intel employees are some of the smartest, most driven and hardest-working people you'll ever find.
cons: The overall pace of work and organizational churn has become frenetic; many teams operating in continual fire-fighting mode. Decision-making can be lengthy and painful. Culture and working environment is highly dependent on specific team & local management.

pros: Great company to start at out of college. Teams are large and take the time to train you. Company offers a good work/life balance. However, it's challenging to move to different groups since Intel just wants you to be an expert in your specific area of work for 20+ years.
cons: Intel has issues taking feedback from workers to deal with poor middle management. Re-orgs every 6 months. Lots of turnover lately at the executive level.

review_title: Work life balance, Decent Pay & Benefits, Opportunity to Grow
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Lots of opportunity to make a difference and stand out. The direction it's heading to is promising. Pay is not top tier but good enough and better than average. It works out because work life balance is very good. It can become comfortable if you are in the right group.
cons: Pay is not of highest spectrum.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Benefits and compensation are good
Work/Life Balance is good
cons:
Will cut you in a moment with no consideration for performance or history 
Long Hours, be prepared to work early mornings, nights and weekends if your team has people overseas.

job_title: Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Opportunities to move around and tryOmg new roles.
cons: Lots of unless middle managers and the old boys club mentality. Equality and fair treatment emphasized in communications but in practice not so much. Terrible and expensive cafeteria food. Lost their technology leadership. Now management is constantly reorganization and new acronyms get created for the new teams every other month with no impact to product roadmaps... The important stuff is not getting done.

job_title: Cloud Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Great life-work balance
Great health benefits
401k matching
"Unlimited" vacation if your manager is reasonable
"One complimentary fruit per day for blue badge holders" (i.e. non-temp workers)
cons:
Woke culture.  All the big cheeses and HR are "allies".  Former CEO bought indulgences from Anita Sarkeesian while having an affair with an intern.
Unironic posters around the office that could've come out of the movie Brazil.
Pay is below market
Effectively can't hire to replace leaving teammates because "need to interview more minority candidates first"

review_title: Big company, moves slow, motivated people, good pay
job_title: Director of Strategy & Operations in Portland, OR
pros:
Good pay
Many opportunities to rotate
Constantly evolving culture, for the good
Excellent benefits an perks
Current leadership is excellent
cons:
Big, slow moving
Considered 'old' so have to shed the 'Intel tax' when applying elsewhere
Same old, same old road-maps and business model - can feel stagnated

pros: I dont know.  I can't think of any...
cons: They are too big, too cumbersome and the environment is too dull and boring!  Beaurocracy is just out of this world!

review_title: Use them for the pay and name on the resume. Drop'em when you get the chance,they will not hesitate to drop you!
pros: Above average pay and benefits, when times are good the money really flows.
cons: high stress evnironment, review method stinks there is always a bottom 5% it pits everyone against each other, work life balance is a myth. Its work and work from home some more.

job_title: Graduate Intern Technical in Chandler, AZ
pros: Work was exciting. One could learn a lot and the team was a good mix of experience and knowledge. People were glad to work with you and help you.
cons: There were not too many cons of working in Intel. The one thing could be additional cross functional teams so that work need not be replicated

job_title: Product Development Engineer Intern in Folsom, CA
pros: Intel was generally a great place to work. I loved the fact that training programs were available to all employees, and that we all got our own laptops.
cons: Engineering was a very cramped cube farm. I would hace prefered a more open environment with windows, meeting areas, etc.

pros: Intel truely is a world-class semiconductor leader. They have a huge war chest to use to invest in projects and research and development.
cons: They hire so many employees that it is very easy to feel lost and difficult to get to know other employees within the organization. The cubical world is very Dilbert-like.

pros: Lots of smart technical people, men and women. Authentic leadership -- they've been with the company a long time and they are vested in the people as much as they are in the company.
cons: Lots of smart people when there's no growth and a down economy means promotions are limited for the time being, but there have not been layoffs like at other large tech companies.

pros: Lots of smart technical people, men and women. Authentic leadership -- they've been with the company a long time and they are vested in the people as much as they are in the company.
cons: Lots of smart people when there's no growth and a down economy means promotions are limited for the time being, but there have not been layoffs like at other large tech companies.

review_title: Proud of employer but it was one of the hardest environments to work in
pros: Intel is a great place to be "from".  It has a reputation of "a sweat shop", which at times is how I felt.
cons: I worked in an environment with much ambiguity and often less support from my manager.

pros: Great company. Very good in execuation. Colleagues are very telented and you learn a lot. Overall comensation is very good.  Very aggeressive and efficient culture.
cons: Less focus on research and edevelopment.  Since it is a big company there is a lot variability in the quality of different groups.

review_title: Great place to work for flexibility and opportunities
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Portland, OR
pros:
Great work/life flexibility; no one cares about my timings as long as i get my work done
Opportunity to do a variety of things
Importance on career growth, your manager works with you to help you in your growth
Senior management is reachable
Great company for good performers
cons:
Lower salaries as compared to industry
Very meritocracy oriented culture, you have to perform better than your peers to rise, which results in a rat race and plenty of office politics

review_title: Intel is a career death trap.
pros: more or less a retirement community.  steady job, decent pay, no pressure, no challenges. good for some one not career oriented. Totally non-innovative bureaucratic environment.
cons: extremely high level of org. politics.  people care more about who you are connected with than what you do.  almost no chance of career advancement. working for intel is like career suicide.

review_title: A great place to work in
pros: Stability, interesting, good people. Overall this is a dynamic environment which gives you all the professional and personal support you need.
cons: large organization, a bit square. sometimes they fall into the trap of using corporate buzzwords without letting you really know what that means (innovation for example)

review_title: Mixed Bag of Pros and Cons
job_title: Hardware Applications Engineer in Beaverton, OR
pros:
- Leading edge technology at a world leader in technology
- Challenging work environment
- Best and brightest employees to work with
cons:
- Work hours include day and night due to many overseas collaborations and phone meetings
- High stress work environment with lots of pressure and some unrealistic expectations
- Continuous layoffs of talented, hard-working people
- Lack of concern for employees

pros: Very good work life balance depending on department. Planning is very good for example. Others like the Fab or ATD could be a challenge.
cons: Could be very competitive to get promoted. Also a lot of competition from peers depending on your organization. Some orgs tend to have more micro managers than others.

review_title: Great company great people but not like it used to be
pros: Intel people are the best in the world.  The firm treats employees well.  the bonuses are real and predictable and the benefits are golden.
cons: The concerns are the frequent purges and the evaluation system where employees are ranked against each other.  Also, the once powerful model of senior management being technical giants has passed away as the firm is no longer even run by engineers.

pros: job security, good financial support, big teams, development opportunity for growth, intra group movement is easy, switching between fields is easy, over all good management support.
cons: Growing up the ladder is not very easy unless you are on a high profile project. Growth is more in oregon and other sites compared to santa clara.

review_title: Great company that cares about their employees
pros: Intel cares about their employees and promotes a great work-life balance.  They have a lot of networking opportunities and events for employees.  They promote volunteering and even match your donated time.  They pay very well for the work you do.
cons: The work is very routine and is not always exciting.  There is not a lot of variety or options for additional projects.  You have a lot of down-time in the job.

review_title: Good company for people who like accountability and meritocracy
pros: Focus on deliverables and results.  Open, honest culture.  People are encouraged to move around inside the company, every level of the company is encouraged to participate in all discussions.  If you are in the room, you are included in the discussion.
cons: Not all groups are created equal.  Lots of very smart people.  There is a tendency to a culture of "no" and risk taking is waning from the culture.

review_title: Great work environment, excellent community initiatives but pay could be better
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Boston, MA
pros: Intel is active in the communities that host the company and encourages all employees to contribute their time to their own preferred organization(s).
cons: Like many companies, Intel discourages employees from sharing information about pay and bonuses with each other. They even discourage employees from telling each other their current job title (grade level).

pros: Pay scale is very good with base pay, bonus, employee stock purchase, etc.  It is a very dynamic environment and you get to work on bleeding edge technologies with very smart people.
cons: You are working with a lot of type-A personalities and there can be a lot of conflict between internal teams.

pros: The work culture is comfortable and  you have plenty of resources e.g. trainings to your disposal so that you can be on top technological advancements.
cons: Too many hierarchies and the growth path seems verrrrryyyy long! Also sometimes the incentives are too strongly attached to business unit performance and the individual contribution is not taken into account at all.

review_title: Both challenging and rewarding working environement
pros: Benefit package is very competitive compared to similar companies. Intel has robust training regime for both new hire and seasoned staff. Great emphasis on work-life balance.
cons: It's a very competitive environment-hence survivor of the fittest. It can be stressful for people who are not comfortable in a competitive working environment.

review_title: Ok compensation, global focus, local attention scarce
pros: Compared to other tech companies locally, the pay is ok. If you focus global projects or accounts, available resources are great. More work than contract hours would indicate, which explains the slightly elevated compensation.
cons: Most resources are dedicated to big US and Asian customers and their needs. Fringe customers and localized projects you can forget. Lots of colleagues are long time veterans, and hierarchy can be fairly flat, so climbing the corporate ladder can be difficult.

job_title: Component Design Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: Lot's of resources and secure monopolist position in the market, solid manufacturing, design not leading edge.
cons: Very poor life balance. Expected to work from home on weekend and evenings, but heaven forbid scheduling regular work from home hours during 9-5 weekdays. Endless, pointless meeting and the only way to get 3 hours of uninterrupted time is to work from home.

review_title: great place to work, for a few people only
job_title: Staff Technology Development Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: great benefits (medical, vision, dental), good retirement contribution options, paid sabbatical program (8 weeks/7 years) which has expanded to include 4 weeks/4 years, good great place to work options, high job security for fab related positions
cons: middle level management lacks long term vision, limited career growth opportunities, fab jobs can often get too specialized, and the scope to learn new skills are limited, the chance to diversify and learn new skills are often not provided.

review_title: Poor mid level management. Works like a government org with lots of red tape to get simple stuff moving.
pros: sabbatical/profit sharing decent health insurance even though now comapny is moving most of teh burden to employees
cons: very bad mid level managemnet. Most managers are morons and just beat people. Hardly 1% managers have a vnc and are technically involved. they dont care about employee development. Nepotism seems to be rampant. Most teams have core group of people and they are the ones promoted.

pros: This is a professional work place.  You have a lot of opportunity to do many different things.  There are many different groups that you can find opportunity to move and improve your technical knowledge.
cons: it is stressful when project is starting to the time it finish because deadlines is tight.  You have to work smart and balance your family time at the same time.  You have to be flexible with your time and willing to sacrify.

review_title: Not bad, but could be better
pros: The salary at Intel are a bit below the industry average, but there are done decent benefits that help to make up the gap.
cons: Pay is a little bit lower than the average for the industry, almost constant reorganizations taking place over the last couple years, and high prices for lunches in the cafe.

review_title: Current project work environment can be stressful
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Great benefits, competitive salaries, decent bonus structure and nice amount of vacation time. Good engineers to work with.
cons: Draconic performance review process. Managers are given strict guidelines regarding the distribution of ratings and stock level awards. The forced quotas on lower stock level rating make susceptible to layoff algorithms when job cuts come around. The new converged methodology drives very tight aggressive project schedules and leads to some questionable design decisions.

pros: Intel is a great place to work.  There are many opportunities to work with different groups.  Travel can be limited depending on your role at the company.  Lots of perks outside of work as well.
cons: With about 18,000 people at Intel in Oregon, it can get overwhelming at times.  Everything, every day is about Intel.

pros:
-Good work-life balance
-Working hours flexibility
-As long as you finish your tasks on time, no one will question about your working hours.
-Regular family get together
-salary at the industry average but not the best
-360 deg Performance review
cons:
- Salary not best in the industry
- Flat tax structure, no HRA, travel benefits
-Longer project cycles than competitors.
- Slow career growth

pros:
It is a big company. Everything is settled, great benefits, stability.  Possible to change your positions between teams.
Flexible work hours
cons:
It is a big company !!  too many teams and products, dont expect any exceptional growth in your salary/compensation in short term. 
food is always a problem inside the campus for me but it is pretty subjective.

review_title: Former glory but still keeps up
pros: World renown brand, still known by people. Some engineers are very good. Diversity is good.
cons:
A lot of politics. Diversity unfortunately means that there are also some moochers. Work life balance is bad if you are a good contributor to your working project. 
Values are good but often management pays only lip service to them.

pros: Amazing people. Most of the managers I worked under really cared about thier people. When downsizing, the company did the best it could to move people to other locations. Interesting technology. Excellence valued. Safety really was top priority. Great company.
cons: Long work hours, but then that's normal when doing something of real value. Large company, so personnel and procedural issues sometimes killed things that would benefit the company. To some extent can't be helped.

pros:
- INTEL is offering a wide areas of high-tech businesses and is able and ready to invest
- A strong technical culture and a lot of very talented people
- INTEL can offer a lot of opportunities
cons:
- INTEL is a big company with the biggest challenge is to scale from a PC leading company to a Mobile/IOT follower
- a LOT of politics, INTEL needs to get more customer focus 
- Intel is entering into big changes (restructuring, leadership changes)

pros: I have had a very exciting 27 years at Intel in various roles. That is the best thing about Intel is that you can do very different jobs and be at the same company.
cons: Currently restructuring amid challenges in the mobile market. Cloud and IoT segments are very promising for the future

pros: Great benefit package. Competitive Salary. And good chances of development..
cons: Worker management relations are very impersonal. Not all plants operate the same. The workload is high and management expectations is for you to meet demand, no matter what. As described by a co-worker "They work you to death."

pros: Very smart people, good pay and benefits, workout rooms at all of the major sites, yearly and quarterly bonuses.
cons: Long hours, yearly review process is brutal because someone is always on the lower end (leading to individuals not sharing information so they can remain 'vital').

job_title: Senior Design Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: Lots of smart people in the team and in the company. Lots of interesting projects going on. Lots of opportunities to grow.
cons: Lack of proper training for new employees. The new employee orientation could be more informative. Lots of basic stuff we need to figure out on our own.

review_title: Great benefits, lots of potential for career growth.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: The benefits are great, particularly for those with families.  The sheer size of the company provides the employee with a great deal of opportunities to grow their career.
cons: Cross-geographical teams in some groups makes collaboration sometimes difficult.  It's also sometimes hard to find managers that focus on employee growth.

pros: Intel had a great culture that promoted teamwork, innovation and success.  Many times the goals would seem impossible at first but evwryone would work together to meet the goals.
cons: Although the compensation was very good and management appreciated people's work, the work life balance was difficult.  It was difficult to have family time that was not interrupted by work.

pros: Cool tech, got to learn a lot, good health insurance, and other benefits. It was a great opportunity, glad I got the experience that I did.
cons: Cliquey, my teammates were not nice or willing to help, too many layoffs recently. Not a good move for intel

pros: Great company overall, many great people.  Plenty of chances to grow professionally (and personally).  You are empowered and held accountable for your work.
cons: Executive mandates and promoted corporate mindsets and behaviors do not always get carried out all the way down, or across all organizations.  In certain respects, company is not quite as great as it once was.

pros: reasonable salaries for area (although lower opportunity for growth at times)
cons: Job security, some groups and roles can be highly stressful and demanding, lots of internal politics

review_title: Intel: good for work life balance, bad for enthusiasts looking for fast learning and individual development
pros:
Good work life balance
Focuses on employee safety and security
Ample of opportunities to switch cross functions
cons:
Slow growth and personal development
Appraisal process is not purely merit based
Slow to enter market in terms of new technology
Too much of email and meeting culture

review_title: A company in transition mode and try to strike the balance of great place to work
job_title: Product Development Engineer in Bayan Lepas
pros: Intel culture promote great place to work, hence lots of work and personal life flexibility, which is good for anyone with family.
cons: Intel is in transition mode to enter new market territory, hence you will observe frequent organizations structure change and project realignment from time to time.

pros:
good facility, comfortable work hours, promotions options are available if you don't mind shifting professional specialty. nice compensation and benefits.
also very stable work place
cons: not really a con but Intel is depending on its own infrastructure technologically so it might be a bit constraining for developers who want to be diverse with outside tech

pros: Good benefits, some groups give a very good work environment and opportunity to work with talented people. Good culture and values.
cons: A lot of bureaucracy and seems like there is a lot of variation in compensation. Every manager can give you multiple bureaucratic excuses for why a promotion cannot be given or how many years one should work at a certain grade level before getting promoted. Some groups have great work life balance while some other groups have none.

review_title: Big Ship, finds it difficult to move around
job_title: Software Engineering Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Big Organization, lots of visibility into all aspects of engineering and product development, balanced culture that gives you your personal time as well
cons: Multi-site projects across various Geo locations cause a lot of off time meetings. In general movement of things is slower than other competing companies.

pros:
Minimum office politics. Maybe more at top management but its bearable. Nice office and employee perks (good food at cafe, free drinks, gyms, courts).
Need to do a lot of projects to prove yourself and move up the ladder.
Managers are usually very helpful with this.
Great work life balance because of the flexible work arrangements.
cons:
Some of the people are overly friendly. Maybe they wanted to prove themselves through getting connections.
Parking can be full if you're late to the office.

pros: Challenging work, competent technical coworkers, state of the art technology
cons: HR interference and needless harassment using frivolous Open door investigations particularly against folks in position of authority

review_title: Good Company with an indefinite future in Massachusetts
pros: A market leader, solid financials, a good, supportive culture and a company with its ethics in the right place.  It's a good company.
cons: The Hudson site will eventually close down and there is little that can be done to prevent it.  Employees have a limited life span there.

pros: Intel is a great place to work, it overall has a lot of benefits and rewards.  They work hard to provide oportunities for education and advancement.
cons: Like most large companies there are a lot of politics and red tape to deal with. Focal or review processes are not always easy to deal with.

review_title: "Great Place to Work" is one of the Intel Values
pros: Employees feel apprieciated. Information is shared at all levels. Open door policy encourages opinions from everyone. Pay is reasonable. Benefits are great. Meals are provided - the feeling is "we'll make the environment comfortable so as to encourage you to work as much as posslble".
cons: The company is big, so it is more difficult to get personal waivers/changes from procedures. Being big has advantages too.

review_title: Good work culture suitable for experienced candidates
pros:
Very flexible working hours, work from home facility
lot of awards and recognitiion
Very open and flat structure
Work culture is good
cons:
at times, too much pressure..
it depends on the manager though. 
technical learning will be very less.. Not suitable for freshers who is very keen to grow in the technical path

review_title: Good place to work overall in the sense of technology chanllege but not so good considering work-life balance
pros: Good place to work in the sense of technology chanllege, great management structure and nice knowledable people around, very supportive and cooperative
cons: not good enough considering the work-life balance, not for someone who never wants to work extremely overtime sometimes to meet deadlines

review_title: Good place to work overall in the sense of technology chanllege but not so good considering work-life balance
pros: Good place to work in the sense of technology chanllege, great management structure and nice knowledable people around, very supportive and cooperative
cons: not good enough considering the work-life balance, not for someone who never wants to work extremely overtime sometimes to meet deadlines

review_title: feedback about work life at intel malaysia
pros: Can learn a lot of new technology and chances to expose yourself in software , atomation development or data analysis based on semoconductor behavior and commonality, a lot of opportunity to grow yourself within company.
cons: sometime it is just overloaded and deadline specified.

review_title: Fun place to work.  Definitely good for recent college grads
pros:
They're very flexible in allowing you work from home to accommodate personal obligations.  

The atmosphere is very fun.  Management is not uptight.
cons: Layoffs occur every 1-2 years.  They go through hiring sprees, then realize they brought on too many people with too little meaningful work to do.

pros: It has a great work culture. The people are very nice and got to learn a  lot. Its a very pleasant experience.
cons: They make you work long hours. There are times you have to put in more hours than for what you are paid.

review_title: Learned alot about the equipment, management poor people skills.
pros: Good pay, you can learn alot about equipment, good advancement opportunities, such as them paying for education etc. Good canteen, and facilities.
cons: Not great communication about what is planned for future, you hear about it at the last minute, an environment for hanging each other exists.

pros: Great Benefits, great people to work with, Work-Life was tremendous. I felt really respected and that what I said mattered.
cons: I think they need to re-evaluate their ranking and rating sessions, and give the raises only to the people that worked and really performed more duties for the team.

review_title: Good place to work, but moderately challenging job. A good place for women employees, work timings are very flexible.
pros: Good work life balance, ideal pressure, open environment for discussion & raising issues, egalitarian approach towards all employees
cons: No structured approach for training, information sharing for new employees, cross-group cooperation is poor, people in US do not have great opinion of work done from BA

pros: Intel had an excellent work culture. Work environment is stress free where one can work with ease. Many other activities than just work.
cons: Even though Intel is such a big organization, one would expect the remuneration for interns to be really good which want not the case and was actually less than many other companies.

review_title: Great company that has a solid benefits package
job_title: Customer Business Analyst in Folsom, CA
pros: Free soda, coffee, and fruit. Very extensive benefits package that provides 6% contribution to retirement and offers performance based stock  units.
cons: Salary is lower than market, but offset by benefits. Lower grade levels are put in highly competitive situations and not given much direction on how to move up the ladder.

review_title: A good team to work with
pros: Efficient team at Intel Mobile Communication. Salaries at par with other telecom companies. No backstabbing. Very good managers, both technical and people. Employee benefits are good. Work from home options improves work life balance.
cons: Interaction amongst teams is less. Hardly any team events or team outings. HR sucks.

review_title: Great experience with many learning and growing opportunities.
pros: culture of meritocracy - high value placed on self management - many growth opportunities - you own your development plan - culture encourages you to move around in the company and not get 'stale' in your current role
cons: high workload, fast pace, not for the meek

pros: Definitely a GPTW and an awesome company to work for. As a student worker I've been able to continue with my university studies and at the same time gain experience at work. Flexible hours and great benefits/compensations.
cons: Haven't seen a defined career development to go for. Opportunities to grow within a team might be difficult to find.

review_title: Intel was a great, low-stress work environment.
pros: Great pay and bonuses. They paid for health insurance for me for the summer. They really tried to take care of their employees.
cons: Interns and even full-time employess didn't have a permanent place to work. "Mobile" stations were located throughout the building and it was on a first come, first served basis daily with where you worked. More free food perks would've been nice, but I guess that's why they give us a paycheck.

review_title: I've had a great experience at Intel, however the culture has changed dramatically.
job_title: Technical Project Manager in Ocotillo, Optional[AZ]
pros: The benefits package is one of the best in the country, and there are many perks.  The company hold true to the values.
cons: No such thing as Work Life Effectiveness. Too many sacrifices.  New hires may have false impression of job duties; not so much as hands on technical role, but a project management role.  Not a place to learn your craft.

review_title: Great place to work, one of the best employes
pros:
Compensation and benefits package is very competitive and complete.
Good opportunities for development and trainings, as well as a results oriented culture. Good work and life balance focus in general.
cons: As many big organizations, Intel can be kind of bureaucratic in its processes, which is ironic considering that it moves in the technology area, which tends to be fast paced. Development opportunities may not be available for some academic areas.

pros: This is a very competitive firm, likes to win. Comp is ok. People are very talented. you will work with the best in your field. Workplace facilities are improving and plenty of opptys to work in different parts of the company
cons: Not really a lot of cons. It's a big company, and just depending on where you are, sometimes decisions can be slow. Normal for any big company. Intel is relatively agile.

pros: You get to work on cutting edge technologies, and the job is very interesting. You get a good medical inssurance benefit
cons: From first line managers to CEO it is full of politics, you can get doors closed because someone is doing politics against you. The worst, HR can do nothing but "advice" managers, they have no capacity to take actions even if they see something going really bad.

job_title: Graphics Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Salary and bonuses are decent; the four-week sabbatical benefit after 4 years is also nice.  There's a lot of flexibility given to the engineers (at least in some groups).
cons: Too much bureaucracy and no concern for software quality; constantly having to fight others to get the right things done.

pros: I worked for Intel Security and the best thing was my friendly manager and flexible work demands. Also great team lunches.
cons: QA positions can be pretty boring. The pay was not the best. Lack of proper remuneration is a concern for most of the people I knew there.

pros:
1. wide range of positions, can move to different roles without leaving the company
2. good benefits
3. Haifa site is close to central bus station and train station
4. Food is ok
5. Great work/life balance
cons:
Yakum site:
1. Location is really annoying. Very difficult to get by train or buses. Also problematic by car from almost any location.
2. Parking lot adds additional 10 minutes to daily "go to work" process.

pros: For the support groups (non core) - its is an easy going company. Heavy emphasis on work life balance, good benefits, above average salary.
cons: In case you are looking for a fast paced company & job, this is not for you. At times I have seen 2-3 people doing the job of one.

job_title: Graphics Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: You work on very interesting and important projects. Everyone around you is willing to help you. They foster a very intelligent environment and is very organized in terms of teams.
cons: There were large cubicles. Still cannot see the rest of the room even when standing up. Not much interaction other than meetings, and no free food.

pros: Cohesive work environment, heavily team oriented, prioritizes safety of employees, decent pay/great benefits, you own your own training, love the CWW schedule (and 6% pay kick), good people, free soda/tea/coffee, advancement opportunities....and much more
cons: Just like other company's in the industry they are cost cutting. LEAN environment means increased work load with less people, the kicker being those people may be new and inexperienced. Attrition target not hit so voluntary separation packages offered in lieu of layoffs (pro/con).

pros: Proven success over many years. Large company so various opportunities and development paths in both job type and geographically. The various divisions each have their own cultures.
cons: Large company so sometimes is bureaucratic and individuality can sometimes get lost in the shuffle and get competitive between co-workers instead of being part of a team.

review_title: Not a Tech Co; A Manufacturing Co
pros:
Sabbatical is nice; you get 6 weeks off paid every 7 years.  
Work life balance is always good.
People are all at least moderately intelligent.
cons:
Manufacturing environment applies to everyone, even the office workers
You must:
- Hold handrails when walking up/down stairs
- Not text/use laptop when walking
- Take the elevator if your hands are full

Manufacturing comes first, no matter what.  Everything else is secondary.

job_title: IT Project Manager in Aloha, OR
pros: Frequent opportunities exist for new job experiences.  Some areas are on an automatic rotation schedule (i.e. finance)  Good compensation compared to other options.
cons: Intel tends to not respond to trends until after it is very late and the market demands change.  Intel missed cell phones, tablets and is late in responding to the changes in the PC marketplace.

review_title: Good opportunities for learning, Moving too far into bureaucratic oblivian
pros: Talented people working on complex technologies in a fast-paced environment.  Near continuous opportunities to solve interesting problems.  Ability to work globally.
cons: Near-continuous time demands (poor work-life balance) if working in the production facilities in an exempt/salaried capacity.  Increasing trend toward over-management of metrics and complex/arduous decision making processes.

review_title: Unfair layoffs - new CEO not making the right calls
pros: good work life balance, work culture not the best in NM, good benefits, coworkers very helpful
cons: layoff strategy made no sense- NM is a sinking site with very limited future

review_title: Pretty good, but you are a number
pros: Big-company stability, lots of processes in place (which can be both good and bad), good managers.  Lots of internal classes and seminars to help you grow as a manager or engineer.  Projects well planned out.  Stress level average.
cons: With any big company comes red tape, and there is plenty here.  Glass ceilings.

review_title: Good company undermined by incompetent managers
pros: Work flexibilty and WLE. No time restrictions. Office transport provided. Sometimes interesting work.
cons: Bad managers, especially lower level ones. The don't support employees' careers and don't value your work which can be destructive in the long term. Repetitive work. Salary is average and hikes are very less. More layoffs each coming year. WFH options are being discouraged lately which is a step backwards.

review_title: analog and digital cmos circuit design
pros: You use state of the art VLSI  technology on mixed signal circuitry for  different parts of the chip. Great performance achieved.
cons: So much time invested in work including off-work time and weekends, no time for resting or family. You have to work all day long and weekends.

review_title: It was a good experience to work at Intel
pros: Intel is a great company, plenty of training and coaching. Nice canteen with spectacular meals, fresh fruits and drinks, also have nice bar and bakery. Chance of pay raise according to performance. Great people caring culture, because Intel copy exactly worldwide. Managers listen to people.
cons: Very narrow career path, pay is not competitive enough, compared to local market,  minor pay raise each year. Hardly have chances to relocate and shift position.

review_title: Great company, but could use some help
job_title: Technical Operation Supervisor in Chandler, AZ
pros: Large company with competitive pay and lots of opportunities. Very diverse culture with a responsible moral nature. Fast pace, cutting edge technology around every corner. Good place to learn and refine many different skills.
cons: Employee retention isn't very good, and performance management needs refinement. Most opportunities are for lateral moves, not advancement. There are people who can provide mentorship, but most haven't networked enough to be useful getting you connected to other very large departments.

job_title: Graphics Hardware Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Some really smart people and Graphics is a growing area. So you will learn some good skills
cons: Anchor site is Folsom, which is ridiculous; Lots of politics and old guard that doesnt change the ways and bureaurcy runs the show; senior folks takes credit away fronm younger people all the time.., very less recognition and promotion is based on favoritism

review_title: A big company with a history of highly ethical behavior
pros: A strong company commitment to ethical behavior, especially in regard to diversity, global responsibility, and legal/regulatory compliance. World class user researchers. Access to cutting-edge technology and technologists.
cons: Be aware that it's a large, global corporation, with both the momentum and inertia that implies. 2016 saw a large number of job cuts as the company changes from a personal-computer company to a server, memory, and Internet of Things company.

pros: Smart and focused co-workers.  Good pay benefits.
cons: At will employer, employees must sign agreement that employment can be terminated for no cause.  Can be argued that Intel used this to eliminate positions based on age.  Ranking and Rating system designed to turn co-workers again each other.

job_title: Verification Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: good work-life balance, good for people who need greencard, good healthcare insurance, work isn't demanding
cons: Compensation is about 15% lower compared to some other companies, due to recent series of VSP layoffs many good people left company and there is a feeling that company is lacking skilled people. Unambitious people stayed. Diversity is lacking. Despite Intel continued struggle to have diversity 99% of people are from India.

pros: Good time PTO and decent benefits. Huge company with lots of career avenues if you get into the right team or module.
cons: If you are not promoted within the first three years after hard dedicated work transfer  within the company or look for a new position else were.

pros: You can easily transfer from team to team if you don't like your boss. some bosses are good, and some work is tough.
cons: There are strong political atmosphere.  not good for junior to grow up.  Reorg is normal. one bad thing in Asian countries, policy doesn't allow international relocation inside, except top managers.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Depending on the Business Unit, some are very relaxed and just let you get your work done.
cons: Contractors, regardless of role, and regardless of security clearances, are NOT treated remotely close to full time employees. Intel Corporate does not view contractors the same and displays the attitude that contracts bring a high level of security threat.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Depending on the Business Unit, some are very relaxed and just let you get your work done.
cons: Contractors, regardless of role, and regardless of security clearances, are NOT treated remotely close to full time employees. Intel Corporate does not view contractors the same and displays the attitude that contracts bring a high level of security threat.

review_title: Nice company with some great talent
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in King of Prussia, PA
pros: Salary, benefits, WFH, peers, good for younger workers, they lay off the older workers eventually
cons: Fear of layoffs, consolidation of small sites, some horrible managers, yearly performance appraisal (called a Focal) is the worst I have ever seen in my 30+ year career.

review_title: Onboarding is a long, comfortable on ramp
job_title: Software Development Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: Training recognizes the company is huge and acronym filled.  It makes a very good effort to instill the company culture and give new employees the pointers they need to get started.
cons: The onboarding process specific to the group you join may not be as well documented, especially if the group is smaller with a lot of long term employees.

job_title: Field Sales Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: I have been at Intel for about 12 years and worked my way up from a grade 3 analyst to a senior sales engineer.  It is one of the best companies I have worked for.  They let you decide if you value work life balance or more money, have had good opportunities for growth
cons: Intel needs to attract new young talent, improve compensation in competition markets,

pros: The company has good compensation, great perks if you work at one of the main sites, opportunities to advance are possible. Great on a CV.
cons: It has a very American large corporation vibe. This can get grating. Very aggressive environment, which doesn't suit everyone. Pretty high turnover.

pros: Interesting work at times, Good pay and Facilities (Excluding canteen), work not overly difficult .
cons: Some great people work for the company, but the importance of their role is greatly diminished by the many mediocre employees that are allowed to skate by, by management either because of internal politics or below average leadership capabilities.

pros: Good Name to have on your resume.
cons: There are two types of employees.  Blue Badge and Green Badge.  Blue is where you actually are employed by Intel and Green is where you are a long term contractor.  I've been here three years and still feel like a second class citizen.

job_title: Principal Architect in New York, NY
pros:
1. Interesting Work
2. Seen as Product / Vendor Nutral in IT Ecosystem
3. Overall Compensation Package (Salary, Bonus, Stock Options)
4. Work / Life Balance
5. Professional Development Opportunities
cons:
1. Inability to change and evolve in the post PC-world
2. Senior Management is not very good
3. Extremely engineering / manufacturing centric perspective

review_title: Good, Bad, and Ugly - Working for Intel Corp
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
+ No. 1 CPU company
+ Some of the very bright and best people 
+ Company still making lot of profit
cons:
+ Focal process is worst - Due to which creativity and innovation is lost
+ Too much management overhead and layers
+ Management is non-technical
+ Decision making is very slow
+ No professional and career development
+ Too much non-techincal extra baggage with technical people
+ Too much bureaucracy

pros:
-Relatively fair compensation
-Reasonable in schedule flexibility to accommodate employee occasional personal matters
-Free flow of coffee and soda
-Home to many distinguished technical experts
cons:
-Focus can be too narrow, sometimes engineers do not have a bigger picture of the technology
-No work life balance during crunch time, although that is expected anywhere
-Ratings system fosters too many personal agendas among individuals

job_title: Software Engineer III in Portland, OR
pros:
- Always new opportunity available
- Training available, even advanced degree support
- Large, diverse company
- Everything is results oriented
cons:
- Middle management with little value add
- Long hours can be implied 
- Cube farm work environment
- So many people trying to stand out leads to a lot of politics

pros:
- benefits aren't as good as they were but still good
- bonuses are great
- ability to work from home is  great
- great job skill ehancement opportunities
cons:
- no work-life balance
- unfriendly culture
- focal review methodology pits employees against each other and lowers trust and morale
- if you don't have a good manager, you may find yourself targeted for explusion

review_title: Intel Corp is good to start yoour first job.
pros: You will receive good training when you enter Intel.  You can also learn good methodology for problem solving capabilities.  Many smart people work at Intel.
cons: If you are in manufacturing floor, the work is kind of stressful.  You must be talkative to get known by other people.

review_title: Very good in the beginning, can be painful in some division
pros: Very good if you are a person in highly specialized chip design. They train you very well. You get a great set of people to work with.
cons: Will be difficult for you to move a more generic chip designer. The work-life balance is not very good and can be overworked.

pros:
Excellent health insurance
Free give outs like sports and movie tickets
family friendly management, let me leave for family doctor appointments
not stingy on lunch and smoke breaks
Free fountain drinks all day
cons:
Not alot of paid time off (compared to military)
Adds more responsibilities instead of more people without pay compensation
only one piece of free fruit a day!

job_title: Senior Design Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Co-workers and mgmt are very helpful in sharing information.  Plenty of opportunities to learn new skills and change jobs within the company.  Great energy within the company, and things are generally moving at a fast pace
cons: Growth opportunities for upward movement maybe limited sometimes.  Folks who are in engineering may have a hard-time crossing over to mixed disciplines.  Somewhat slow in tackling the new paradigm shift towards tablets/smartphones

review_title: Great place to work, learned a lot and advanced my career.
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Columbia, SC
pros: Excellent compensation, benefits and work life balance. Working with cutting edge technology is exciting and mentally stimulating.  Makes me glad I chose engineering as a career.
cons: Sometimes the pressure and stress levels get too high. Many times there is more work than people to do it but it still must be accomplished

review_title: Fast-paced, challenging environment.  But in need of a motivating leader.
pros: Work is very interesting, employees are bright and motivated.  Compensation and benefits are outstanding.
cons: The culture has suffered under Paul Otellini, which has led to widespread infighting amongst many business groups.  Intel is desperately in need of a CEO with strong leadership capabilities, who can motivate its employees.

review_title: Overall good, but too much overhead between different organizations. As big company, too much fat
pros:
Company size and stability
offer a lot of career opportunities inside company
more structured and process oriented
cons:
too much organization barriers.(geographic, culture, technology boundaries). Not as competitive as small company when developing new products, esp when breaking into new markets
too much fat and unnecessary teams
less efficiency
bad health benefit

pros: Some of the top technical minds in the industry, lots of hard working motivated coworkers, interesting time to be in this industry
cons: Egos and attitudes matter more than analysis or information. Remarkably poor communication on what is going on - employees are almost always in the dark, especially with rapid (churn) changes to direction

pros: Talented team. You can move to different jobs within the company. Lot of training opportunities. Very high ethical standards. Trying hard to make it a GPTW.
cons: Lot of politics, stifling middle management. Too much focus on removing experienced people, but not the right people. As you work longer here you will be less appreciated. You either move up or get out.

pros: Intel has a great working environment, employees are treated well and the perks are very good. There are many programs to be involved with the community and local area. Work life balance and wellness is always being review and updated. Intel offers great benefits, with many choices to meet your every need. Work schedule is flexible for some and time off is not an issues most of the time. Safety is there highest priority.
cons: Long hours for shift work

review_title: My Experience with Intel has been rewarding as well as Prouctive
pros:
Best WLE benefits, better than market compensation package, lot of employee benefits such as Bus pass for all employees at 0 cost and many more....
Great company for Senior professionals
cons: Learning curve/Job increments as slower than market this can be a issue if you are trying to move between Jobs

review_title: Where do all the years go?
pros: My Sabbatical is coming up and I am very excited about that benefit and the opportunity to refresh and recharge! Intel has many programs that make employees feel loved...
cons: It is such a big company, you can get stuck doing one thing unless you purpose to move out of that particular area. We are not good at hiring and developing our employees.

pros: It's possible for you to have the opportunity to take on more responsibilities if you work at it. Benefits are great, compensation is fair, good company values. Also opportunities to travel internationally.
cons: Like anyplace else, there are good managers, and bad managers. The sheer number of meetings can be mind-numbing. Work/life balance for me was way out of whack, but maybe that was my own inability to say no. You have to be able to push back...often.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel trusts the employees to do their jobs and the company always assumes employees act with integrity until proven otherwise
cons: For some reason, they think it is a good idea to put people into jobs they know nothing aobut and have no skills, training or ability to execute well - i find this to be particulary true in the HR organization - which is frightening

job_title: Portland Technology Development Integration and Module Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Pretty good pay, smart people to work with, and a lot of resources to make things happen.  Things are always changing, so there is a lot to learn, and you don't generally get bored.
cons: Work life balance is not a priority.  The work environment is not very friendly or fun, the culture is very grim and serious. Not a lot of career mobilitiy.

review_title: Great experience in API management domain; Great location; Good base salary.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros:
This is specific to Mashery (An Intel company)
Work life balance 
great location in the midst of market street.
open minded managers (with no micro management)
cons:
Not much performance bonus.
Not much interesting green field dev projects. 
Too much CS cupport

job_title: Platform Applications Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Solid business, guaranteed paycheck, great benefits
cons: The bureaucrats have taken over. It's like a government to get anything done and silos prevail. It doesn't matter if what you do is really important as long as someone up top validates.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Plenty of opportunities to work in various business units to acquire broad spectrum of functional domain knowledge
Great people to work with depending on the group
cons:
Mid management  not capable of identifying and aligning resources to high values projects
Good managers are hard to come by --  some first level managers chosen for diversity not merit
Not nimble -  too slow, lack of transparency

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Plenty of opportunities to work in various business units to acquire broad spectrum of functional domain knowledge
Great people to work with depending on the group
cons:
Mid management  not capable of identifying and aligning resources to high values projects
Good managers are hard to come by --  some first level managers chosen for diversity not merit
Not nimble -  too slow, lack of transparency

job_title: Product Development Engineer in San Jose, San Jose
pros: There are excellent benefits, great work environment with gym,bike and run tracks, a lot opportunities for development overall in any organization.
cons: It has been almost 5 years for me and so far I don't see any cons, the decision I made has payed out and so far so good.

review_title: Good work/life balance; industry is slow/down
job_title: Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good work/life balance (though that depends largely on what group you sit in). Lots of smart folks around, especially long time intel folks with a great amount of institutional knowledge.
cons: Can be slower moving which is to be expected with a company this size. Lots of functional groups so it's often difficult to keep track or stay on top of what adjacent groups are working on, increasing the risk of redundancy or divided voices.

pros: Intel gives back to community, has a strong safety culture, and is very results driven company. There are lots of different jobs so you can do different jobs without having to change employers. And of course the sabbatical that is offered every 7 years!
cons: It is a 24 X 7 global environment so can be very demanding with meetings early in the morning and late in the evening (depending on what part of the organization you are in).

job_title: Engineering Technician in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: They have some great benefits and quarterly bonuses love my coworkers. It's a product that is changing the world. The work was fun and challenging
cons: they are consolidating so some are losing they're jobs and i'm looking for a job myself, I would stay if they weren't moving my lab to Phoenix.

pros: Market Gorilla with tremendous resources; lots of incredibally bright and talented people
cons: Culture under current CEO (BK) is degrading...they're not living up to the values that made the company great in the first place; struggling to find growth...without growth, I expect more layoffs to come; moral is horrible at the moment due to the recent layoffs and how poorly they were executed

review_title: Used to be great, not anymore
pros: One of the most respected (at least, so far...) semiconductor companies. Compensation is on par with others, if not better.
cons: The recent re-org was a complete and utter disaster. Morale is no all-time low. Judging by how this re-org is conducted, new leadership team is barely competent.

pros: I had fun meeting new clients and helping them get in shape.  We got to participate in auburn fest so we we're in a great location
cons: Wasn't much organization going on within the team.  It was times we weren't getting things done like they should have been getting done.

review_title: I'd wait and see how things shake out
pros: Great people to work with and decent pay. Lots of opportunities to find a different job within the company. And free fruit and soda.
cons: Your manager can make or break you. People stayed around while not doing anything for years, and hard workers let go for no reason.

job_title: Engineering Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Good Compensation and many tools to grow.
cons: Too many levels of hierarchy and many many overlapping roles . The rules for advancement and success are more political rather than real. So people spend more time in discussions rather than actual work.

job_title: Engineering Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Good Compensation and many tools to grow.
cons: Too many levels of hierarchy and many many overlapping roles . The rules for advancement and success are more political rather than real. So people spend more time in discussions rather than actual work.

job_title: Financial Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros: The work life balance is great. They are totally cool about people taking time off, or having to leave work early to pick up kids. Family is first.
cons: Many managers at Intel should not have been allowed to become managers. They don't know how to manage people, don't have enough time for you, forget you exist, overwork you, mismanage the distribution of the workload within the team, and don't help with your career development.

pros: Dynamic company with tons of talented individuals from diverse backgrounds
cons: When you top out in your job grade with a high salary, there is no room for further growth.  It is at that time that you are asked to retire and in many cases, train your replacement.

review_title: The company is going through a change. And not in a good way...
pros: Great benefits, ability to switch roles and move within the company. Good people to work with. Flexibility in work hours.
cons: A lot of politics and burocracy. Decisions take months to make. Much less "people first" than it used to be.

job_title: Program Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: My manager is trusting, supportive and doesn't micromanage. It helps that I've built up credibility with him over a couple years.
cons: It is a very large company and it can take a lot of influencing and coordination to complete large projects given the amount of matrixed stakeholders involved.

pros: Intel creates a results oriented environment that is driving innovation globally.  There are opportunities to partner with the business to drive the right financial decisions for the shareholders.
cons: Intel is no longer growing the finance organization and with that, there are limited growth opportunities and the ability to find the right role to match your future goals.

pros: Flexibility - you could work from home, leave early, come late, etc with minimal if any oversight. This changed drastically in the last few months before I left, but it was nice to work for a company where management made room for life.
cons: New leadership dropped the hammer on all the good things, filled manager positions with buddies, and left no opportunity for upward mobility.

pros: The company provided good benefits (i.e. car plan, HMO, medical and dental), good office environment, many activities organized by HR
cons: Management is sometimes not transparent about the status of the company. There is also sometimes a  lack of coordination between departments and managers .

pros: Excellent terms, High level facilities, Really health centered, taking concerns about employee well being, ok paycheck,, good career options and jobs
cons: Big company means you are a small screw, a lot of unnecessary regulations, tech initiatives about systems and such are clunky and destined to fail,  ok paycheck nothing more.

pros: Being 50+ years old company, intel is well established and hence there is stability for employees. Intel have wide opportunities accross different technologies and employees are free to move from one BU to another. Pay is decent and employee satisfaction is high
cons: Little less in salaries than other companies but work-life balance is good. All flows are well developped so very less chance for development work from scrach. Lot of management hierarchies and following process is hectic

review_title: It is an ok job but not great, but it does pay the bills.
job_title: Technical Project Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Experience at Intel looks good on your resume. You will also gain good working experience. Intel is really good about sending you to classes to gain learn and gain further expertise.
cons: It Can be difficult to move up the career ladder. Also, there is too much paperwork that is envolved with the projects and processes.

job_title: Senior Hardware Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
If u are in the right business/Technology group employees are exceptional.
Helps in knowing different cultres as Intel is spread around the world.
If u like to travel Intel has ample oppurtunities.
cons:
Growth path very narrow, difficult to move once u get in a field.
Too many meetings ( which may be necessary) slow u down.

review_title: Intel - good potential if a few problems get addressed.
pros: Compensation and career advancement opportunities. In addition, there are multiple training opportunities, in many different areas, that lead to exceptional personal growth.
cons: Big company leads to a lot of areas of the company being "forgotten". People not int he core areas tend to have less visibility and opportunity.

review_title: Intel is not the excellent employer it used to be
job_title: Human Resources Analyst  in Folsom, CA
pros:
Schedule flexibility
Working with inteligent people
Casual dress / atomosphere
cons:
Cutbacks / headcount reductions without 'work' reductions have left us all doing more and more, with no appreciation or compensation for doing such. 
They tell us we should be happy to have a job
Management is not invested in keeping employees happy

review_title: Why Should you work for Intel
pros:
1. Great place to work
2. Challenging environment
3. Working with the smartest people on the planet
4. Freedom to propose ideas
cons: There is nothing really that makes Intel not a good place to work for. May be one reason would be that there is a lot of competition to cope with

pros: A great place in terms of work-life balance and salary, if you are not working in the main-stream project. The bonuses are good as well, and there is usually not too much pressure (again, off the main-stream)
cons: Not so interesting for a computer scientist though. If you can live with boredom, you should definitely give it a try.

pros: Besides the fact many jobs are outsourced Intel is a great place to work. The benefits and work and life balance needs are met.
cons: At Intel there is constant change. Change and movement are not only internal but many jobs are outsourced. Intel may be very political.

pros: the salary is good and the atmosphere is enthusiastic and competitive. i love to work there with all my colleagues its a great experience.
cons: the downsides are that folsom is a little away from the bay area and somtimes it is tough to maintain good connections with the other people in the industry

review_title: There are a lot of experience levels that i have gained inside the company
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Cairo, Cairo Governorate
pros:
it is a big name that you will be proud of to work over-there.
different aspects of experiences that you can get in the field of embedded systems.
Working in global products that are currently in the market
cons:
Management is still not so good
some undisciplined planes in work

review_title: Good work life balance, best microprocessor company around
pros: Great work life balance, competitive compensation, sabbatical every seven years you get to work on the cutting edge of microprocessor technology.
cons: Very limited growth opportunity, there is a lot of bureaucracy, lots of middle managers who have been around for a long time and have no clue what's going on.

review_title: Good work life balance, best microprocessor company around
pros: Great work life balance, competitive compensation, sabbatical every seven years you get to work on the cutting edge of microprocessor technology.
cons: Very limited growth opportunity, there is a lot of bureaucracy, lots of middle managers who have been around for a long time and have no clue what's going on.
