pros: It is very opened to try all kinds of technology. Hence there will be some job vacancy probably. Jobs can make life easier but you need to work independently and ramp up soon.
cons: Reorganization is usually seen. This may due to the improper evaluation strategy before applying new technology.

pros:
Temporarily a stable job.

Will provide work visa if you need one.

You can get a job if you are completely fresh out of college. In fact this is precisely what Intel prefers. Intel does not like to hire experienced people, and instead prefers to hire inexperienced college grads and pay them the lowest salary the market would allow. This gives Intel the advantage of having young, single, hardworking engineers at very low salaries.

Surprisingly intelligent peers. One of the unfortunate things is that smart engineers graduating from top schools in the country think that Intel is a great company. Intel has a great legacy to talk about. It has a rich legacy and a great history of amazing products and innovation. But that era is long past. Intel is now a middle-aged (it is almost exactly 50 years old now) obese company with a totally crazy CEO. The era of Intel's greatness is over now. Unfortunately, students graduating from universities don't know this. They learn about what amazing things Intel did almost 15 years ago and are awe-struck, and they want to join!

Practically the only major company with a large fab. So if you want a job in the fab, this is one of the companies you could consider. But as such jobs in the fabs are on a slow decline. Remember, automation is key in everything. And Intel's 10nm, 7nm, and 5nm are not really as far ahead of the competition as they claim. In fact the thing Intel senior staff has repeatedly ignored is that time to silicon is as important - if not more - as silicon manufacturing readiness.
cons:
Intel is a slowly dying company. And jobs there are about as stable as the temperature of water in a kettle that is on a low flame. So when you join you will not know at all that the company is dying, but it is slowly dying.

Poor salaries. Actually the "highly paid" Principal Engineers are abysmally paid according to industry standards. Intel HR compares salaries with other companies of "similar nature", but Intel has to grow up and learn that employees do not use that criterion when deciding whether to stay.

Intel does NOT reward additional industry experience or knowledge with appropriate salary difference against fresh graduates. As a result, your salary will NOT be ANY higher than a fresh graduate with zero industry experience, even if you have prior experience in industry.

Stagnant salaries. In fact this is the #1 indicator of a slowly dying company. The smartest of their engineers could get a salary increment of less than $2000 additional, year on year. Their best performing engineers do not get the best salary increments. If you want a good salary increment you better hope that you are some sort of a manager. Intel rewards ONLY, and ONLY managers. In fact, the only individual contributors that might be rewarded are Program Managers.

Practically the only main job growth avenue is to become some sort of a Program Manager or become the supervisor for your team. Yes, Intel does have a technical track for growth. And yes, there are divisions where tech ladder is a serious job growth avenue. But the VAST MAJORITY of Intel jobs can advance to the next level as ONLY a sort of Program Manager (or someone "driving" something tracking its schedule) or at best as the supervisor in your team - a minor promotion. But remember you became a manager ONLY because your boss became a second-level manager. And now there may be additional levels between you and the chain of command. In my view, job growth should be measured in terms of your sphere of influence - how wide is the circle of people you influence. What you'll realize is that while you may technically influence a very large number of people, you will probably never get rewarded for that. And even if your managerial sphere of influence is moderately improved, remember that Intel is an ocean of very smart people, all wanting to grow just like you.

Be ready to be unsatisfied with the salary for years. Your manager will keep showing you a carrot of phenomenal job growth out in the future "if you do this one thing". But that doesn't really matter. They've decided to pay you what they plan to. This carrot is only a fake. When it comes time to actually give the increment you deserve "low budget", "lack of funds" etc., are commonly heard. Intel has the most unscrupulous and the most unfair and dishonest managers of all in the entire industry.

Please be forewarned.

pros: Wages and benefits are good, and they certently know how to run a fab.

review_title: This big company gives you freedom to succeed
job_title: Product Manager in Santa Clara, CA

cons: Too process oriented. Intel needs to break away from its manufacturing processes to succeed in new markets

review_title: NOT a place to grow your career or income.
pros:
Intel's competitive advantage is its ability to deploy a manufacturing technology quickly and in the largest scale possible. Intel's manufacturing technology is cutting edge, but only in commercial deployment. The cutting edge technology is developed not in big corporations but in academia and start ups.
If you are fresh out of college, start your career at Intel to learn about the industry, tools, and commercial technology (usually at the beginning of its decline). Leave no later than 2 years, start your own company or join a start up (you will make more for the hours you put in).
cons:
A typical manager is competent talking to a power point, with very little understanding of or appreciation for the content. He is a good salesman and a sycophant. He gives little thought to the growth of his direct reports (who usually haven't left the team or the company because they are on Employment Visas or the employment market is bad).
If you are looking to gain technical experience/knowledge you will work atleast twice as long as the industry on a project, spend twice as much time in irrelevant meetings.
If you are looking to grow your career vertically, there is little hiring and most managers have decades to o before retirement, translation: very few management positions in the foreseeable future.
If you are looking to broaden your skills (grow horizontally), the hiring managers will not consider your application without "prior relevant experience", translation: most groups operate as silos.
If you are looking to grow your income, follow the stock price INTC (a good portion of the compensation) the last decade (Jan 3rd 2000 to Jan 4th 2010) the stock has fallen more than 50%. The average annual raise in salary in the US has ranged from 0% to 6% during the same period.

review_title: If you are lucky, maybe you could do something better!
pros: good people, good salary pay, nice team work, good management and collaboration. sometimes you maybe have additional bonus, etc. so on....
cons: very few change to get promotion, if you want to stay there over 15 years, maybe you have a little bit change.

pros: Influence on world class technology, great products. Big variety of products - from biomedical chips to chips for supercomputers. Diversity of teams - hardware, software design, chips and packaging. High level of research in some teams.

review_title: Big Company. Big Bureaucracy. Small Advancement.

pros: work life balance ok for the most part, good benefits and exciting high tech field.

review_title: Good pay, horrible work conditions and future prospects
pros: Intel bonuses (if they continue giving them at the same rate) put total comp well above their peers.
cons:
Working conditions are truly abysmal.  They just went to even smaller cubes in Hillsboro (Jones Farm campus).  
Sr. Managers spend 90% of their time trying to manage their hierarchy of reports.  
HR, payroll, and IT are woefully out of date.
Huge bureaucracy and overlapping job responsibilities even after their recent layoffs.
Too many people running around doing nothing, especially those that have been there for more than 10 years.
Middling benefits

job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Very nice and has a lot of nice people, they also make work very fun and you can get some great benefits
cons: I think that i should get payed more money because i stay late work overtime and i don't get to see my family that much

pros: Amazing people who are making a BIG difference in the world!  Competitive compensation and benefits and commitment to flexibility and being a Great Place to Work!
cons: Work many hours and always "on".  You definitely need to be someone who is driven by this type of culture to be successful and happy at Intel.

job_title: Senior Manufacturing Technician in Chandler, AZ
pros: Great pay and benefits. Very exciting cutting edge work. Great training. Great culture.
cons: Like all big companies it's about dollars. When the company is doing well everybody benefits. But when times are tough financially budget cuts and layoffs become the norm. Especially targeted for layoff are those in higher pay grades and close to retirement. If you know this ahead of time and save money and plan it's no big deal.

pros: Cutting edge work, best in class EXOS program (trainers/nutritionist/exercise classes), seems better than average on keeping employees long term, good work life balance if you are on the software side
cons: not an agile company in general, even hiring has a huge overhead. Hardware side of the company is a fine-tuned machine, software side is still rough around the edges

review_title: BAD management and BAD place to work for serious software programmer
pros: Free drinks from coffee machine, free fruits program
cons:
Bad environment for serious software programmer. The company focus too much on the hardware until the software departments do not have proper and healthy software culture. This leads to bad software quality especially the internal tools. Software engineers in my department are mostly under lots of stress getting a half baked product out quickly and then struggle with tons of bugs. And while we are fixing bugs and providing support to the users, the management pushed us to deliver more features or new app/tool. This department is super under resource and sadly the management still want to be even more stingy by expanding the business scope without hiring more engineers.

I worked in the so called "low cost geography", and yet my wages and salary is not even on par with the market value after working in Intel for 3 years. This is a very slow career growth for me. And Intel is not as high tech as everyone think. They give engineers slow laptop, they still using old system and the management are pretty much old school and reluctant to change.

There is this graduate trainee program going on in Malaysia Site. Basically this program is to hire fresh grad with 1 year contract.  Unlike the permanent employee, all the graduate trainee are not entitled for various bonuses such as Quarterly Profit Bonus, Annual Performance Bonus. In my department the management treat the Graduate Trainee even worst. There are times where the department give priority for the permanent staff to have a proper wide screen monitor, while the Graduate Trainee only get to use a square IBM monitor! Graduate trainee also gets older laptop and they are not entitled to claim for broadband and online external training.

review_title: Good company for career growth aspect

You get to work on cutting edge technology. 
Currently Intel is pushing hard to establish a foothold in the 5G modem market as well as AI.
Also I expect Intel's acquisition of Israel's Mobileye is soon going to open huge markets for Intel's wireless technology as well.
cons: There is too much work pressure in some teams like the firmware teams. The work life balance is more oftenly compromised.

pros: Flexibility, strong career development, opportunities for international rotations, good canteen food, free coffee, nice people, rewards hard work and new ideas, good pension and share investment schemes. Free health insurance and gyms. Free Gym classes.
cons: Sometimes a little slow to keep up with the market in terms of basic pay but still stays in top tier.

cons: Due to world competitiveness and lower employee wages  Intel computer chip manufacturing  have relocated overseas in China, Israel and Ireland.

review_title: Amazing benefits and so many career opportunities!

I also have had the opportunity to change careers within Intel.  I've been able to work in the Fab, assembly and test, test software and now Human Resources.  I have been here for 14 years and hope to retire from Intel.
cons: Nothing I can think of!

pros:
- Some of the best minds in the world. 
- Incredible access to resources and opportunities to work with giant manufacturing and supply chain infrastructure.
- There are no lazy people at Intel, just overworked people.
cons:
- Too big. 
- Too many gatekeepers, things take a long time to get done because there are so many involved
- People become averse to risk and become filled with fear 
- Management definitely rules through fear.

cons: The cube environment leaves people feeling lonely even though they are surrounded by people.  Organization of work space is not by functional area, so it was difficult to find anyone else working on the same project.

Secure job compared to other companies which lay off many engineer periodically.

review_title: Work Hard, need to be close to the revenue stream to be appropriately rewarded for that work.
pros: Good flexibility with benefits and balance time agains long work hours.
cons: Advancement opportunities, reward for good performance is inadequate if role is removed from direct revenue impact.

pros: Intel is a great place to work providing a good work lif balance. The people are very talented and the product line is very innovative.
cons: The corporate culture is confrontational and needs some professional attitude adjustment. Else, you will find yourself out of place at Intel.

pros: Great place to work, flat corporate structure (everyone is accessible), decent pay, smart coworkers, company cares about your growth and progress
cons: It's a highly specialized industry (silicon manufacturing), and being the best at what they are, it's really the high point of being in the silicon manufacturing industry.

review_title: Overall I have had a good experience over my 11 years at Intel.
job_title: Senior Technical Marketing Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Taking all 4 weeks of my vacation is never a problem.  Training is encouraged, so you can stay current. Intel has been one of the best companies to work for.
cons: More work than time for family life.  Travel can be a problem in my position.  Getting the equipment needed to do your job needs lots of justifcation.

job_title: Graduate Technical Intern in Folsom, CA
pros: The small group I worked with was a great group of people, doing interesting work.  As an intern, I was happy to see they help you with the learning curve, but still expect you to pick it up and work hard.
cons: Lots of bureaucracy and politics.  Half way through my internship, my group was disbanded and people were moved around with little satisfactory explanation.

review_title: Great place to work on cutting edge products that impact every one
job_title: Senior Verification Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros:
Great place to work
Most cutting edge product development
Opportunity in multiple technologies/desciplines
Good benifits
cons: Longer decision making needs to be fixed which is due to bigger hierarchy

review_title: Fantastic technology company, great culture, great company overall
pros: Always challenging, very smart/competent coworkers, very driven culture, good benefits (including an eight week paid sabbatical every seven years), great management; always feels good working for the company driving Moore's law and exponential growth in technology
cons: Culture can be a little stuffy compared to other tech companies; some areas of the company have too much governance, not enough freedom for teams to do their own thing

review_title: Interesting project, frustrating experience with corporate
pros: There are always interesting projects to work on.  The company has a commitment to diversity and ethical behaviour.  Pressure to work overtime is reasonably low.
cons: Information sharing within the company is remarkably restrictive considering this is a tech company.  The company fosters an unhealthy attitude of internal competition, both between employees and between teams.

review_title: Intel not such a great place to work
pros: will hire you when you are not experienced
cons:
you would probably get stuck in a job you don't really enjoy.
you will have tones of meaningless meetings.
may god help you if you need help from another employee if it is not in their interest they will in the best case ignore you.

job_title: Business Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros: This company provides challenging opportunities, good benefits, and great learning opportunities.
cons: The ranking, rating, review and promotion process reminds me of a shark tank.  It is too competitive.

review_title: Intel really a great place to work for!!!!
pros: Intel did provide free fruits and drink in cafeteria every day, it is kind of healthy lifestyle. There is a lot of sport facilities in the companies also. The working environment is pretty good and the working hours is quite flexible. Intel really a great place to work!
cons: Quite stress when few week before the milestone deadline

job_title: Component Design Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: Intel provides a great environment for technical discussions in and across teams. Provides lot of good training to strengthen your understanding of the field.
cons: You are expected to sometimes unreasonably handle a lot of tasks in parallel by manager. This leads to getting burnt out and lesser productivity.

pros: They have great employee retention. I have known many people there who have worked there for 20-30 years. People literally enter Intel as fresh graduates and work their way up to high management there. Good benefits. Lots of opportunities within the company to change group or move to any other geographical location.
cons: They have fallen a bit behind in the latest tech businesses and need to turn around faster

pros: Great place to work. opportunities to develop your career. Well structured and organised complany with clear roles and responsabilities, good salaries
cons: Meritocracy which could make you feel frustrated depending on the department and manager you work with. Soft skills become in a short period of time more important than technical skills

review_title: Like any large company. Good work/life balance
pros: The CEO is pretty transparent with its employees and has done some interesting strategic moves since he's taken on the role, which has been reflected in the tremendous growth in the stock price.
cons: Like any big company, it's difficult to move fast and execute quickly at this company. It's a components company with a focus on selling chips in PCs and servers. You need to like that.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Helsinki, Southern Finland
pros: My direct boss is the best I've ever had, but that's not thanks to Intel per se.
cons:
Growth thought acquisitions creates sporadic product portfolio and cultural conflicts.
No connection between what executives say and what happens on ground level.
Far too many overlapping functions, no sense of common goals.
Ridiculous organisational change management.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Good strong company, excellent finance talent.  Ability to work on projects that are of enormous scope.  Finance rotates through various business units so you get a wide angle view of various parts of Intel - mfg, sales/marketing, engineering, product groups, etc.
cons: Way too much emphasis on diversity, bordering on enabling URM's unfair advantage in promotion, job oppy, and raises.

pros:
Very flexible working hours and location.
I have worked from home for more than three months!
cons: Very large company, which makes it difficult to progress in your career. specially when you work in a very big group where everyone is competitive. It all depends on the department, it could be one with lots of opportunities and unfortunately it also could be very not stable with a lot of people and limited chances to progress.

pros:
Many teams are doing outstanding projects at Intel India, So great opportunities.
Open culture, your ideas will be heard.
Good Work life balance
cons:
Many teams do not give proper Technical training, thus, sometimes it takes a long time to learn small things.
Synchronization between various teams is less so many time you end up doing duplication of work already exist.

pros: Great benefits, pay, stock, bonuses…. You will work with very high caliber people.
cons: cyclical layoffs, a less then honest upper management about plans, stressful review process, you will miss your child's birthday party for a critical project that will suddenly be canceled the next week….if you are a technical woman, they will pay you much, but don't get how to keep you in typical tech fashion.

job_title: Senior Account Manager in Portland, OR
pros: Competitive, diverse, strong values. Global player in technology markets. I found lots of opportunities to grow from RCG to middle management
cons: Very competitive internally. Forced ranking and rating. Market is tough for PCs and Intel is driving new markets. The focus on server and IoT will make things interesting

pros: Good People and friends...that is what keep me going to work. Learning few things and tried to share with others. community services, helping each others, looking after the new hired until they feel comfortable working on their own.
cons: Management needs to learn how to be transparent and not take sides. The world has changed and not everyone's names in John Smith. Large food chain and only friends survive

review_title: Great place to work, with excellent compensation.
pros: Their compensation package is excellent, and the benefits package is very good as well. Also they offer a paid sabbatical after only 4 years.
cons: It seems the management keeps expecting more and more output with less and less people, although goals are still met, not sure if it's sustainable. Also, news about any layoffs or closures are heard in the media first.

pros: Only hires top talent from top schools in order to keep innovation
cons: Internal FOCAL process is forcing management to identify min 5% population to get penalized, and sometimes excellent performers got hit with business situation changes. Those people are still high quality performers than many other companies.

pros: Flexibility in work hours and ability to work remotely etc. Good benefits. Sabbatical policy is a great benefit. Improved bonding leave policy is a boon.
cons: Extremely political environment. Beauracratic and top heavy. Hiring/firing/promotions are no longer based on meritocracy. Zero accountability in the system. Many people to take credit but very few want to roll up sleeves and get the work done. More focus on processes than outcome.

job_title: Senior Graphics Software Architect in Folsom, CA
pros: Relative job stability, good/competitive compensation, internal opportunities, technical knowledge, access to state of the art technology, blah, blah, blah, etc... blah, blah, blah, etc... blah, blah, blah, etc...
cons: Too much nose browning, politics involved to climb ladder. Yearly performance review (Focal) process is completely broken and fosters internal competition instead of collaboration

job_title: Operations Manager in South Amboy, NJ

Many changes are occurring and going too fast to see what is working and what is not working !

review_title: Intel is a Great Place To Work

review_title: Stable Employment but Very Stale Managers
job_title: Senior S/W Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Stable employment, above average compensation, professional environment.
cons: Disengaged managers who have been in their positions very long term,  very little turnover in front line managers, directors and GMs.

job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
Have been with Intel ~8 years. 

Leading edge technology and lot of learn. Flexible management to allow easy move in different domains. 

Shuttle services (bmtc buss passes given free),
internet access at home,
good travel and reimbursement policies
Good campus,
good quarterly celebrations and year end celebrations
Good cafe (though paid food),
cons:
Need to hire good talent and pay good attention to retention. 
Need to solve traffic problem in front of SRR main gate.

pros: Pay is ok in Portland area but with the sacrifice of your family life. Sabbatical is good if you stayed long enough to actually use it. Insurance and benefits like onsite gyms, eye doctors, dentists, health centers are all positive, again if you get to use them.
cons:
In Portland Technology Development, the biggest problem I've seen is the incompetent top managers. Not that they are technologically incompetent, but becasue the important technological decisions/directions are changed on a weekly basis due to product roadmap change. I feel this company is very product/market oriented. Because of this, an engineer's work for weeks, months or even years, easily goes in vain simply due to the direction change. In the end of the year, no one cares what you have done, the managers only value the outcome and if you have none, regardless it's due to the directions change, you are screwed. It just makes you feel you are cheap and expendable.

An engineer in PTD has minimum chance of career growth. No way to switch to other companies because of the geological location. The skills are also not very transferrable considering all the code names and acronyms. Everything is secret. You can only learn what you need to know. 

Weekend meetings and extra work often ruin your personal life and trip plans. Depending on the manager, you can be called for weekend coverage very often with no compensation day. Favoritism is something that does exist. The exposure to top managers decides how good your Focal is, not the time/effort you spent on your work. So practice your bragging/chit-chat skill if you decide to climb the Intel ladder. Also be sure to spend time on attending every possible meeting than doing the job. Someone will pick it up anyway. Top managers are impressed by talkers much more than doers.

pros:
Reliable work: Even if automation steals your job, they'll retrain you to do another.
Low turnover. 
Great mobility between day and night shift. If you can't work nights, they work with you immediately to get you off them.
cons:
Limited upward mobility, rumored lateral mobility. Staying a tech for two years brands you as a tech and possibly stuck that way.
You will do the same job, repeatedly, for years.

job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: Work-Life Balance, Pay is OK, Sabbaticals, that's about it...
cons: There's increasing feeling of unease from within the company. I've been in multiple organizations across Intel and the last few years have been filled with reorganizations and "shifts in management." It almost feels like there's no one strong at the helm that is willing to make the tough decisions to make progress. IT is in shambles so productivity has hit an all time low with outsourcing abound. We're behind in process technology after being the leader of the pack for so many years, and the gap is growing. We also can't seem to find an industry where we can land a hit on so we acquire hoping to gain market share and then when we fail we sell off at a loss. Culture health within Intel has also hit an all time low. We have many managers that are in high places within the organization that have zero understanding of how to manage, plan, provide vision and lead. They're essentially YES men/women pleasing those above them. Backstabbing is rampant in order to advance in your career or become "visible." If Intel doesn't start making some hard calls and clean the slate of leadership bad apples and fix the culture we're in for a catastrophic next few years.

review_title: A good place for people with donkey/slave mindset - Worse than a mindless IT job
job_title: IP Logic Design Engineer/SOC Design Engineer in Bangalore
pros: you can work from home any day
cons:
I worked in something they call "RTL design/IP logic Design team". Within a week I got to know that the designation is fake. Every body in design teams in Intel India is just maintaining the designs made by Israel or American teams. My work only involved removing errors, cleaning and maintaining their flow. The management is trained to manipulate the employees by frequently lying that whatever they are doing is something they have to be proud about. I was lied before I joined to this team that I will be getting the best work in the world!!! 
As soon as I joined I was given a bunch of linting errors. People who worked in Intel for more years lack skills and are incompetent/useless outside India.People who join Intel after college are either stuck in Intel forever or are forced to go for higher studies. US teams consider indians as slaves and expect them to be always available. There are some very senior people in the team who are so insecure that they will try everything they can to make sure that the junior people will not learn anything so that they can remain important.  Approaching the management is useless as all they can think about money. You will get reminded of the mind set of indians that led to their enslavement by the europeans in the past.

review_title: CEO needs to follow his own policy
job_title: IT Marketing Communications Writer in Sacramento, CA
pros:
It's a Fortune 500 company recognized throughout the world, so people immediately take notice when you say you work/worked there.

Benefits are still better than with smaller companies; vacation and sabbatical plans are particularly well set up.
cons:
Intel no longer places employee happiness or job satisfaction at the top of their list. It's now about the bottom line -- $$$ -- to where people are literally worrying about their jobs from quarter to quarter.

Company uses some devious -- albeit legal -- ways to dump employees: 

Close a facility and let everyone go because their job skills are no longer relevant, instead of providing new training. 

Consolidate nationwide/virtual departments to one campus, and force existing employees to move there (with no relocation reimbursement by company), or have to quit their jobs (and of course, when you quit your job, the separation package is substantially different), or retire. 

Implement a "no rehire" policy on some of the employees who are cut loose, instead of placing them in redeployment pool for consideration when future jobs appear (apparently, this policy has always existed, but was never enforced until last year. However, Intel made the policy enforcement retroactive to your previous year's job performance, meaning you didn't have a chance to correct anything that you may have just found out you were deficient in). 

Make an "all decisions final" edict, meaning no appeal if you're let go for any reason (the benefit of being an "At Will" employer). 

And, coincidentally, manage to primarily lay off (or encourage retirement among) employees with 15+ years of experience at Intel, or who are 50+ years old. There are legitimate, legally endorsed reasons for this, but it still looks bad.

job_title: Financial Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Really great work life balance...almost too laid back for everyone's own good.  Ability to work from home often is great.
cons: Intel is so old and corporate that it does not know how to retain top talent.  They are very strict and really hold the glass ceiling on top of young people.  If you haven't been there for multiple years you don't have a say in anything.

Some great Managers, but most are good technically, but not skilled man managers, in term s of looking out for their employees interests and aspirations.

pros: Intel was a great place to work. Good benefits, great people, flexibility when needed. Proud to work for an industry leader.

pros: Onsite benefits, great colleagues, scope for development. Opportunity to learn about market, business, and operation inside Intel.
cons: Unrealistic expectations, reality differs from claims of employee first, and totally hung up on (lower cost) millennials, weeding out as much of higher cost experience as possible.  Corporate future not entirely clear.  Focal process = religion, but fundamentally flawed.  Good luck.

pros: Some of the best minds in the world work for Intel, giving it a strong/long-term competitive advantage.  Great place to work, flexible work/life balance, great benefits, lots of oppty to grow your career.

pros: Lots of technical problems. Cutting edge technology in the industry. Competitive salary. Great perks. Good benefits. Easy lateral mobility. Flexible

review_title: Good company if you are of the right race

cons: Management is terribly ineffective; a culture of entitled men pervades the atmosphere; certain minorities are seen as a hindrance or dead-weight existing only to satisfy some diversity quota. A minority can have a PhD or be Nobel prize worthy and he/she will still be seen as unworthy.

review_title: Electrical Engineer Validation Testing Qualification Reliability
pros: Opportunity abounds during boom times

pros: Great flexibility with time off.  Sabbaticals and bonding leaves available for newborns.  Good pay  and bonuses.  Good office workspace with ability to work remote when needed.
cons: Too political and not Merit based.  Too many people working there that are just getting by and not passionate to make a difference.  Way too many managers.

review_title: You are lucky if you are a part of Intel
pros: Great work life balance , understanding managers , you get to work on things which interests you,  easy to switch teams or groups with in Intel.
cons: Interns and ICE should be considered and given higher priority while hiring  with in the teams rather than hiring folks from IIT's

pros: Worked on a lot of cool projects with some cool people. Gained a ton of experience in overcoming numerous obstacles. Some folks really cared about getting better each cycle.

review_title: Options at Intel to grow professionally

Options for career development
Flexibility
Environment and other activities to support the local community
Resources for formal education
cons:
Low compensation compared to other companies of the industry of the same or similar sector.

review_title: Worst place with deeply ingrained dishonesty and political BS.
pros:
1)Great Benefits. Excellent health, dental, vision, 401K, and PTO policies.
2)Company's earnings are stable. The company is never short on cash.
3)Cutting edge in many IT technologies. The company is not afraid to spend money on IT projects that delivers business value.
cons:
In my opinion, Intel is one of the most dishonest corporate culture I have ever witnessed. It is also racist, and I don't just mean racism from whites to minorities. Reverse racism (H1B Indians against others) is fairly rampant especially in IT.

The company has deeply ingrained dishonesty in its culture.  If you look at any long term employee who has made at least to middle-management, you can bet they are dishonest and shady. The company, in my opinion, inadvertantly rewards those who lie and hide the truth. There is no straight-talk between senior leadership and the rest. There is no straight talk between the middle-managers to the rest. There is only BS and it is pervasive. Everyone knows this. 

The performance review is almost always a complete farce. Seniority is highly prized and political alliances takes top priority. Those who are outside-looking-in will almost definitely get the shaft, irregardless of their actual performance and capabilities.

That is too bad because Intel has a virtual monopoly on one of the most important products: the chip that drives virtually every computer today.  For over 30 years, Intel has tried to diversity its product portfolio by pouring tens-billions into its R&D and M&A. Today, Intel has virtually nothing to show for those tens of billions invested outside of its single core product. Why? Its culture is rotten, dishonest, racist, and degenerate and doesn't reward\punish its employees properly. 

Intel has been a subject of numerous lawsuits that validates everything I stated above. Again, no one ever says Intel is a culture of straight-talk and honesty...ever.

job_title: Engineering Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Decent benefits, and large company offering some stability if you need to change teams or there is market instability.
cons: Promotions are slow and political. In the current atmosphere promotions are also potentially limited based on your race and gender.

review_title: It is a large company so you have lots of stability because it is well established.
job_title: Physical Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA

review_title: Intel Finance- Great Place to work

pros: Intel is a fairly secure company to work for, sure there's occasional layoffs, but typically if you do your job, you're fine.

pros: Overall a good place to work.  Great city.  Moved away to take another job, however I'd come back in a heartbeat.

Here is the summary of Pros at Intel:

cons:
Here are the Cons of working at Intel:

-  The company is too paranoid about financial performance which starts to be destructive.

review_title: Bad planning, moving developers from project to project without asking their opinion, pressure
pros: Did not find any yet.
cons:
I was hired for one project I was interested in. I was interested in technologies in this project. On my first day I was announced that I will not work for the project I expected. They lied about reasons why I was reassigned. I heard so much lie within two weeks that I stopped trusted any word.
The planning was bad. I had to be in the office at 7am to connect to another team. Early morning conferences and late evening conferences completely ruined my regular life schedule.

pros: Moulds your career with new skill set set and trainings. You can explore, learn and contribute sharing and gathering your knowledge with your peers. And most importantly great compensation with amazing benefits.

review_title: Abandon all hope, ye who enter here
pros: Competitive benefits, though benefits don't mean anything if it is HELL to work there everyday
cons:
Where to start:
-Management:
  • Treats you like garbage
  • Takes all the glory for your good results, give you all the blame for their mistakes
  • Plays mind games with you. Pulls you in with empty complements, has you work hard, and throws you under the bus at a moments notice if there is any indication that they may receive any kind of negative feedback for anything you may have done, based on their VERY poor direction
  • Over all EMOTIONALLY abusive, subversive, and passively aggressive (see the pattern?).
 -Work environment
  • CANNOT TRUST ANYONE - because of the dog eat dog work environment, you have to be a soulless monster in order to achieve any success at the company
  • Do not expect to have any real friendships, do not expect anyone to care who you are, everyone is there to survive, and (for those who have been there for some time) understand that it is survival of the most 'paranoid' - See "Only the Paranoid Survive" by Andy Grove (First Intel CEO)
  • If you like working in a mental and emotional HELL, well, look go further, because you have found it! In the words of Dante (from Inferno) "Abandon all hope, ye who enter here.".
 
Over all results of poor management and terrible work environment (personally speaking):
  • Nervous breakdown
  • Severe clinical* depression (*clinical diagnosis)

Glad to say I now work for a company (TOYOTA) that is the anti-Intel in terms of overall work environment. TOYOTA is a company where I feel truly valued.

So, unless it is a choice between working at intel, and being homeless/living on the streets - Please do yourself a favor and look else where.

review_title: Intel (Data Center Group) is unstable and clueless about its future roadmap for machine learning
pros:
It is a big name company which can look good for your resume. But if you can get to a Tier 1 company like FAAG, don’t bother with Intel. 
You can move between organizations (but do not ever expect a pay raise. The only way to get to a raise is to be a people pleaser and work 80 hours or leave)

There are some really knowledgeable programmers  who know all the tricks to squeeze every ounce of performance out of a CPU.
cons:
Data science / machine learning specific comments:
Intel has little vision for machine learning and artificial intelligence. It does not align with market expectations. It also does not want to solve current pain points of big data which sorely needs easy parallelization solutions and easy engineering tools. Most of the managers and executives are old: they don’t want to innovate either from a hardware nor a software standpoint, but to reuse old business models that “worked”. They keep using deep learning benchmarks for computer vision that show their inferior performance to GPUs when there are NLP benchmarks that CPUs are better at than GPUs. And they just don’t even bother to hire people who know how to write machine learning benchmarks that showcase their products in a better light. 

They have trouble attracting good machine learning talents and the imposters scare the real talents away. 
I see “data scientists” and “machine learning researchers” at Intel who are actually programmers who took a few Coursera courses with a random (CS) degree. They think by running a few online tutorials, they KNOW machine learning and data science. 

Software at Intel is considered as non essential as hardware is the bread and butter. It speaks a lot for the (lower perceived) status of the software developers or data scientists at Intel. More importantly, if you are a software developer, expect that boosting hardware benchmarks to be your sole mission. 

Culture wise:
The Data Center Group, despite being the growth engine, is beaten up by NVIDIA and has low moral. There are constant reorganizations, hiring freezes and firing rounds because the executives need to act like they are doing things. It cannot attract talent as it pays peanuts compared to top tier tech companies and act arrogantly like it is a top tier software tech company.
I saw teams and teams of developers of promising software products (eg Apache spark and Hadoop) got gutted just when they start to get results.

Also a lot of the devs do not know nor use modern software engineering practices like version control nor software testing for work. If you use something more up to date you will get marginalized. (Forget about teamwork).

There is also little to no accountability for projects. They don’t care if a job is done well they only want you to say you have worked on certain shiny technology.


HR experience: 
They have terrible hiring procedure and HR people have terrible attitude. The HR pits teams against one another to fight for talent and they complain to each other afterwards. The HR person also had the worst attitude for salary negotiation as if s/he does not expect a negotiation. 

The clerical staff was overworked by all the managers for supplies and paperwork and was discontinued because s/he was on a contract and it expired.

review_title: Not the Intel that it used to be
job_title: Process Engineer in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: You get to work with a lot of very smart people.
cons:
The environment in Intel is tough. Many companies have training programs for new employees, but training runs counter to Intel's culture. If you are new and trying to figure things out, no one will help you. You are expected to learn everything by yourself. Intel also has a habit of taking H1-B visa students who recently graduated and overworking them as much as possible. If you are a new graduate, do not come to Intel. There are much better companies.

As a process engineer, work/life balance is non-existent. Process Engineers are on-call 24 hours per day, and it is very common to receive phone calls at 3 am. Intel refuses to hire shift engineers. The Rio Rancho plant is also being downsized, and 10% of the work force will be laid off in the fall of 2013. 

Intel claims that it has a 2 year lead on its competitors, but that's a lie. If Intel had a 2 year lead, why would they need to lay off 10% of their work force in Rio Rancho? If they had a 2 year lead, why are their chip sales 5% lower in 2013 compared to 2012? The reality is that Samsung and TSMC are dominating Intel in the cell phone and tablet markets. Intel has focused too much on laptops and PCs, and they have ignored cell phones and tablets. Now, Intel is 10 years behind in cell phones and tablets, and they refuse to consider new ideas, such as licensing their designs to third parties or making chips that aren't based on x86 architecture.

If you are considering working at Intel, pay attention to what is happening right now. Intel does not have a realistic 10 year plan. I would not be surprised if Intel lays off more people within 10 years. Intel is shrinking, not growing. Intel is simply not adapting to changes fast enough, and upper management refuses to consider making changes to Intel's business philosophy.

review_title: The Internet Has Left Intel Behind
pros: Strong earnings in microchips and memory.  Strong benefits package.  Gatherings every month to get office workers together.
cons:
Intel does engineering at the pace of a snail.  Their "agile" teams are slower than your average waterfall team.  The culture is driven by pointless and generic Power Point slides.  This is not a joke.  Even the developers and engineers are writing Power Point slides.  There is no ownership in the company.  Everyone blames other people and teams for problems and no one ever says, "I own this problem.  I will solve it." which leads to nothing getting done.  For example in the whole time I was there they never fixed the issue of getting Macs onto their network.   You can "connect" but then you can't get to critical resources like...the Internet.  Or if you can get to the Internet then you can't connect to company web pages that are optimized for IE 7.  That's not a joke either.  It's not a complaint because as an Intel employee you get used to things being slow and not working right.  I just offer it as a tangible example.

If you have ANY talent at all stay away from this company.  If you are marginal in talent then jump right in. By the way enjoy the on-boarding process.  It is from 1990 and drives everyone nuts but no one ever fixes it.  Again, no ownership here.

job_title: Senior Hardware Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Reasonable compensation; plus "panem et circenses" including free fruit and soft drinks, free movie tickets once a quarter or so.
cons:
Intel was once a great company, managed by great men such as Robert Noyce and Andy Grove (who was the CEO when I started work at Intel).  As the years have gone by, the leadership of the CEOs (and, inevitably, the management chain under them) has steadily degraded to what seems like rock bottom with the current CEO, Brian Krzanich.  BK, as he is affectionately (?) known, is in way over his head, and seems to be running the company more as a social justice platform than as a business.   Failed decision follows failed decision, each accompanied by multi-billion dollar losses.  But what does this mean to the average employee?  Nothing good:  intent on making up for lost profits through cost cutting, the company has decided that loyalty to employees is a thing of the past.  They are working to transfer all jobs to the lowest bidder by replacing US jobs with overseas jobs, and experienced workers with new hires.  To accomplish this, they are laying off (or encouraging the defection of) tens of thousands of their best and most experienced people.  This is cratering employee morale, and leaving behind more work for less people.  Trust me, you don't want to be one of those 'left behind', nor do you want to begin your career with a company that will start you off you in such an environment. 
Workplace accommodations have been dropping for years - employees are expected to empty their own trash, accept smaller cubicles every year, and overcrowded buildings make it tough to even find a conference room.  
Benefits have been dropping for years - at one time Intel hired the best and brightest, and strived for first-in-class pay and benefits.  Now they look for employees who are merely 'qualified', and continuously decrease benefits (such as retirement benefits), shooting for compensation that 'is in line with peer averages'.
If you're a low to mediocre performer, Intel may be the place for you.  For the best and brightest, you would be better off looking elsewhere.

review_title: Not a Great Place to Work
pros: Intel has very competitive pay and benefits.  It's how they retain their employees in the slave like environment.
cons:
Intel is a military type of culture.  Employees compete with each other as part of the "ranking and rating system" that is closely enforced by Intel HR, and is pleasant neither for the employees nor the managers.  This encourages a company culture of secrecy, competition rather than collaboration, and an overall atmosphere of fear and bad morale.  Especially with the recent round of layoffs, morale is really bad.  Employees feel like they have to compete with each other to each the "Outstanding" and "Exceeds" ratings, which can be 10% of the employee population on any given year, otherwise they may be at risk for being laid off.

I was part of the recent layoffs in April.  I was sat down in a meeting with my manager and HR, told I was being laid off, told I had a few hours to get any personal files off of my company laptop, and was not allowed to go back to my desk to collect my personal things.  After 20+ years of service, that is how Intel Corporation treats employees.  Not what I call a "Great Place to Work".  The pay is competitive, but the price is your sanity.

review_title: It's a TOUGH company to work for.
pros: Intel seems to have a decent compensation package, there is a lot of opportunity within the company for younger recent college graduates,
cons: Tough company culture to deal with; continuous offshoring and job relocations; higher level management is disconnected from the reality within the company; senior leaders protect their buddies.

job_title: Software Engineer III in Hillsboro, OR
pros: I cannot think of any positives except for the fact that there was a really great cafeteria with good burgers and a pretty good salad bar. My contract ended prematurely for which I was ecstatically  grateful.
cons:
My contract ended prematurely for which I was ecstatically grateful. I felt sort of like a POW finally being released released from the Hanoi Hilton.
The building, all of it, was kept uncomfortably cold
The bathroom sinks were unable to provide any warm/hot water
The Senior/Lead to whom I reported was so autocratic and such a critical parent that I finally began referring to her as "Ivan the Terrible"
The work environment was sickeningly political
My co-workers were either hot or cold. Very friendly to work with or extremely negative. One co-worker actually had a disclaimer on his email signature which read (paraphrase), "I apologize for being extremely difficult and negative to work with. It is because of my long term employment with Intel". News Flash: If you aren't trying to fix it then it isn't an apology.
The work environment was so stressful for me that I finally began barfing 2 - 4 times a week.
The Test Fixtures with which I worked were constantly being altered by other people with no notes indicating what had been done. Thus, almost every day I had to get the lab manager to help me troubleshoot the darn things. This inevitably led to "Ivan the Terrible" browbeating me for taking too much time.
There was NO "How To" documentation regarding procedures and processes. It was ALL tribal knowledge and you really had to know what question to ask in order to "fill in the blanks".
Contractors are only allowed to work when "real" employees are present. Hence, contractors, me specifically, had no avenue to make up hours. This REALLY hurt over the Christmas and New Year weekend where I lost a total of 32 hours of pay.
My work hours were mandated as 7:00 AM to 4:00 PM. Nine hours because I was required to take a one hour lunch break.
Contractors, at least for me, were made to feel unwelcome and NEVER a part of the team. I was pretty much treated like n inconvenient piece of meat.
I had, at one time, vowed to never work at Intel due to their penchant for laying of a few thousand employees and then replacing them with Contractors. For me that is dishonest and unethical. I took this contract against my better judgement because I was unemployed and dying of "Cabin Fever".
This was by far the most damaging contract I have ever worked, both psychologically and physically.

pros: Supports innovation a great place for young recent college graduates to get their feet wet. I would take advantage of the experience and then look for opportunities at other companies.
cons: Recent top level management shifts have removed the founder's protections against arbitrary management decisions, making it easy to summarily dismiss someone without cause. Recent "house cleaning" has been very byzantine. A lot of very exceptional people dismissed surprisingly.

pros: Good pay and benefits, large cafe with many options for all meals, lots of time off.
cons:
Recent college grads have too much power to make big mistakes and get so many chances to continue to make bad decisions.
It amazes me that young, recent college grads get more power to make horrible mistakes than do the seasoned veterans who have decades more experience.
There is HUGE divisiveness between co-workers due to this fact.  
I'e worked in 4 groups and no one even likes one another. The team builders often times fail because no one wants to see those they work with 12-hours per day after work.
There's a department called the Great Place to Work department that puts together lame things for folks to feel like they're important but they are simply ridiculous ways of saying "we're trying" rather than make real changes to end the divisive between co-workers.
there is no trust and it's rare to find someone who is truly trying because they so often get doors slammed in their face.
The large cafe I mentioned earlier is large indeed with lots of choices. The food typically is horrible and they completely over charge.
Lots of time off is followed by a horrible 12-hour, ball-busting shift....and they continue to cut resources so everyone remaining has to work even harder.
Quite the sweat shop inside the fab.
The CEO said in a video he wants to begin hiring more folks from other cultures because he thinks white males have enjoyed too many years of privilege.
Morale is worse than I've ever seen in my 30-year career in the semiconductor industry.

review_title: From the point of view of Software Engineer (Contract)
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros:
Nice cafeteria and great food
Organized
Great d.space room with cool gadgets and resting area
cons:
Let me start by sharing demographics. 
70% Indian, 29% Chinese , 1% Everyone Else
98% Male, 2%Female

As a contractor you  a basically treated as 2nd class citizen . For example you must pay for each cup of coffee u consume (1.89$), you not allowed to drive bicycles, sick time off or any personal time off at all and referred to as "green badge".  From the very beginning  things were rather odd.  When I started , i was left alone for about a week. No introductions to team members, no lunch , nothing. Out of boredom i wrote a 20 proposal with visuals and backing stats how to improve the software i was assigned to. Well it was completely ignored , not even response to email acknowledging its existence. Indian manager kept polite , but very distant and dint wanna hear nothing about innovations or at least upgrading .net 4.0 to something more fresh. Oh well, ok fine.  They dont use  async , solid or design patterns. The code is working , well kinda -  if you careful about clicks u good. They dont engage in technical discussions, code reviews or any kind active knowledge sharing. Tools such as Resharper ,  only out of you own pocket. Also had to bring my personal headphones and mic for conf calls. The work hours, and lunch time very strict and always had to start and finish day at the minutes precision. I was getting tired of paying for coffee and asked if i could bring my own coffee make. Nope. Long story short the place felt like prison. I cant say if all teams are like that, but mine was.  If you are contractor : run .

cons: Constant "headcount reductions" and shaky future visions made for a stressful environment. Compensation was slightly below average compared to other companies for this position.

job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Bangalore
pros: intel is my first job since i passed out from my graduation.   I am very happy to be with team intel.  I work at graphics hardware engineer.  The open policy of intel is good.  Intel also give free to innovate.
cons: company is driven politically rather than performance of individual.

pros:
Flexible work environment
Smart and Friendly people
Decent Packages
Plenty of budget to try ideas
Good opportunities to work with other partners and companies
cons:
Pays based on seniority and not ability
Bureaucratic decision making process
Some management have been there for 20+ years
Quite an old demographic

pros:
Competitive benefits. Sabbatical as well!
Lot of good projects to work on that use and exploit x86 architecture instruction set. Talented group of engineers to work with
cons: Transition from PC centric to IOT, Data Center domains creating layoffs and one needs a lot of patience to ride it off for the next few years

review_title: Employees, customers and products don't matter
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: It's very hard for me to come up with anything nice to say about Intel. It's the worst place I've ever worked.
cons: Intel is always looking for new ways to cut costs. There's a constant push to move jobs to China and India. Projects don't finish. Deadlines are always blown. There's a culture of overpromising and underdelivering. Employees who challenge it are not deemed team players. Employees who blow deadlines and overpromise are promoted.

job_title: Validation Engineering Technician in Portland, OR
pros: good wages but slow to advance.
cons: Their employee retention policy is poor

pros:
Opportunity to work on latest wireless systems
Competitive work environment
Intel promotes diversity
Strong focus on ethics
Strong people focus and work/life balance
Performers are rewarded very well
cons:
Highly vertical functions with little collaboration, prevents cross functional opportunities
Re-organization every quarter, employee careers go for toss due to change of managers
Frequent produce road-map changes, confuses employees on company direction

pros:
Get to work on cutting edge technology with the sharpest of minds.
Extremely helpful people, with a lot of growth options
cons: Depends from team to team, but some roles might not unleash your full potential, need to keep a self check that one is improving over time.

pros: Challenging technical environment, smart peers, lots of problems to solve that are advanced in nature, professional organization, close to home, affordable housing close by.
cons: Political, promotions done behind closed doors, not a good place if you are looking for career advancement, lots of back stabbing. Highly clueless management in recent years. Long hours, long weekends.

review_title: Stable company with good work-life balance
pros: Work-life balance is great. Workloads typically do not overflow into the weekends, except a couple times a year during a critical project milestone.
cons: The cross-site work model can be quite demanding at times, especially when meetings are held late at night and early in the morning.

pros: Good salary. Good benefits. Eight week sabbatical every 7 years of employment. Free fruit, soda, coffee, and tea. Stock purchase program.
cons: Some of the criteria used for selecting people for voluntary and involuntary layoffs has caught some people by surprise. People are left wondering if the criteria will change in a way that makes them a future candidate for layoff. Work environment growing uncomfortable.

pros: Smart people and is a great place to work.  Pay seems to be higher than other comparable employers in the area.
cons: Layoffs in 2016 affected everyone in the company.  6 months later and it is still a challenging environment with the worry of more layoffs coming.

pros: Great place to work, farily transparent biz processes, diverse projects portfolio, good benefits, great stock sharing program
cons: certain functions (which could be globalized) are very much kept in specific locations only

job_title: Staff Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Pay is good and opportunity to work with some of the brightest minds is awesome!  Also working on the latest technology is fun.
cons: Politics with management since ACT has gotten out of control.  It is starting to impact our ability to get things done.

job_title: Senior Hardware Design Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Great technology to work on, we were always working on a class-leading chip technology with almost every project.
cons: Not very open to design experience from outside Intel, a 'not invented here' attitude is there.  Lots of management overhead, not unusual to have multiple managers to report to on a project.  Unfair layoff guidelines that are now causing tension for the remaining workers at Intel

pros: Intel is a good company to work for due to the good company culture, decent salary and benefit. People at Intel are in general nice and efficient.
cons: Some of the managers can not treat the employees with respect. Their talk in certain rude way, which is really annoying. As a return, it reduces the employees' productivity.

pros: Great team, great pay, great learning experience! Top notch technical company.
cons: A bit of a sweat shop and there are many "re-deployments" which is like a layoff but you get a chance to find another job in the company first. Also you tend to have a different manager at least once a year.

pros: Small team. Actively engaged in deployment efforts. One on ones with executives. Distributed team with chance to work from home.
cons: Just launched. Limited benefits. Hard to set long term strategy since the direction of the market is unclear at this time.

review_title: Upper management doesn't have a direction.. very reactionary company. Good engineers work there
job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer Grade 6 in Austin, TX
pros: Good work life balance, lots of stuff to work on usually. Lots of smart and helpful people working at the individual level
cons: Poor communication from upper management.  They have also started to nickel and dime, don't even have a trash can at my already tiny cube.

pros: Good work life balance, good health benefits and decent 401k match
cons: Low salary for bay area standards, people who you work with are either very good (they like their job, some of the best in their area and loves Intel) or are bad (they cannot get a job elsewhere, and stick with Intel).  Slowly, the former category of people are either retiring or leaving Intel.

pros:
Good compensation and benefits package
Right means to progress in your work
Relaxed environment
cons:
Technical priorities change as often as the weather
No clear roadmap defined and therefore objectives are never clearly understood (you need to define your own)
Human Ressources? Personal Development? really forget it if you don't work in the US

job_title: Software Development Engineer in Nizhniy Novgorod
pros: Big (a lot of horizontal opportunities within the company), stable, low entrance thresholds.
cons: A lot of bureaucracy, impossibility to get promotions more frequently than once a year, strict constraints on the number of promoted people and it doesn't depend on your actual contribution, but on the amount of time you spent in Intel.

job_title: Graphics Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Work life balance You can find few great people to work with you get sabbatical which is great u get 2 months after 7 years
cons: Bad management bad managers too much politics less compensation there is little room for growth some managers do a lot of micro managing

review_title: Great Company with lots of History
pros: Company has lots of innovations in Silicon and Software development in various projects. Great engineers working who are spread world-wide.
cons: Not fast paced. Takes a lot of time for teams to accept new changes compared to industry. [Tool usage, infrastructure]. Lot of re-org due to changing management strategies.

review_title: Used to be a great company
job_title: Systems Analyst in San Jose, San Jose
pros: Flexibility, on site options, bonuses and SPO
cons:
Management, cost savings mentality, changes on the stock plan.

Terrible management

pros: Great pay, benefits, PTO and flexibility to go to school and learn new skills.  Amazing ESPP and 401k plan.
cons: Extremely resistant to change and fear driven workplace. Older workers are constantly feeling threatened and they threaten the newer employees that are trying to learn and grow.

job_title: Manufacturing Technician in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Great Benefits
Good Pay
Stable Company
Tuition Reimbursment
Profit Sharing
Employee Discounts
cons:
Depending on the department you are in. 
Hard to move up
Promotions and raises are not based on knowledge or hard work, but instead whatever your manager finds of value.
There is no rhyme or reason to their staffing model.

review_title: Very good company to work for.
pros:
Excellent work/life balance
Decent compensation
Excellent health and retirement benefits
Sabbatical (additional 8 weeks every 7 years)
4 weeks vacation (after 10 yrs). 3 weeks otherwise
cons:
Growth opportunities hard to come by. 
Annual salary hikes could fluctuate depending on economic conditions.
Management sometimes could be political.
Bureaucracy

pros: Great place to work. Flexible hours and task oriented. Challenging work that you will enjoy working on. You will have satisfaction that you are making an impact. Teaches you how to handle multiple projects at a time.
cons: None. Based on time spent.

review_title: Steep curve in the beginning, flattens after 2 years
pros:
Good brand name among technical community
Good work/life balance (depending on the team you join)
Easy going colleagues (again depending on the team you join)
cons:
Peanut salary
Underwater stocks
Little opportunity to try out different roles
Few opportunity for job rotation
Tough annual appraisal process

pros: Plenty of online resources, unlimited subscriptions to help you get information for your work. Industry tools and practices visible. Fun to play with the tools.
cons: Working with sub-par Penang employees. They come off with a superiority complex but sounding shallow. Have obvious limited knowledge of practices outside of Intel, even if it is in comparison to their domain of expertise.

review_title: One of the best run companies I've worked for
pros: CEO and senior leadership team are excellent with good vision.  Good compensation and benefits but make your best deal going in.  Comp levels are rarely addressed for changes in market place.
cons: Management team below senior levels needs development.  Legacy issues keep the company from being as agressive as it could be.

review_title: Dynamic environment, constant pressure, too much attention on trivial issues.
pros: The brand is huge, vast possibilities to learn and share technical and non-technical knowledge, access to cutting edge facilities, constant interaction with skilled workforce.
cons: Sometimes trivial issues are given too much importance and become roadblocks preventing from analyzing and finding the real root causes of the problems. Procedures and bureaucracy are often overwhelming and frustrating.

review_title: Quite often Intel and it's managers/leaders treat employees as commodities.
pros: Overall employees are good and care, but take it from leadership due to the decent wages and benefits in tight markets. People are committed, give alot of themselves, push for excellence.
cons: Crisis mode at all times often due to poor planning and vision. Reactive. Not open to developing it's people, just execute for results. Innovation is down.

pros: Great place to work -- pretty flexible, family friendly, not high pressure, stable, etc etc etc etc etc etc etc
cons: crowded place, cafe is often occupied, small cube, managments like to make employees restricted in certain areas, no intention to grow employee

job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: The brand , the value it adds , the work I do, the firmware I write, and how it changes computing all are Pros. Our team meetings involve strategies to re-invent our-self, how to beat competition, and this gives a big high to develop the next world beater
cons: Growth sometimes could get hindered by internal politics...

review_title: California PhD turned night shift drone in Arizona
pros:
excellent pay.
interesting work
amazing automation
neat fringe benefits 
people from everywhere with interesting backgrounds
feeling of building the tower of Babel
cons:
long hours and strange hours
hostile environment (dominated by ex-military)
constant change and constant competition consciously controlled
feeling of building the tower of Babel

review_title: employees are treated well, nice people but salary depends upon group
pros: Employees are treated with respect and trust. Good work environment and office too. You get opportunity to grow but you have to identify it. Good office facilities.
cons:
Salary depends upon group. So while selecting the job need to see.
Microprocessor group generally don't pay well.

pros: Less politics, One of the most ethical company. Intel hire honest people and trust their employees. there is no website barred, no time sheet, no swap in / out system.
cons: Manager is extremely powerful. He can make or break your career. Performance measurement is based on perceptions. Lot of processes which makes everything complicated in Intel.

review_title: Overall I am satisfied with the company though the growth in the company takes a longer time.
pros: work life effectiveness and benefits are very good if not the best in the industry.
cons: Career growth is very slow and takes a very long time to reach management positions such asFor example to become a project manager it takes about average of 5-7 years. This is a very long time.

pros: @ Intel , I found good people and work culture is very nice. Heaven for people who have skills related to core business of Intel. people from other skills will find this place to work for larger number of years. minimum at least 5 yrs.
cons: > Tough to move around different Intel offices across world.

pros: Pay, RSUs, stock options, 401k, stock purchase plan. Working on leading edge IC technologies. Training allowance. Exercise facilities on campus. Opportunity to move around.
cons: Projects are frequently cancelled despite achieving objectives. Re-deployment. Many long hours due to poor program management. Politics of rank and rate. Difficulty of getting to Principal engineer level.

review_title: I often wonder how companies with such poor corporate culture can be so successful. I saw a lot of unhappiness there.
job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Salary is good. Equipment needs are generally met. Most people working there were OK.  The work presented few surprises.
cons: Corporate environment sucks. My group would meet endlessly and never reach a plan or consensus. Meeting which should have never taken place at all (or could have been conducted in under of an hour) would last endlessly.

review_title: I am Analog Engineer @ Intel Corp since 2011. As a new-hire, I got good exposure to the project flow.
job_title: Analog Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
1. More responsibilities --> varied scope for learning
2. Great development opportunity
cons:
1. Planning and execution could be better
2. Lots of time wasted in debugging tool issues, not adequate DA support

review_title: Intel is a great place to work
pros: Intel develops your skill set with many useful classes and refresh classes every year. The people here are always helpful eventhough they may not work with you. The pay is great!
cons: Intel is a very process oriented company. Eventhough they encourage you to think outside the box and be innovative, at times, this becomes hard to achieve with current process.

pros: Job Security and Work-life balance.  There is a good sense of work life balance within the company and generally you can work out your needs with your manager. Also Job security with the company is good, it is a good company to retire from and you have a sabatical ever 7 years.
cons: The yearly review process may not reflect the amount of work you did.

job_title: R&D Test Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: will work with very talented individuals and cutting edge technology.  will work with large, cross-functional teams.
cons: evening and weekend work is expected.  flex time is supported, but often not practical with other demands.  don't think I ever used all of my vacation days in a year and they are not rolled over.

pros: The working environment is quite nice. The team I worked in is like a big family. People there are hard-working. And they are patient when you ask them questions. It was a valuable experience for me.
cons: As far as I know, the corporation is good. But some department in it doesn't accept international applicants. That may depress some applicants from other countries.

review_title: Engineers are given what they need.
pros: Compensation is good. I think each department is different. My environment was supportive. Training and development is good.
cons: Because it's a big company, engineers have some choices to make about which department or product they want to be a part of. This leads to some jostling when things get reorganized.

review_title: Terrific place to join strategic thinkging and doing and management!
pros: Intel is the center of so many universes, working here was akin to helping so many people the world over in their  everyday lives!
cons: At time, too management heavy, with time spent at meetings more than doing one's work.

pros: I believe that to be productive you should really love your job and be happy. That is what Intel was for me.I totally felt the company and it was such a pleasure to work with INTEL and its employees. All the people were very warm and they keep you motivated through some activities.
cons: I haven't seen a downside during my work experience

pros: It's been a pretty solid place to work for over the time I have been here.
cons: Some expectations and standards can be unreasonable. It used to be a better place to work when I started. The size and bureaucracy is comparable to the Federal Government.

pros: Flexibility, stability, corporate services, vacation time, sabbatical, family atmosphere (depends on group you work for)
cons: Monotonous jobs, fickle management, low travel budgets, low stock grants, complacent upper management, too much management, no headroom for growth

pros: Flexibility, stability, corporate services, vacation time, sabbatical, family atmosphere (depends on group you work for)
cons: Monotonous jobs, fickle management, low travel budgets, low stock grants, complacent upper management, too much management, no headroom for growth

pros: Intel is a solid company to work for. Intel have had the history and the vision for the future which makes it the best place to work for
cons: As a big company you do not have the opportunity to progress your career as you wish to

pros: great benefits, probably close to the best i have seen in this day and age. pay is good too and vacation time off.
cons: managers are technical and not people based. some of the worst managers in the business i have come across, think they are great because they have a manager label. HR is toothless.

review_title: Great, unless you are unlucky enough to land in a bad project
pros: Smart people, disciplined processes, good compensation and excellent benefits.
cons: If you land in a project with a bad manager or with no direction, you can end up spinning your wheels furiously and getting nowhere.

pros: good culture, good people. Decent benefits and the ability rotate every 2 years is a nice change of pace
cons: you can be overworked pretty easily. work can become tedious at times. nothing else to report

job_title: Senior Sales & Marketing Group Manager in Maricopa, AZ

cons: Corporate culture is at odds with actions.  Goal is to convince the world of PC stance on everything but actions speak louder than words.  Ethical focus is lacking, management is from the 18th century

pros:
Intel is one of the best place to work.

earnings, stocks, bonuses etc are all very very good
cons: You need to really think harder to find cons at Intel.  Sorry I dont have any except internal politcs, but even that natural when there are humans.

Meritocracy

pros: Great pay and benefits are included.

pros: You are surrounded by some of the most intelligent people anywhere, and you get to work with the most advanced technology in the world! You also have the freedom to chart your own career path. Management is fairly accessible due to open door policy.

review_title: Great work environment, but company lacks cohesive strategy for growth

review_title: I'm an experiance RF engineer, currently Validation domain

Intel is known as a good place to work in. It a place that you can create, express yourself and make an influence so product can be optimized to be the best quality possible.
In Intel you can take your professional level higher.

review_title: Mostly ordinary work unless you are in specific group

Benefits. Connections. Resume.

review_title: It's a good place to work
