Intel is very advanced in process and circuit technology - so it's fun to learn and contribute at the same time.
Melting pot - you meet so many people from different countries.
cons: Intel is a very big company and sometimes it is hard to understand why we are so solid but it is an advantage at the same time - or?

pros: It is a big company and stable. there is chance to learn more related work compared with other places. Pay is not bad
cons: work load normally is heavy. There are too many politics. Spend too many time on arguing rather than doing work.

review_title: Great place to work but underpaid
pros: It´s a great place to work, with a peaceful environment and good compensations including good vacations days quantity from the start.
cons: The main issue are the salaries, they are under the average. Some of the management couple are incompent. You get a raise or promotion by selling a bag of smok rather than hard work.

review_title: Great place to work if you find the right manager

If technology tickles you, you won't be bored
Compensation above average
Good work-life balance
cons:
Some jobs discourage creativity
Some sites have bad management (not all sites) - choose carefully where you choose to work.

review_title: A great operational company if a little lacking in free thinkers

In general a well oiled machine with honed processes for everything from HR to operations

Anything not related to microprocessors is a second class citizen

review_title: good employer if you just want a stable job at a much lower salary
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Austin, TX
pros:
#1 semiconductor company
comparatively longer project durations hence somewhat relaxed work environment
stable job if you work in big group
mostly good work-life balance unless you don't get along with your manager

bonuses were at industry median.. now going down

review_title: Not a great company to work at.
pros: Clean, Certain techs do very good work.
cons: Green Badges "Temps" or "Contingent Workers" are shut out of any and all Intel parties/programs/events. As a veteran I tried to attend their veteran event and was turned away because my badge wasn't blue. The Actual workers for Intel "Blue Badges" talk down on green badges.  EXTREMELY one sided racial ratio. Nobody speaks English unless they have to. Very poor security, people walk out with items in their purse/luggage all the time.

review_title: A great place to start  your career
pros: A great technology company with lot of smart and dedicated folks.   Has huge resources to throw at a problem when decides to focus on something.
cons:
Very, very slow moving company.   Very cumbersome decision making process.
Majority of senior technical talent is wasted as they are mostly doing stakeholder management instead of focusing on innovation.

review_title: Been a good run, but shutting the doors soon
pros: Great company and pay, great place to work. Had a wonderful career here, but the time is coming to a close
cons: Quick decision to close the factory from what we have experienced, alot of very experience and knowledge going to potentially lose their jobs

pros: Working conditions and benefits are very good, flexible working hours and the possibility to work whenever you want or need to online from home is very efficient in balancing family and career.
cons: Work structure within defined job is very confined and repetitive therefore one finds oneself doing the same things over and over again.

review_title: A great company to work with
pros: Great company culture which integrates you seamlessly with such a globally dispersed organisation. Intel pays comparative to the market trends on the higher side which is good, flexibility in working schedules..
cons: Still heavily inclined on US based decision making which never gives you end to end ownership of a product, work life effectiveness is bad as you move up the ladder,,

pros: Tech titan, semiconductor manufacturing leader, great employee benefits, excellent bonuses when company does well, Intel Education Service Corps, stock purchase program, retirement contributions.
cons: Late to the tablet and smartphone markets, core PC business not growing any more - new management focusing on wearables and Internet of Things too - significant uncertainty lies ahead.

review_title: Highly competitive workplace working on the cutting edge technology in the engineering field..

review_title: Bad HR and Management practices at Intel GDC Guadalajara.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros:
- Payment is good 

- The stocks share plan is very good for long term employees 

There are some benefits that include some food from the cafeteria
cons:
- The work culture at GDC facility is terrible. 30% of employees do most of the job,  and 70% are employees who don't focus on specific task accomplishments, thanks to the management sponsorship. 

- Human resources department does not protect the employee... Once you have an issue with a manager you can be laid off with out any consideration about your performance regardless if you show clear reports about your results. 

- It depends a lot of your manager to have a fair amount of balance between your personal life and work life. Be careful to be part of the 30% that actually perform, Otherwise you are fine. Very small room for innovation. 

- Intel in general is not doing very well this days so don't expect to have your job safe etc all. You can be candidate for layoffs at any time with no valid reason. 

- Do you want to have a more challenging position, even working at USA?  Forget about it you need the blessing from all (Mexican) management to apply anywhere in the organization, no matter how capable you are, or how hard you work to get a position. 

- Once I asked a senior employee if Intel was a fun ride... Her answer was an elegant No.

review_title: OK, but not much of a future
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Good work life balance.
cons: Management is terrible for the most part. Untrained ex-engineers for the most part that don't know anything about people management. The prospects in New Mexico are VERY limited now. They're fighting for their lives and it shows on how they now treat their employees.

pros:
Good compensation and benefits.

Interesting problems to work on.
cons: The employee review system is set up to force a performance distribution, whether or not there are any poor performers or not. Managers are forced to give bad ratings even if all of their people are performing well.

review_title: Not the place it used to be.
pros: Really smart, hard-working people. Sabbatical program gives much needed time off every 4-7 years. Free fruit (limited to one piece per day so make sure you get a good one).
cons: The place has lost its way under the new CEO. Political infighting. A culture of fear. The values are all talk no action. Don't make waves.

pros:
You will develop top-notch core knowledge on x86 and embedded systems.
You will work in a very collaborative environment where the bar is pretty high.
Very formative experience.
cons:
A lot of red tape in the engineering (product development) process, imposed by management which stifles productivity.
A fast career track within the team seems to be discouraged by management.

pros: One of the leaders in CMOS foundry/manufacturing technology. Have good healthcare benefits. If you work for seven years you get a sabbatical. Descent retirement benefits.
cons: No work life balance, absolutely none. Work environment is very much a silo-model. Management cares about one thing and only one thing, the schedule. Unrealistic schedules which burns out employees. You can get pigeon-holed into one type of assignment. When you leave, it is hard to find another job, because of your limited knowledge (no breadth). Additionally you work with CAD tools which the rest of the industry is not familiar with.
